PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Condor Laucke) took the chair at 2.30 p.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) left Australia on 30 May to attend the 67th session of the International Labour Conference in Geneva. The Minister for Education (Mr Fife) will act as Minister for Industrial Relations until Mr Viner returns on 22 June.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on 30 May 1981 of His Excellency, President Ziaur Rahman, President of the People's Republic of Bangladesh since 1977, and tenders its profound sympathy to his family and to the people of Bangladesh.

Bangladesh has lost, under tragic circumstances, a leader of zeal and integrity. His loss is one that Bangladesh can ill afford. His dedication to the development of rural Bangladesh and its huge population was one of the principal reasons why his party won a substantial majority in the democratic elections held in 1979. He spared no efforts either at home or abroad to achieve the objects that were the basis of his election and continuing popularity. He became a leader of the least developed countries. The late President was highly respected by all for his views within the North-South debate. Within the non-aligned movement and the Islamic Conference, he had established himself as an independent and moderate leader.

President Ziaur had strong links with the Commonwealth and it was gratifying that he attended the first Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting in Sydney in 1978. The friendship between our two countries has grown and strengthened in recent years. Australia was one of the first countries to recognise the newly independent nation in 1971 and we sponsored its membership of the United Nations and the Commonwealth. In the past year, Bangladesh was the third largest recipient of Australian bilateral development aid and an increasingly important trade partner. The late President was aware of these important links.

We were particularly shocked by the circumstances of President Ziaur's assassination. This is the third occasion in recent months on which a world leader has been the subject of political violence. It is impossible to express in words the abhorrence that Australians feel about events of this nature. They deserve the strongest condemnation by all people. All members of the Senate and all other Australians will join me in condemning this brutal act and in extending our sympathy to the President's family and to the people of Bangladesh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish only to associate the Opposition with the expressions of condolence by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) in the remarks which he has made.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- Mr President, I wish to ask whether you were consulted about and whether you gave permission for the clearing of King's Hall, realising, of course, a very unpleasant situation was developing in King's Hall. I wonder whether those who gave the order for the clearance anticipated the violence that would follow-that women would be dragged from the hall and children would be pushed down the stairs of Parliament House. Mr President, were you informed? Did you take into consideration the fact that this is the people's Parliament and that, no matter how erratically and how extraordinarily people may behave, it is their Parliament and such action against them should not be tolerated? In the 13 years that I have been a member of this Parliament, I have not seen a scene such as developed today in King's Hall. I know that the blame may rest very heavily on those women who gathered in King's Hall. Nevertheless, the responsibility for the resulting debacle must rest on those who gave the order to clear. Were you consulted, Mr President?

—In response, I refer firstly to the latter part of Senator Georges's question when he said, and rightly so, that this is the people's Parliament. That, and the desire and the need to ensure free and easy access by all citizens to this Parliament, weighed very heavily on my mind, having experienced disturbances here on previous occasions. No person or body of persons coming here should so act as to intrude on the rights of all other Australians who come here. Yes, I was consulted. Mr Speaker and I consulted. The decision to permit eviction proceedings to be taken was not an easy decision to make. I can assure the honourable senator that everyone concerned was advised not to use unnecessary force and to avoid causing any hurt or harm to anybody. We appreciated the gravity of the situation in doing what had to be done, but this place must go on uninterrupted.
—I wish to ask a further question.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I do not want to intervene as I think that this is an important matter, but I suggest that Senator Georges should seek leave. If he does, we will give it to him. Such questions could be asked at Question Time. If he seeks leave to make a further comment, I will go along with it.
—Mr President, I seek leave to make a further comment.
—Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

—I thought that any supplementary question would be covered by my first request for leave, which I was granted. Nevertheless, I have now sought further leave and I thank the Senate for granting that leave. I should have thought that all the members of this Parliament, especially the Opposition, through the leaders of the Opposition would have been consulted in some way. I take it that that was not done. No appeal was made to me to try to find out in some way whether any of my constituents were involved so that I could appeal to them to use, shall we say, more sedate methods. I was going to say 'respectable methods' but it seems to me that a certain section of society has found that respectable approaches are no longer to any avail. Nevertheless, was the Opposition consulted? If not, why were members of the Parliament not appealed to in some way to try to separate out and quieten down those people who felt it necessary to take part in such a demonstration? In spite of all the attempts to avoid it, acts of extreme violence occurred in King's Hall. There is no doubt that the police had to use and did use extreme violence against individuals in King's Hall. Those who made the decision should have taken that into account.

—The final decision in such matters is the responsibility of the Presiding Officers. Mr Speaker and I, after consultation and deep consideration of the matter, gave instructions for the action of eviction to take place with the least violence possible, given the situation, which was not taken lightly in making that decision.

—by leave-Mr President, in view of what you have just said, I think you should know that I stood in King's Hall and watched women dragged, bump by bump, down the steps from King's Hall. There were at least as many policemen present as there were women, so the police could have at least picked the women up and carried them outside, but they did not. They dragged them down the steps, in some cases by their hair. I had to stand in this Parliament building at the top of the stairs and hold a small child while she screamed in terror because a policeman was taking her mother away. I say that, if we cannot keep order, if we believe that this is the people's House, and if you are forced at some stage, Mr President, to declare that certain people should be removed because the Parliament cannot go about its business, then surely those orders can be given so that people can be removed in a civilised fashion. This afternoon the scene was like every scene I have seen out of every film about fascism in this world. I stood in the hall and watched women, who had stood aside with their children, herded out of the hall, in much the same way as women without children were herded out of the hall. I hope that if ever again you have to give those sorts of orders you will remember some of these remarks.
—I note the honourable senator's remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-My remarks will be quite brief. Today is a sad day for Canberra. The last time we saw brutality of this nature was when police were forced by the then Minister for the Interior, Mr Hunt, to remove the black embassy from outside Parliament House. I understand that one of the women involved has a broken arm and that other injuries have been sustained. Under these circumstances, if there are any injuries, I ask whether you, Mr President, or Mr Speaker, have done something about getting medical treatment for the people. The group was engaged in a perfectly legitimate exercise. The Government has seen fit to take away the funding from a group in the community which needs it most. This is its only way of showing protest. The people used no violence at any stage. I understand that a number of the policemen involved are extremely upset because they were forced to carry out this brutal eviction from what has been said--

SPEECH.PARA: Government senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be all right for honourable senators on the Government side to get a fit of the giggles. They are all in receipt of handsome salaries, none of them are hungry, none of them have their womenfolk in King's Hall battling for a mere living on a government pension. Mr President, I am disappointed that you had to be involved in the matter. You have had a very good reign in the Senate as our President, but in the last three weeks of your reign you have been forced into this situation where you have had to order brutality to be carried out within Parliament House.
—That is not true.

—Of course it was brutality. If honourable senators on the Government side were out there and were pulled by their hair down the front stairs they would realise exactly how we feel about it. I suggest that it ill becomes those Government senators, who are turning this matter into a joke and a charade, to carry on with their interjections of this nature. Obviously they strongly support the brutality that has just been carried out and they like seeing it done. This Senate will not be turned into a fascist House even if people such as the Liberal senator from Warrnambool, who frequently goes to sleep in the chamber anyway, now approve of what has happened.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, it was not my intention to make a statement and it is not my intention to turn this matter into a debate. It is my intention, at a subsequent stage, to suggest that the Senate might debate the substance of the matter. I want to put the matter into perspective. I reject out of hand the claims of Senator Keeffe of the Australian Labor Party, who spoke before me. The Government finds no joy or happiness at all in the situation, but we accept, and I hope the Australian Labor Party accepts, the fact that the two Presiding Officers have a very serious responsibility. That responsibility relates to the orderliness of conduct and behaviour within the precincts of the Parliament and the degree of protest movement, if any, within those precincts, as distinct from the place outside where protests normally occur. If any of the circumstances, as described by one or two honourable senators, did occur this morning, I hope that they took the number of the Commonwealth policeman so engaged, because if they did not--
—No. It is not their responsibility at all.
—I ask honourable senators to hear me out. If they did not do that, they were recreant in their action. Honourable senators have the opportunity--
—Goodness gracious me!

—I do not want to turn this matter into a debate. I want to make this statement as seriously as I possibly can. It is just as wrong for us to make statements which we cannot prove against police as it is to make such statements against any other citizen. I do not know what went on. I did not see it. However, several times in the course of the last week, I saw something unique to me, that is, King's Hall largely obstructed by a demonstration. I would be second to none in favour of the right of people to protest, but the right of people to protest in a large way in King's Hall is a matter for very serious consideration by the Presiding Officers. It is also the people's Parliament and there should be freedom of access and egress of visitors and members of the Parliament. So this matter raises fundamental questions. I call upon anybody who saw an act of violence by a police officer to name that officer or to give details of that situation. I invite them to give--
—Do we run around with a little book in our hands?

—If they do not have the details, I invite them to give a description of the incident. Mr President, I suggest to you- you require no such suggestion-that you seek a report both from police officers and from your attendants who were in King's Hall at the time. In due course, I hope you will make available a statement to this Senate and we will debate it.
—I note what the honourable senator has said and will give consideration to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MELZER

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 17 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Ex-Servicemen's and Women's Pension Association is a body formed for the express purpose of obtaining a Service Pension for all Ex-Service Personnel at sixty years of age for men and fifty-five years of age for women regardless of where they served during the 1939-45 war.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should give urgent consideration to a favourable decision to the granting of the Service Pension to all Ex-Service Personnel who served their Country in time of need and who did not serve overseas through no fault of their own. The Service Pension is presently only granted to Returned Ex-Service Personnel.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Clerk-A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving 'property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects, namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programs,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Communications to a question I gave him notice of on Thursday last and asked in the Senate on Friday last and to the fact that the question of which he had notice specifically asked for the earliest date on which any draft of the broadcasting and television legislation was made available to and discussed with certain organisations. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that his assertion in the Senate on Friday that he was not given any notice of that specific question is incorrect. As the Minister has had notice for some five days of this question requiring specific pieces of information, I now ask him again: What was the earliest date on which any draft of the broadcasting and television legislation was, firstly, made available to, and, secondly, discussed with News Ltd, Consolidated Press, the Fairfax organisation, the National Regional Television Association of Australia, the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations and the Government back bench communications committee?

—The answer that the honourable senator seeks requires considerable detail which can be supplied only by the Minister whom I represent in this place. The honourable senator's question has been noted and every effort is being made to get him the detailed information.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs noted a statement in the annual report of the Committee on Overseas Professional Qualifications that there was a 100 per cent increase in the number of assessments of the qualifications in 1980 on the number assessed in 1979? Can the Minister provide the Senate with a dissection of the assessments processed, including the number of approvals for each profession by the countries of origin of candidates for both 1979 and 1980?
—The answer to that question will require a certain amount of detail. I will refer the question to the Minister and ask him to provide that information as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INVESTMENT IN AUSTRALIAN FILMS: TAXATION DEDUCTIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the Treasurer's recent decision that, in future, taxation deductions on investment in Australian films will be available only when approved films are completed and are being exhibited. Did the Treasurer not foresee that his decision would mean that film producers would be forced by investors into making cheap 'quickies' completed in less than one year and that plans for high quality productions involving production periods of two and three years would be shelved? Does the Minister agree that this is a manifestly unfair decision which, if carried through, would constitute a massive blow to an infant Australian industry which has distinguished itself in an extraordinary fashion by its progress over the last few years? Is the Prime Minister in the process of intervening in this situation and urging that the Treasurer adopt a compromise formula which would better serve the interests of the Australian film industry? If so, what is the nature of the compromise and the stage that it has reached at the moment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp has raised a matter which is of considerable interest and which has had public comment in recent days. He has referred to the position which has arisen under the legislation introduced for taxation deductions for investment in the film industry. The matter has had comment from the Prime Minister, I think as recently as last Sunday night when he referred to this matter in a speech that he made. The Treasurer has had numerous representations on the subject. He also has had meetings with representatives of the film industry. I understand also that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Wilson, has had many representations on the same subject.

ANSWER.PARA: The views that have been expressed have been taken into account and noted by the members of the Government who have spoken with film industry representatives. At this stage I can say only that the Treasurer expects to be making a statement on the matter shortly. I am unable to give the detail which was requested by Senator Chipp in his question, although I understand that the matters that were referred to by him will be covered by the statement of the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —No doubt the Minister representing the Minister for Communications is aware of the student-run radio station, Dynamic Radio CHY, the cable radio station situated in Coffs Harbour which directly involves some 250 students. Is the Minister also aware that this station has been actively seeking an FM broadcasting licence for the last six years without success? Is the Minister further aware that his predecessor met in Canberra last September with the general manager and five student announcers, and publicly promised that the licence would be given immediate attention? When will such immediate attention be given, thus encouraging and ensuring the continued participation of these young people in this worthwhile community project?

—I note that Senator Bonner referred to a meeting which took place. I am unable to comment upon that meeting. I am aware, as are other senators, that the group representing this radio station recently made us more aware than we were previously of some of the local produce for which the Coffs Harbour area is famous. I am advised that in 1979 a draft planning proposal concerning both public and commercial radio services for the Coffs Harbour area was circulated and that various comments on the draft proposal were received. I understand that the final proposal is at present under active consideration and that a number of complex matters requiring resolution are still under consideration. The Minister is aware of the desire of Radio CHY to go on air without delay. It is hoped to be able to resolve any outstanding problems as soon as possible. However, Radio CHY has still to be considered as part of a comprehensive plan for both AM and FM radio on the mid-North Coast.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not feel like asking a question after witnessing that spectacle in King's Hall. Nevertheless--

QUESTION.PARA: Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If honourable senators opposite want to start me off, they can quite easily. Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that the deregulation of interest rates has now led to a scramble for deposits in the market place? Is she aware that such fierce competition is likely to endanger smaller financial institutions? Having that in mind, is the Treasurer prepared to bring interest rates again under control and regulation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer to the Treasurer the question from the honourable senator as to whether the Treasurer is prepared to bring interest rates under control. The policy of the Government on this matter was announced earlier. I will see whether the Treasurer wishes to comment on any change to that policy.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. Has the Commonwealth followed up its support in principle for the establishment of an Australian Children's Television Foundation? Since the Australian Education Council's meeting last February in Hobart when all States and the Commonwealth looked to this Foundation as the best way to provide for and promote improved television programs for children, the objectives and the budget for the Foundation have been decided, and most State governments have com- mitted their share of the funding to the Foundation. I urge the Government to provide in the Budget the proposed Commonwealth share, which I understand to be $377,000. Finally I ask: Is the Government aware that this kind of initiative was strongly recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, the Davidson Committee, in its now widely acclaimed report on children and television?

—I can certainly respond emphatically to the last aspect of the question. What is known as the Davidson Committee-the Senate Standing Committee-did very valuable work and produced a very significant document that has been widely accepted in the community. I acknowledge the work of both sides of the chamber on it in terms of children's television. That has been the basis for the commencement of a useful dialogue throughout Australia and, I understand, in the Australian Education Council. My understanding is that there has been a substantial agreement on the general principles. I am not sure as to the point of decision-making in a budgetary sense.
—He is asking you to put your money where your mouth is.

—I understand Senator Button's interjection. He also understands that the Government puts its money where its mouth is in August of each year when it brings down its Budget. It will no doubt do that. I will bring that specific aspect to the attention of the responsible Ministers. If they have a comment they can make it directly to Senator Teague.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Under the new health arrangements will a disadvantaged person, say, a low income person who is in receipt of a special card to obtain health treatment and who receives an increased income and therefore joins a voluntary health fund, have to wait the normal two-month period before becoming eligible, at any scale, under the health funds?
—No.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Does that mean that people can go from a disadvantaged status, take out full benefit cover and still not have to wait the two-month qualifying period?
—My understanding is yes.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. I refer to the decision by the committee for the Review of Commonwealth Functions to abolish the Curriculum Development Centre unless the States agree to contribute 50 per cent of the operating costs. What stage has been reached in negotiations with the States? Have the States indicated that they wish the Centre to continue?

—The Senate of course will know that the Curriculum Development Centre is essentially a Commonwealth-State organisation. It is a body which is, to an extent, funded by both the Commonwealth and the States and therefore it is no new principle that the sharing of funds should go ahead. It is just that now the basis is to be 50 per cent. I understand from the responsible Minister that discussions are proceeding with the States at this moment. I understand that the discussions are not finalised. I cannot indicate the point they have reached. The States tend to do a considerable amount of curriculum development work. They look to the Curriculum Development Centre for special kinds of projects. It may well be that one of the solutions will be for the Australian Education Council to identify from time to time particular projects which would then have the 50 per cent blessing of the States and the Commonwealth. I will refer the question to the responsible Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, refers to the as yet unreleased draft report of the International Energy Agency for 1980 entitled 'Overview and overall evaluation of Australia's energy performance'. I understand it was prepared towards the end of 1980. Paragraph 56 of that report refers to a 1979 Australian Government submission estimating shale oil production in 1990 at 235,000 barrels a day. The figure was reduced to 40,000 barrels a day in the 1980 Australian Government submission. In other words, the Government has drastically scaled down its Rundle estimates and/or extended the time frame. Did the 1979 and 1980 submissions to the IEA come from his Department? If so, will he table those submissions? If they did come from his Department why, as late as his 2 February 1981 Press conference, was the Minister still talking up Rundle shares? I refer for example, to statements such as this:

QUESTION.PARA: The fact is that there's some ten billion dollars of copartnership of the Australian partners and Exxon say that they are going to produce shale oil in Australia at import parity prices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —To put Senator Walsh's question in perspective, the International Energy Agency from time to time visits one of the member countries and, with its own assessors, independently makes its assessments of what is happening with regard to energy in that country. That is precisely what happened. Members of the IEA came to Australia. They had complete freedom of movement and they sought their information wherever they wished to do so. Of course, they had discussions with my Department. I am not aware of anything in the nature of official submissions being made. My understanding is that that is not how it works; rather, there are general discussions between the Government and the IEA and the IEA then produces a draft report and, ultimately, a full report. I believe that within the immediate months ahead the IEA is likely to produce a full report. Certainly that will be made available. My instinct is that the IEA will regard oil from shale as one of the most significant cost effective sources of synthetic crude oil for the future, but that will be a matter for judgment when the report comes around.

ANSWER.PARA: The general understanding when the IEA representatives were in Australia was based upon the reports of the companies concerned-acting, I believe, in good faith-that they would have the pilot plant in position and proceeding to production from 1984-85 onwards. No doubt, the IEA made its own assessment in that regard. So all that has happened, as is the case with any mining venture, is that certain mining and cost difficulties have been perceived and the mining venture itself has therefore made some rearrangements. The statement by the Rundle consortium in recent days has shown the path on which it should proceed in the future.

It is significant that, with the knowledge that Rundle was under question and, indeed, at the very time it was the subject of controversy, there should have emerged discussions between some of the Rundle partners-the Australian partners and the Japanese National Oil Corporation, JANOC-to set up heads of agreement for a feasibility study of Condor, another shale oil deposit. With all that knowledge, the Japanese, including the Japanese technologists, believe that shale oil is likely to be a very significant part of the general program for synthetic crude oil in the future.

Once again, Senator Walsh has suggested that I talked up the price of the shares. I wish to state what is now history, and in Hansard. The prices of shares in Rundle moved substantially downward from high levels in, say, October and November of last year and were halved prior to my visit to Rundle; so the prices of the shares were falling, due undoubtedly to judgments made in the market place. On that we had no influence, direct or indirect, at all. There was no intention of talking up or talking down shares. Had the Government and I wanted in any way to alter the position in the market place as such in a talking-up fashion, the last thing we would have done, once we discovered that there was a difficulty-a perceptibly different viewpoint amongst the partners from that in the market place-would have been to seek the earliest possible public exposure of the matter. The contrary is true.

If the intention of honourable senators opposite is to suggest that shale oil is not a likely significant syncrude, I believe that that perception will not be held by the experts. If there is some movement in the development of shale so that it comes on stream not by 1990 but during the 1990s, that may very well be because the import parity pricing policies of the Government are producing more oil in Bass Strait and elsewhere than had previously been thought possible, and therefore the capacity to achieve an energy balance in Australia is becoming more apparent. I hope that in due course we will be able to publish figures in that regard. Therefore, those who are seeking to produce synthetic crudes may believe that the time frame and the lead times are longer than they may have judged to be the case before.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. As the Minister has now told us that the International Energy Agency's drastic downgrading of Rundle's prospects between 1979 and 1980 was the product of its own deductions and was not a report on a submission by his Department, can he explain why the International Energy Agency had a much more realistic appreciation of Rundle's prospects way back in 1980 than either he or his Department had at the beginning of February 1981?

—The habit of some honourable senators, notably Senator Walsh, deliberately to misconstrue what I have said is one that I hope the Senate will deprecate. The fact is that the first half of the honourable senator's question bore no relationship whatsoever to my reply, and I reject it out of hand.

—I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to newspaper reports on Sunday and yesterday in which the South Australian Premier made reference to the supply of natural gas and the River Murray situation. I refer to that in passing. Is the Minister aware that statements such as those reported reflect the degree of frustration that is being felt by the Government of South Australia in its dealings over the River Murray? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether, as claimed by Mr Tonkin, the Federal Government has acknowl-edged that it has a responsibility to redress the situation and whether the Prime Minister has agreed that further action might be necessary? If so, can he say what form any further action might take?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a number of very detailed discussions with the Premier of South Australia, Mr Tonkin, commencing in recent times last Friday when we discussed this matter in detail in this building and during the weekend when we met under other circumstances. The Prime Minister also had some discussions, in which I joined. The fact is that the Commonwealth Government recognises that the River Murray and its main tributary, the River Darling, are of immense significance not only to the States through which they move but also nationally. Downstream they are of great significance to South Australia. As everyone knows, there is, largely in Victoria but also elsewhere, an inland dried seabed of immense proportions which, when there are droughts and when irrigation is misused and raises the water table, produces excess saline into the water in the Murray. That has serious consequences for agriculture. That situation becomes exacerbated when drought does not allow a flush to go down the Darling into the Menindee Lakes and, therefore, to dilute the salt. It is a sad fact that about 1.5 million tonnes of salt is going down the Murray from the dried seabed.

ANSWER.PARA: The great solution would be for the good Lord to continue to send us sufficient rain so that the Dartmouth Dam, which is 40 per cent full, could reach its full capacity and so that the Hume Dam, which is 10 per cent full, could be filled so that we might let water flow further down the Murray. Against that background, the Commonwealth and the States have been working very closely to get a new River Murray Agreement which will place emphasis not only on quantity of water but also on quality; and it is the quality factor that is highly significant. The States have made enormous progress and are within only one factor of reaching total agreement. We have asked the New South Wales Government whether, in good faith, it will reach an agreement on this matter. The significant point is that we are asking the New South Wales Government to be willing to agree that the agreement should state that where the Government proposes to take any action which would have a significant effect on the future quantity and quality of water it will notify the River Murray Commission prior to taking that action.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is all governments, Senator?

—Yes, all governments, but I have to say that we have the agreement of the other governments to this. I am not being in any way critical. I pay tribute to the fact that the Water Resources Commission in New South Wales contains officers of very superior standards who are good Australians and who are trying to get a result. The Minister was prepared, under his own authority, to go as far as to agree with respect to water use for irrigation, but naturally we need it with respect to paper mills, industry and so on. What has happened is that there has been consultation on the wider sphere. I understand indirectly that progress is being made. I am enormously hopeful that we will reach that result with the good will of the New South Wales Government. I believe that it understands fully the need to take a national view on the matter.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question asked, of course South Australia is frustrated. If honourable senators were facing at this moment, as a result of such a drought, a situation in which the river mouth was sanded up and in which downstream irrigation was producing a situation in which there were strong saline levels in the stream which were damaging plant life, of course they would be frustrated. The Premier indicated his frustration. He has indicated, of course, that he has no intention at all of using the duress of gas supply. He is using the parallel that he has a national responsibility for the gas supplies that come out of South Australia. Honourable senators should take that in good faith. As to the future, let us get the agreement in position first because if, with good will on all sides--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what we want-good will from South Australia-and you know it.

—That is right. I would like a little good will when I am trying to explain a very serious problem. If we have good will on all sides about the use in a national sense of the Murray River and the Darling River and the fact that everybody using its tributaries has a responsibility nationally, we will get an agreement in place. If it is not totally good enough, we will take the next step. But an ability to apprehend changes in quality and quantity will enable the River Murray Commission, ahead of the fact, to expose the fact to the world, to create a dialogue and, therefore, to initiate other action. As to further matters, the Commonwealth Government matches dollar for dollar anti-salination measures for the River Murray. Apart from that, I urge everyone to continue to pray for rain.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Has the Department of Finance advised the Australian Broadcasting Commission that its operational budget, excluding salaries, will be frozen in 1981-82 at this financial year's money levels, that is, be reduced in real terms by some 10 per cent? Has the Federal Government, as a result of the razor gang's report, required the ABC to reduce staff by a further 2 per cent, that is, further to the 15 per cent reduction achieved in the last five years? Why have these decisions, with the potentially disastrous impact on the quality of programming and, indeed, the very viability of this national organisation, been taken before the Dix Committee has delivered its report to the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — At present the Government is conducting discussions with Ministers with regard to the forthcoming Budget. Preliminary rounds of discussions have been held with a number of Ministers and some have yet to be held. No final decisions on funding for the forthcoming year have been made with regard to departments or instrumentalities at this stage. Certain guidelines were given in these preliminary talks on the formation of the Budget and the consideration of the level of funds next year bearing relationship to the funds received in the present year. As I have said, no final decisions have been made with regard to funding for the forthcoming year. This will not occur until such time as we have Budget Cabinet. The discussions which are being held are preliminary and they will then become the subject of Cabinet discussions at a later stage.

ANSWER.PARA: I will need to look at the latter part of Senator Tate's question to see whether information can be given to him. The Dix Committee's report is awaited with some interest by the Government and, I am sure, by the community in general. It is not a case of pre-empting recommendations that may be made in that Committee's report and that may have led us to have some Budget discussions. These need to occur in the usual time frame for forming a Budget. We will certainly await with interest and consider seriously the recommendations that come forward from that Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I think that one point was inadvertently missed by the Minister. I asked: Has the Federal Government required the ABC to reduce staff by a further 2 per cent as a result of the razor gang's deliberations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The review committee's requirements of all departments and instrumentalities were that there be staff reductions. The ABC was dealt with in that report in the same way as other departments and instrumentalities were.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Although it is perhaps not a good week in which to refer to the subscriber trunk dialling public telephones, that is what I want to refer to. I am well aware of the problem of vandalism to public telephones in isolated areas and the costs of repairing such damage. Has Telecom Australia considered designing a less bulky and cheaper to build public telephone for use in areas that are relatively free from vandalism, preferably one that is made in Australia and not in Japan, as I believe the large green telephones are? They work very well. Further, in line with my aim to encourage the Department of the Treasury to produce an up-to-date range of coins in this country, will the Minister ask Telecom to examine and report to the Treasury on its need for a coin of $2 or $5 for use in public telephones, particularly where international subscriber dialling is connected?

—The honourable senator asks an important question, particularly as it refers to making it easier for people to make ISD or STD calls from public telephone boxes. I am attracted as well to other parts of his question, where he refers to the production of telephone sets and hand sets which are vandal free, or to telephone boxes which might be more resistant to vandalism. The question he asked regarding a $2 or $5 coin is obviously one which would have to be referred to the Treasurer as well as to the Minister for Communications. It would involve a policy decision on the part of the Government. I will undertake to refer the question appropriately.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that the real effective exchange rate appreciated by between 4 per cent and 5 per cent during 1980? What has been the effect of this appreciation on the farm exporting sector? Is the appreciation due to the Government's much vaunted resource and energy investment boom? If so, what steps is the Government taking to reduce the adverse impact on Australia's rural exporters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will have the details of that question referred to the Treasurer for his comment as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMUNICATIONS IN REMOTE AREAS: TELECOM DISPUTE

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Communications inform the Senate of what action is being taken to ensure that remote communities in Australia, such as pastoral stations, Aboriginal communities and mining towns in the Northern Territory, are not left without communications in emergency situations during the present Telecom Australia dispute? Can the Minister also advise what efforts have been taken to date to provide special exemptions from the bans imposed by the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union and the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association for the Northern Territory and similarly placed parts of Australia where telecommunications are vital to medical, business, police and all other matters, not forgetting, of course, matters of national importance including quarantine, Customs security and surveillance? Further, can the Minister inform the Senate of what response he or the unions have given to repeated requests from the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory for a special exemption from bans for remote communities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that communications in remote areas of Australia are difficult enough in normal circumstances and at normal times. That they should be made more difficult or put more at risk is quite unreasonable. The Government is monitoring very closely the effect of any union bans on Telecom services. The honourable senator can rest assured that every effort will be made to ensure that the network is protected should the situation deteriorate. At present the bans are not having any effect on the Telecom network. In relation to the points raised by the honourable senator about emergency situations, I am advised that the unions have stated that what are called 'life and limb services' will be exempted from the bans.

ANSWER.PARA: So far as the request by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory for an exemption for the Northern Territory is concerned, I can only say that a response on that matter is not one which government can make. The unions have to respond as to whether they will accede to the request from Mr Everingham. The unions, after all, initiated the industrial action and it is in their power to lift or amend the bans.

It is pleasing to note that the unions are presently meeting with Telecom in private conference under the chairmanship of Deputy President Maddern of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It is to be hoped that these discussions will lead to a resolution of the dispute. I come back to the first point I made: We are well aware that conditions are difficult enough in the remote areas of Australia. We hope that the benefits of such communication as is available are not to be denied to the people in those areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy will recall his many answers to questions in the Senate in respect of the River Murray and its tributaries, in which he has rightfully emphasised that under the Federal Constitution each State of Australia has sovereign rights over the water resources within its declared boundaries. In view of the statements made by Mr Arnold, the South Australian Minister of Water Resources, reported in the Adelaide News of 14 May, that he does not discount the possibility of taking legal action against New South Wales to prevent any further theft of water from the Murray's tributaries and the further threat by the South Australian Premier, Mr Tonkin, during the National Liberal Party Conference in Canberra at the weekend that he would cut off natural gas supplies to New South Wales unless the State ceased its strangling and restriction of South Australia's water supply, I ask: Did Mr Tonkin get a Government assurance at the weekend, as he has claimed he did, that the withdrawal of Federal funding for water resources projects would be considered as a means of getting a reaction from the New South Wales Government? In what years, if any, has South Australia not received its full entitlement of water under the River Murray Waters Agreement, as is claimed to be the case by both Mr Arnold and Mr Tonkin? What evidence is there that New South Wales has been thieving water which, they claim, rightfully belongs to South Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is abundantly true that Australia is a federation and that within the federation those rivers which run through a State are the responsibility of the State.
—Come on! It is a national resource. Why fiddle around?

—Senator Georges should contain himself. If he has an argument on this matter, he should be arguing with his colleague. It is his colleague who has asked me whether this matter comes under State sovereignty. I suggest that Senator McLaren take Senator Georges aside in the future and explain the matter to him. I regard this question as a serious one. As to the first matter--
—You are the architect of the problem.
—Senator Georges, do not interject; the question has been asked.

—As to the first matter, the answer is yes; under federation the States have responsibilities for the rivers that run through them. Had I been allowed to proceed without interruption I would have said that nevertheless the only two great river systems in Australia, the Murray and the Darling-they are really only one system-have such national consequences, as I said in answer to a question earlier today, that of course there is a need for Federal-State co-operation. That is evidenced in the River Murray Commission. It is evidenced in the National Water Resources Council, of which I am a member. It is acknowledged in the national water resources programs and in a variety of programs in which the Commonwealth seeks consensus with the States to use resources to the best advantage. It is quite natural for the South Australian Minister of Water Resources to be apprehensive when he observes that States are continuing to develop along the tributaries irrigation projects which, in his perception, will draw off water-not simply interfere with the quantity of water-and by drawing off water will interfere with the flush and therefore alter the rate of salinity and turbidity in the journey.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of the matter is that a time will come-and very soon-when no new water licences for irrigation can be permitted in any reasonable way by a State along the River Murray's tributaries, if the quality and quantity of the Murray are to persist. That is a nice question of judgment and it is a nice question of self-control and management that the States will have to exercise. The States, by their actions, have added to the problems. For example, the detreeing of areas along the Victorian reaches of the river and the use of water for irrigation have exacerbated the problem because the particular trees were salt-absorbent. So every State has a responsibility in this matter.

I can fully understand Mr Arnold's frustration and sense of indignation that this matter has not been resolved. I am not aware of what legal matters Mr Arnold may seek to pursue. That is a matter between him and others. As I have said, I read a statement in a newspaper by Mr Tonkin regarding gas supply but I took it to mean that he paralleled the fact that gas came from his State with the fact that he had a national responsibility and other States should share that responsibility. I believe that New South Wales will accept that national responsibility.

A number of discussions took place between Mr Tonkin and me, and no doubt between the Prime Minister and Mr Tonkin, regarding the future development of dams which may be used to store water high up on tributaries and therefore lower the volume and quality of water further down. I indicated that there will have to be discussions between the various States as to the general philosophy for the future of the development of irrigation dams. There is a limit to the amount of water available. As I have said, the real problem is not only the salinity, which sadly enough largely comes from Victoria, but also the drought conditions, the lack of water flow down the Darling River which would dilute the salt and so alleviate the situation. South Australia has a quantity of water asserted to itself. That is an established fact. I think the real worry that Mr Arnold has in mind is that any further irrigation or industrial grants-riparian rights-might result in damaging not only the quality of water but also the quantity of water. I take the whole matter seriously and am endeavouring to get it to a proper solution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister: In view of the fact that Mr Arnold has accused New South Wales of thieving water-the Minister may not have this information at his fingertips-in what years, if any, has South Australia not received its proper entitlement under the River Murray Waters Agreement?

—I will get that information. I said that my understanding was that Mr Arnold was talking about the threat of extended irrigation and use of water by industrial plants, thus preventing it going downstream. This is not just a theft in quantity but also a theft in the sense that it denies the upstream quality of the water to users downstream.
—It denies the flush.

—It denies the flush. I think there is evidence that the lack of flow in the Darling, which has been aggravated by the growing irrigation from the tributaries higher up, has contributed to a situation which the drought itself caused initially. That is why I suggested that we should all pray earnestly for more rain.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Government aware of the well organised and steadily growing lobbying campaign aimed at relieving the present double taxation burden borne by those Australians holding shares in dividend paying companies? Is the Government conscious of the negative effect that this double taxation system has upon efforts to raise risk capital within Australia? Further, would the Government consider a reform which could reduce the need for overseas capital to develop Australia and also reduce the need for future generations of Australians to have to buy back the farm?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not know whether there has been any increase in the lobbying. I am aware that there always has been lobbying with regard to the issue of so-called double taxation concerning dividend paying companies. The Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, as I recall, did hold a seminar at which public expression could be made and I am aware that at that Committee's hearings a variety of views was expressed and there was fairly strong lobbying, if that is the term, on the effects of this so-called double taxation. I think other comments were made about alternative types of arrangements that could be undertaken.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer did point out earlier this year the cost of introducing a measure that would have the change envisaged by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. It would be a very considerable revenue cost and it is of such magnitude that the Government would need to be aware of the effect that it would have on the encouragement to small investors to undertake equity investment. It would need to outweigh the revenue that would be forgone under the present system. The material contribution that could be made by small investors to equity capital would be significant. Perhaps, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen has suggested, it may overcome some of our need for foreign capital in the development of some of our corporate structure. I think that there would be need to weigh these counterbalancing effects to see what the outcome of them will be. It may be that the Campbell Committee of Inquiry will report on such matters in detail sufficient to give us an overall picture of the effect of a change of this type. If not, I will see that the Treasurer is advised of the question of Senator Bjelke-Petersen and see whether he has any comment to make or any figures that may be able to be given to the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: What was Commonwealth revenue for each of the years 1975-76 to 1979-80? What is the latest estimate for revenue for 1980-81? What was the increase in the consumer price index between 1975-76 and 1979-80?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I suggest that that question be placed on notice for the details that have been requested.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DELORAINE BY-PASS ROAD: TASMANIAN NATIONAL HIGHWAY

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport whether there has been any report to the Minister for Transport concerning reported difficulties or increased costs in establishing suitable foundations for portion of the Deloraine by-pass road on the Tasmanian national highway. If not, can the Minister seek information on the matter, particularly as to whether any difficulties have arisen or may arise and whether they would affect the overall cost or time estimate of that project?

—Mr Hunt has provided some information on this matter, but I understand that he has not received a full report on it. He has told me that an investigation of the planning and design details of the proposed by-pass is currently being undertaken and that he is unaware of any foundation problems at present. He has also advised that officers of his Department have regular consultation with the Tasmanian Department of Main Roads on all matters affecting national roads in Tasmania and that his officers keep him informed on any significant developments, such as those to which Senator Archer referred. I will need to refer the question of timing and problems which may be related to that to Mr Hunt and obtain an answer for Senator Archer.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. While in the Antarctic earlier this year I was told that it is thought that Newcastle disease, a poultry disease, has been introduced to the Antarctic and is affecting penguin colonies. Can the Minister advise whether this is true? If the Government does not know, why does it not know? If it is true, what steps is the Government taking to protect Australia from the entry of this disease from that area? What steps is the Government taking in international areas to control and eradicate the disease in Antartica? If it is not true, what steps is the Government taking, nationally and internationally, to prevent an outbreak of this disease and other diseases in the Antarctic? Are people returning from the Antarctic subject to check in any way?

—Honourable senators will be aware that Australia is very concerned to prevent the entry of Newcastle disease or other exotic diseases into this country-diseases that could affect poultry or other diseases such as foot and mouth disease which could affect our national herd. The honourable senator will not be surprised to know that I do not have at my fingertips the precise details about the health status of Antarctic penguins, but I take the question very seriously because the honourable senator obviously made a valid point. If there is a reservoir of that exotic disease in the Antarctic it is a matter of potential importance to this country and to those who are concerned to keep Newcastle disease out of this country. The question is obviously one that will require reference to my colleague the Minister for Health. It might also involve reference to those other Ministers who have an interest in the Antarctic for other portfolio reasons. I will undertake to see that we get as comprehensive an answer as is possible to the various points which the honourable senator raised.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Government been approached by all or any of the following banks to be granted a licence to operate in competition in Australia against traditional Australian trading banks: The Bank of Tokyo Ltd, Chase Manhattan, the Midland Bank Group, Barclays, Citibank N.A., the Bank of America, and Citicorp? Further, is it the Government's intention to grant a licence or licences to any of these foreign banks? Finally, is this the rationale for the recent rush to merge by Australian trading banks?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — From time to time the Government has received expressions of interest from various foreign banks in relation to obtaining approval to operate in Australia. Some of the banks mentioned by the honourable senator could well be among their number. Such expressions of interest, of course, do not constitute a formal application for authority to conduct banking business in this country. The long standing policy of Australian governments on this matter is generally well understood by foreign banks, as is the fact that this policy may come under review in due course as a result of the recommendations of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. I could not speculate on the motives that may be involved in any pending applications from certain Australian banks or foreign banks seeking the Treasurer's consent to merge their operations. That is a matter which, of course, would be before the Treasurer for his decision. It is not something on which I could speculate with regard to motive. However, the applications and expressions of interest that flow in show that there is active interest in the banking sector in this country and it probably will be of great interest to us to see the findings of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Does the Commonwealth have any current plans to revive the Australian Constitutional Convention which last met in Perth in 1978 after three earlier sessions dating back to 1973? What information is the Attorney-General able to give about attitudes of the various other governments participating in the Convention to the holding of a further session of the Convention, on what date and at which place? If the Commonwealth is not prepared to initiate or actually participate in setting up another session of the Convention as it is presently structured, will it give consideration to the re-establishment of the Convention as a directly elected popular body with a view to creating some real momentum for a fundamental rewriting of the Constitution, perhaps with the 1988 bicentenary year as an appropriate target date?

—The Government has no plans to have another session of the Constitutional Convention. I am not aware of the attitudes of the State governments. There may have been some expressions of which I am not aware. I will have to inquire to make sure whether there has been any pressure from any State government; all I can say is that I am not aware of any. I am currently giving consideration to the whole question of the future of constitutional conventions. I will be taking the matter to Cabinet shortly. The question of our future attitude on it I trust will be resolved in the near future.

—I ask a supplementary question. Is one of the matters the Minister is taking to Cabinet a reshaping of the whole structure of the Convention along the popular directly elected lines I have suggested? Further, will he give me a detailed reply in writing of what is currently known about the attitudes of all the State governments to the further holding of another session?

—I will take the suggestion of a popular convention into account in the consideration I am giving to the future of the Constitutional Convention. As I have said, I will inquire into the actual current attitudes, if they are known, of other States to the Convention. I will let Senator Evans know.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to an article appearing in the Age of 13 May 1981 concerning the prolonged delay experienced in waiting for the Federal and Queensland governments to reach agreement on the boundaries of the Cairns section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Is it correct, as alleged in this article, that, despite a promise by one Federal Minister on the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council that the boundaries would be declared before the end of 1980, the Council has not met since last August? In the interests of those many conservation groups and concerned individuals seeking preservation of the reef, I ask: What reasons underlie the long delay in the declaration of the Cairns section of the proposed park? Has a definite date been set for the next Ministerial Council meeting? If so, when will it be held? Can we expect an early announcement on the declaration of the Cairns section?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Missen is correct. All Australians want to see the various sections of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park declared as soon as possible. However, joint action is required between two governments. These are two reasons for the delay in arranging a meeting of the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council and hence a delay in the declaration of the Cairns section of the marine park. The Queensland elections of late 1980 and the recent ministerial changes in Canberra led to some administrative hold-ups. I understand that last week the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment made a statement in another place when tabling the regulations for the Capricornia section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. In that statement the Minister said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Queensland Government has been asked to nominate its two representatives on the Council-

It is my colleague's understanding that the Commonwealth will be informed of these nominations in the very near future. We cannot reconvene the Ministerial Council until we have those nominations. A meeting of the Council will be convened as soon as is practicable after the Queensland Ministers have been formally nominated. I think the other events will flow from that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services been drawn to the population figures published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics which show a great relative variation from State to State? Is the Minister aware that, due to separate State and Federal electoral rolls in Queensland, many thousands of electors are left off one roll or the other in the mistaken belief that being on one roll automatically puts them on the other as is the practice in most other States? What is the Government's attitude towards the keeping of separate electoral rolls and the subsequent effect upon the right of citizens to vote in all elections if they are enrolled on one electoral roll?

—The Government would share Senator Gietzelt's concern that no Australian entitled to vote should be prevented from so doing because of unnecessary administrative complexity. If, in fact, special registration procedures exist in Queensland or any other State, and these are not well understood by potential voters, I am sure that the Government would want to examine what action might be taken to improve the situation. The honourable senator asked some quite particular questions and I will undertake to obtain a reply to them from my colleague.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in Question Time today, I was asked a question, and also a supplementary question, by Senator Grimes regarding the matter of eligibility for health cover of persons who lose their entitlement to a health care card. I took the question to be directed in the main to the matter of time lag. Upon reflection it occurred to me that it may have been directed more particularly to the level of cover that could be obtained. The position was made clear in a statement put out yesterday by the Minister for Health, part of which read:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government now has a policy of requiring registered health funds to waive the two months waiting period in the case of persons losing their eligibility for a Pensioner Health Benefit Card. The Government proposes to extend this policy to persons who lose their entitlement to a Health Care Card. I propose to shortly introduce legislation to give effect to this decision.
It can be seen that that statement relates to the question of-I am sorry--

TALK.START.PARA: —Asleep again.

—Yes, asleep again. My understanding is that that applies to basic cover under the new health policy-cover for 85 per cent of the scheduled fee for medical costs, and hospital care costs for shared ward accommodation in a public hospital. I will examine Senator Grimes's question more carefully when it is available in Hansard to ascertain whether the answer I have given has been adequate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Papers are presented in accordance with the list circulated to honourable senators. I seek leave to incorporate the list in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The list read as follows-
