TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I seek leave to make a very short statement on the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I am on my feet, I seek the co-operation of the Senate in its consideration of these papers. One could expect that quite a few of the papers that have been tabled would attract the interest of honourable senators. We are all aware of the extremely tight legislative program of the Senate for the next two weeks. I therefore ask honourable senators who wish to take note of these papers to move only to take note and not to speak to such motion. My Whip has given an undertaking to the Opposition-one which I endorse-that during the first week of the Budget sittings the Government will allocate a significant part of a sitting day to the consideration of these and other reports presented to the Senate. I ask for the goodwill of the Senate. In that spirit I undertake that opportunity will be given to debate fully papers that are indicated as being considered important.
—by leave-The proposal made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) was put to the Opposition just before lunch today.
—Yes; I am sorry.
—I have indicated that the Opposition will seek to co-operate in the matter but will not agree to a situation in which no statements would be capable of being addressed today.
—Surely.

—But that, in the light of that qualification and of the Minister's undertaking, the Opposition would try to confine its remarks on the various statements. In the same context, I should say that recently it was suggested that the Opposition should propose only one speaker on legislation before the Senate during the remainder of the session. That is another request to which the Opposition will not agree. I point out that a week or two ago we offered to co-operate by having only one speaker on a number of measures. However, the Opposition appreciates the concern behind the Minister's suggestions and, whilst not accepting them, will endeavour to proceed with the Senate's program as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In so moving I wish to make what I believe to be a number of relevant criticisms of the first annual report of the Australian Federal Police. Honourable senators may recall that an attempt was made to amalgamate the Australian Capital Territory Police with the Commonwealth Police during the period 1972-75. The government of the day was convinced of the need to merge those two units in such a way that the functions of the Commonwealth so far as police and public order were concerned could be more effectively carried out. That was a period of bloody-mindedness in the Senate and, of course, in both the House of Representatives and in the Senate that legislation did not obtain the support of the Opposition of that time. So it was not until 1979 that the Australian Federal Police was established.

The Opposition finds the first annual report unsatisfactory in that, whilst it gives some statistics about the factors relating to the amalgamation of the two forces, it glosses over to an amazing degree the problems that have developed because of the long period since the Parliament refused to take the step after it was mooted at the beginning of the 1970s. Consequently, there was in the minds of both the Australian Capital Territory Police and the Commonwealth Police at that time a feeling that something might happen and probably would happen. That created a degree of unease, confusion and concern in the minds of the officers and the members of both police forces. However, those feelings were sensibly resolved at the time the legislation received the approval of both Houses of the Parliament. The formal declaration incorporating the two groups into the Australian Federal Police took place on 19 October 1979. Of course, that was considerably more than 18 months ago.

Whilst the report tells us something of the functions and activities of the new force that has come into operation, it fails to deal with the actual position that exists in the Australian Federal Police. Very little has been done by this Government or by the responsible Minister to bring about the kind of harmony necessary, if this force is to do its work effectively, or to correct the problems involved in the merging of two separate forces. The Minister has been singularly inactive and unenergetic in attempting to assist that process. That has probably been brought about by several changes in ministerial control, but it has also been a weakening of the attempts to bring about some harmony. In fact, there has been a lot of discontent which is not referred to in the report; nor does the report make any reference to the differences that exist between the two forces.

Whilst it could be said that there would be difficulties in any amalgamation of two distinct arms of an organisation, the fact is that the Minister has done very little to try to get the two associations to which the Australian Capital Territory Police and the Australian Federal Police belong to work in any spirit of harmony and co-operation. The annual report, presented to us by the Minister and expressing the views of Sir Colin Woods, the Commissioner, seeks to suggest that there are no problems at all as a result of the amalgamation. That is not the position. Therefore, it ought to be part of the responsibility of the Minister and of the Commissioner to tell the Parliament about the problems that exist within this organisation. We have a very absurd, odd and unacceptable position in which members of the force doing the same jobs, for example, are receiving different rates of pay. We have the situation in which old uniforms of the old force are still being worn.

One could therefore be confused about the passage of the legislation and the fact that these situations still exist 18 months after the merger has taken place. Identity cards have still not been issued after this length of time. The resignation rate from both sections of the old force-now part of the singular force-is still much too high, indicating a measure of discontent within the organisation. One can read the journals of the associations. After all, we still have the two separate organisations. I think insufficient initiative has been taken to get the two organisations together. Of course, inevitably there is some conflict as a result of the fact that the two organisations still exist.

One has only to read the journals which are available-I appreciate that honourable senators have so much to read that they would not be going out of their way to read the journals of the respective organisations-to see that there is discontent within the force and that the morale in the Australian Federal Police is at a very low level. There is no recognition or mention of this in the report. As I said at the outset, it is a glossy report. It does not give to the Parliament the information it ought to have about the difficulties. One can understand the difficulties that may exist in such a merger. There are problems about promotion, personalities and tasks which might have varied as a result of the creation of the new force which has set in opposite ways traditions and job procedures which hitherto had been carried out.

One can understand all that but one would have expected that there would have been some mention of these sorts of difficulties in the report. One would have expected that somehow or other the Parliament would have been acquainted with these difficulties so that it is not just left to the Executive to make a decision, if it so desires, on the basis of information that may be available to the Minister. After all, this is the Minister's report. It has his authority and his signature on it. The Parliament is being treated with discourtesy. Therefore, it is the responsibility of the Government, the Minister and the Commissioner to bring to the attention of the Parliament some of these matters which have been brought to my attention on the basis of communications sent to me by members of the organisation who have contacted me and from reading the letters published in the journals of the organisation.

Of course, there are different views about who is responsible for this unsatisfactory state of affairs. I will certainly not suggest that the leadership of one organisation is right or that the leadership of the other organisation is wrong. But there is bickering and procrastination. There are difficulties. A decline is taking place in the standards of the Australian Federal Police and morale in the organisation, because of the way in which the hierarchy within the new organisation operates, is not satisfactory. That is not in anyway to be construed as being an attack upon the rank and file of the organisation.

After all, the responsibility rests at management level. It rests with the Commissioner, the senior officers, the Government and, particularly, the Minister. We cannot afford to have a situation in which this state of affairs continues. I do not agree with the suggestion that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) made at the start of the examination of the reports that we should put these matters off until August because I think they are still too important to be left for some debate that will take place in two or three month's time no matter how much pressure there is for the Senate to complete its business. The fact is that if we have this problem of time on our shoulders it is not the responsibility of the Opposition but rather of the Government.

Therefore, one would hope that the brief remarks I have made in respect of these matters will be looked at by the Government and by the Commissioner. I hope that the Commissioner will take the criticism in the manner in which it is given, that is to say that management has to accept some responsibility for the unsatisfactory state of affairs that exists in this new force, a state of affairs which must affect its efficiency and capacity to carry out its task. This is a period in which we have established a Federal police force to examine a whole range of new activities which need to have the attention of the Australian Federal Police. I am not talking now of the common sorts of law and order issues or of the civil issues with which citizens have to contend. I am talking about organised crime. I am talking about the deficiencies in the matter of drugs in Australia. After all the Australian Federal Police has the responsibilities now for what were previously those of the Narcotics Bureau. So little is said about that in this report.

Whilst it is not our prerogative to pry specifically into these matters, nevertheless I do not think there would be too many people in the Parliament or too many citizens in Australia who would feel satisfied with the surveillance and protection of citizens and with the problems associated with drugs and narcotics in our country. So it is not just another report. It is not just a matter of accepting the nice words included in this report. It is a matter of the Senate fulfilling its proper role of surveying the activities of the Australian Federal Police. Because nothing in the report gives the Opposition any encouragement to believe that it is in a better position to deal with the problems of drug trafficking in our country, it regards the report as being very piecemeal, very inadequate and one which gives us an opportunity at a later date to debate the matter in much more detail than we have the time to do today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the last couple of sentences said by Senator Gietzelt that that part of the report which deals with drug trafficking is, to say the least, very superficial and hardly gives anyone who is interested in doing something about the problem much comfort. The matter is contained very sketchily on pages 20 and 21. I have listened with interest to what Senator Gietzelt said. The Australian Federal Police has problems which were built into the formation of the Australian Federal Police. Since I last spoke about the Australian Federal Police I have had the opportunity of meeting the Commissioner, Sir Colin Woods, and I am pleased to be able to say that the high praise that I was able to heap on him in previous debates, which I made from repute, I now can confirm after having met the gentleman in the flesh. He is a fine person and someone who, I have great hopes, will do something constructive in the direction in which he is charged, particularly in drug trafficking.

SPEECH.PARA: Very briefly I will just refer to something I have mentioned quite often in the last 14 years since I was first Minister for Customs and Excise in 1969. First, the illicit drug problem in Australia is increasing. Secondly, it has reached massive proportions and is growing yearly. There is a cannabis industry in this country which reaps profits of about $250m a year for organised crime. Illegal heroin dealings reaps about the same-about $250m in profits-for organised crime. Added to that is the illegal gambling which takes place mainly in New South Wales with police approval, Government approval and apparently with Opposition approval. It reaps another $150m to $200m a year for organised crime. That means that profits of something like $600m to $700m a year go to organised crime in this country. It never ceases to astonish me--

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of those profits come from crime in the first place to give them money for those drugs.

—Exactly; it is all interrelated. As I was saying, it never ceases to astonish me how legislators throughout Australia, both Federal and State, can be so complacent about a situation where organised crime is earning such money. One wonders whether any of the structures of our society are safe. Is any politician, any magistrate or any judge safe when a bribe of $100,000, $200,000 or $300,000 is petty cash in this area? Once again, I make an appeal to the legislators in this Senate and in this Parliament-probably in a futile sense, but I make it notwithstanding. No matter what sorts of law enforcement practices are instituted, no matter whether Sir Colin Woods turns the Australian Federal Police into the most ruthlessly efficient law enforcement agency in the world, at no time will we be able to prevent less than 10 per cent to 20 per cent of illicit drugs entering this country. Anybody who says that we can do better than that is a fool. That is the experience of every country which is battling against the importation of illicit drugs.

SPEECH.PARA: I was favoured to travel overseas in 1972 at the request of the McMahon Government to study this question. It is impossible even to contemplate law enforcement methods preventing less than 10 per cent to 20 per cent of such drugs entering Australia. I believe the logic is inescapable. If the supply of illicit drugs on to the market cannot be prevented, surely the only approach to the problem is to try to allay demand for the drugs. One wonders whether the policies that we follow throughout our community and in this Parliament, as well as in the State parliaments, allay in any shape or form the demand for illicit drugs mainly by young Australians? The debate on cannabis has raged in this country for 14 or 15 years. I wonder whether those who enjoy their social lubricants-whisky, brandy, sherry, wine or any other form of alcohol--

TALK.START.PARA: —Plus cigarettes.

—I said social lubricant. After 14 years of disputation and public debate, has the Government any conclusive proof that the ingestion of cannabis in moderate quantities is as dangerous as the ingestion of alcohol for the body, the brain, society or in terms of the road toll? I have seen no statistics to indicate that those who promote the consumption of alcohol, who even defend the advertising of alcohol, have put anywhere near a conclusive argument about the harm that cannabis, in any of its forms, does to those who use it moderately as a social lubricant. Although this is not considered to be the policy of the Australian Democrats, I, for one, have reached the view that the arguments for the decriminalisation of cannabis have now reached almost unanswerable proportions. They ought to be considered on a non-party, non-political and non-point scoring basis because the drug trade is not bringing $250m a year to creatures who exploit our young and who exploit this law. One would only need to have read last week of the arrest of members of the international Mafia in Calabria and read of their direct associations with Australia and with the cannabis trade, to wonder whether we are not pursuing this course of stupidity ourselves. These creatures flourish, not necessarily because of the weakness of our young, but because of our hypocrisy. We are too frightened to attack something like the legalisation or the decriminalisation of cannabis because of the political implications.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, why should we also not look at the heroin problem? Does anybody here really believe that we can cure the massive heroin problem in this country by police action-by law enforcement? Time and again I have suggested to this Parliament that it should at least try a pilot scheme along the lines of the British experiment. In that experiment, people diagnosed as being addicted to the opiate heroin are allowed, on government prescription and under medical supervision, to have their habit attended to in a medical way. I am not persuaded that this is a cure-all for a social problem or even a medical problem. I know that when human beings have been addicted to heroin and even when the physiological addiction has been cured, weeks, months and years later, for no apparent reason, there is a reversion to the drug. This happens for no scientific, moral or sociological reason whatsoever. This may happen because heroin does in some way destroy the mental, spiritual or physical processes and makes a human being, once addicted, different altogether. I do not know the answer, but I do know that if an addict is under medical supervision and is being given doses of heroin in diminishing quantities, at least there is a fighting chance of containing that person's addiction. There is an excellent chance of putting the creatures, who make millions of dollars out of the addict's misery, out of business.

In many ways the British experiment has been successful. Where it has been unsuccessful is that the clinics that were constructed for the use of addicts were too far apart and too few in quantity. That meant that an addict, in some cases, had to travel for an hour and three-quarters in the morning for his morning shot and an hour and three-quarters back and then repeat that process in the afternoon. I would have thought that the way in which the program of heroin addiction was being administered, at least in philosophical terms, was unanswerable until, of course, Mrs Thatcher found a brillant way of destroying it. One has noted that Boots Chemist in Piccadilly Circus no longer attracts the midnight queues. Under the former policy, addicts could have some form of treatment in civilised circumstances. Boots now closes at 8.30 p.m. and it has large numbers of security guards to keep the addicts out. This thrusts them into the back streets to buy drugs on the black market.

I know that the suggestion I am about to make is almost anathema to politicians. I suggest that the Government legalise heroin for addicts. Just think what the do-gooders and the National Right to Life Association would say. These people would have an instant rush of blood to the head. They would attack us and say that this is politically unpopular. I ask those people whether their methods of law enforcement have made any dent at all on the problem. Are they likely to do so? Can they genuinely believe that doubling the force of the Australian Federal Police, Federal narcotics investigations or any other body will have any effect in the future? All I am saying at this stage, in speaking to the report, is that the old ways have not succeeded. Is it not time for politicians to have the guts, the courage, to be prepared to cop some flack from the narrow-minded, insular people in the community and at least to introduce a pilot scheme in these areas to see whether there is another way of preventing this kind of damage to Australian society?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly to the motion, but, before doing so, I wish to respond to the appeal which the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) made concerning the presentation of papers. What Senator Chipp had to say was important to him and to those who listened. Whereas the whole of his speech may not have been entirely relevant to the report of the Australian Federal Police, nevertheless, what he had to say was of vital interest to those in society who are concerned about the problems to which he referred. I say to the Government that, if an honourable senator wishes to speak to an item on the list of papers to be presented, his freedom to do so ought not to be limited to any extent.

SPEECH.PARA: I have seen the report. I looked through it because, since there have been several incidents in King's Hall of late, I wanted to see to what extent the Australian Federal Police were involved in the running of Parliament, just what sort of surveillance we could expect in the future and what has been the connection between the Federal Police and the security within Parliament House itself? What has been the relationship between the Federal Police and the Usher of the Black Rod and the Serjeant-at-Arms? I cannot see any mention of those matters in the report-not a solitary mention. There is a mention of the protection of VIPs. There is no mention of the work of the police within this Parliament. I believe that that is highly relevant, considering what happened today. Through you, Mr Deputy President, I say to the President that a debate needs to be held at an early stage on the role of the police within this Parliament, the role of the Usher of the Black Rod and the role of the supervisor of security in Parliament House. Where are we heading? In what way are we regulating the Parliament if it leads to such an occurrence as the ugly incident which took place in King's Hall today? What are the rights of a member of Parliament?

I moved across King's Hall today to try to separate some women and children from the melee that was taking place. In the course of doing that I was interrupted by the police. I endeavoured to speak to the people who were sitting on the floor of King's Hall. I was interrupted again by the police. One policeman told me to stand to one side and, in fact, put his hand on me to push me to one side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he know who you were?

—I do not know whether he knew, but the Serjeant-at-Arms and the Usher of the Black Rod were standing by. I told the policeman that, if he continued his action, he would be subject to privilege, but he should not have needed to be reminded of that fact. Once I started to speak to those people, it was my right to continue to speak to them without interruption and without police dragging people away by the legs while I was endeavouring to convince them that there was a far better way in which their message could be conveyed.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter has to be spoken on now. I speak on it in relation to this report because the police were in this place in great numbers. They dragged people out from this place violently. I do not know where the fault lies; nevertheless people were dragged out violently. The efforts of members of parliament-several endeavoured to intervene-were ignored by police. As I have said, a policeman endeavoured to frustrate me in my efforts. The look on that policeman's face conveyed that he thought I had no right to be there, that once he was given the order to shift people that was his order and he was going to shift them irrespective of what members of parliament wanted. Maybe that is his correct position. Perhaps once an order is given by the Presiding Officers, through the Ushers or the security organiser, a policeman must do his duty, but there is also a responsibility on a member of parliament, in the Parliament itself, that surely cannot be frustrated by a policeman. If I wanted to speak to those people on the floor, I should have been allowed to do so.

To come back to the report, I suggest that, within this report, should be a complete accounting of the role which the police play within this Parliament. I have argued previously that, in spite of the need for security in this place, there is also a need for people to move freely. I have argued against the over-presence of police. I notice that there has been some improvement. The police no longer do the work of attendants on the lower levels. The police are here to carry out what is called a double surveillance. People are scrutinised on the lower ground level and come under a second scrutiny on the ground level. I know that I may be defending the indefensible when I refer to the incident in the Parliament the other day when an egg was thrown in the Parliament itself, the first time that such an incident has occurred in many years. Surely that action does not mean that we should be walled in by glass as has now been suggested is in the mind of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I put it again to the President, directly, that there needs to be a protection of the rights of all people, including those who are demonstrating today. It was said earlier that people could not move freely in King's Hall. That is not correct. There was a great deal of noise. The noise may have intruded into the working of both Houses, but surely that would have been far more acceptable than what followed when the order was given to remove the people who were creating the noise.

The security arrangements in this place have resulted from a reaction on the part of the Prime Minister and the Presiding Officers. It has been an overreaction. We pride ourselves on allowing people certain democratic freedoms and rights. Even though some may behave inordinately those rights should not be limited as they are becoming limited in this place. If there is a risk of some physical damage to us, let us take the risk. It has been argued that the risk is not only to ourselves but also to other people. Of course, that is a risk that we take in society today and, with increasing violence, it is an increasing risk but we should not succumb because of that to imposing added security and giving added authority and added power to the police. That would end up in such an incident as took place in King's Hall today-violence by one individual against another and an intrusion upon the rights of parliamentarians.

There is a fine balance here and the balance should be in favour of less surveillance and greater freedom. If some people abuse that freedom, we must accept that and not overreact to it. I feel strongly about this matter. I have raised it before. I feel very strongly about the Federal Police being invited into this Parliament today to do violence to individuals. I do not know where the position of the Usher rests. The Usher should have protected my rights. To a certain extent he did plead with me but he should have protected my rights to speak to those people who were in King's Hall. Was the Usher of the Black Rod exceeded, overruled or supervised in his authority? I would have thought that the Usher of the Black Rod, on behalf of the Senate, should protect the rights of parliamentarians and protect the rights of constituents through their parliamentarians.

Is it that the supervisor of security is senior to the Usher of the Black Rod regarding the organisation of this place? Is it the supervisor of security who says to the President that we shall do this or that and who advises him on these matters? Is he, not the Usher, the person responsible? So many questions are raised in one's mind because of the unedifying and disgraceful-it has been otherwise described in this place-spectacle in King's Hall. Many questions arise and many need to be answered. One thing I hope is that no matter what the provocation this situation will not arise again.

I remember when a group of Aborigines refused to move from the steps of King's Hall. They were obstructing entry into Parliament House because there was no entrance underneath. People had to move around them to get into Parliament House. That was an obstruction. Deliberations took place for an hour. Finally, the police turned around and looked the other way and the Aborigines got up and walked away. That demonstrated good sense. It took a long time and a considerable amount of discussion. The President was personally involved. Finally the matter was peacefully resolved. I should have thought that the incident in King's Hall today would have been peacefully resolved, not violently accomplished. I think it is a sad day for us all.
