I wish to make a few brief remarks. They will be brief, both because of the time constraint and also because, as usual, the report has been in the Opposition's hands insufficiently long enough to enable any very considered or reasoned response to be made. The report is about the jurisdiction of the Ombudsman. It is clear that that is a very important question because there are some very large exclusions from the jurisdiction which can presently be exercised by the Ombudsman. In the second report of the Ombudsman it was noted that some 11.4 per cent of the complaints received that year by him-that is, 443 out of a total of 2,680-were outside his jurisdiction. By the time the most recent Ombudsman's report was made-the third report-that figure had escalated to a much larger percentage, with 2,457 complaints being outside the Ombudsman's jurisdiction and only another 4,458 complaints actually being able to be investigated. So it was clear, and it is fast becoming increasingly clear, that it was necessary for this question of complaints felt to be legitimate to be able to be investigated.

What this report appears to do is to make a number of quite significant recommendations for an extension of the Ombudsman's jurisdiction, especially in relation to statutory authorities in competition with private enterprise and especially in relation to Commonwealth controlled companies and also in relation to a number of intergovernmental Commonwealth-State authorities and activities. I note that the report does not appear to be a complete analysis of possible extensions of the Ombudsman's jurisdiction to the extent, for example, that nothing is said about the Ombudsman's jurisdiction extending into the area of freedom of information matters. This, of course, was recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in its report on freedom of information wherein the recommendation was that the Ombudsman here have not simply an expanded, conciliatory and investigative role including matters in relation to ministerial decisions, but also an advisory role, a critical role and something of a monitoring role in relation to the operation of that legislation and, furthermore, a relatively unique role as a general counsel before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in relation to freedom of information matters. I simply note the omission of any discussion of this matter from this report and query whether there has been an independent review by the Administrative Review Council as to whether that body feels that this jurisdiction ought to be granted and, if so, query the absence of that report being tabled in the Parliament in time for it to form part of the materials before us when we finally get back to, as I hope we will this week, the Freedom of Information Bill.

The only other matter I wish to raise with respect to the Ombudsman's report is that although this particular document tabled today deals only with the jurisdiction of the Ombudsman, it is in fact known that the Administrative Review Council has dealt with a number of other aspects of real significance relating to the powers and functions of the Ombudsman. Those other matters on which the ARC has reported have not yet been the subject of tabling in this Parliament. It is no secret that such additional work was done by the ARC because it has been referred to in some detail in the 1978-79 annual report of that body.

There are just two matters of this additional kind that I think need specific attention and, if possible, some Government response as to why nothing has been tabled in the Parliament in relation to them. First of all, there is the question whether or not the Ombudsman should have power to apply to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for an advisory opinion, there having been experienced a number of difficulties in that respect and there being a strong case-certainly I gather in the Ombudsman's view-for a clarification and an extension of his power in that respect, not least following debacles of recent years in the Ombudsman's dealing with the Department of Social Security and Mr Lanigan in particular.

The other matter which has been raised in the past by the Ombudsman in his annual reports and which I understand has been the subject of ARC recommendation but which is not part of this document tabled here today, is the question of the power of the Ombudsman to apply to the Federal Court to get a determination as to the limits of his jurisdiction-again, a matter which achieved some notoriety and prominence in the context of the Department of Social Security and the resistance of that Department to claims by the Ombudsman to have such a jurisdiction. This is a matter which does seem to have caused practical difficulties for the Ombudsman. It is an area in which it would, apparently, be helpful were the legislation to be clarified.

Finally, I make the point that we are grateful to have this paper tabled at last, even in what appears to be its present incomplete form. A long time has elapsed since the Administrative Review Council made its recommendations on these matters to the Government. Indeed, I believe that the date on which this material was made available to the Government was August 1979, which is, of course, nearly two years ago. The most pressing need now would appear to be for a government response to the advice it has thus received from the ARC, a response which, I hope, in all cases will be affirmative. Mr President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reports on Commonwealth Employees' Compensation Tribunal and on Social Security Appeals

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

Item 19 is, in fact, two reports of the Administrative Review Council, one on the Commonwealth Employees Compensation Tribunal and another on the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, together with voluminous appendices to the second report. It is, I believe, worth while pointing out that the Commonwealth Employees Compensation Tribunal report was presented to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) on 1 May and on 30 April the Lynch committee, the razor gang, incorporated changes in the administration of Commonwealth employees in line with these recommendations by the Administrative Review Council. So, it seems that there were obviously consultations going on at the time and, one suspects, probably last minute additions to the razor gang's decision on this matter. We believe it makes sense to transfer the jurisdiction of the Tribunal for Commonwealth Employees Compensation to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which is now well established, has considerable authority and, in fact, is developing a very good reputation. The recommendations we particularly approve of include recommendation 1 which states:

There should be a legislative provision requiring Commissioner for Employees' Compensation to determine a matter as soon as practicable, but in any case, within 60 days of lodgment of a claim with the Commissioner.
I do not believe that the justification for such a recommendation needs arguing here. Similarly, we approve of recommendation 2, which states:
The jurisdiction currently exercised by the Commonwealth Employees' Compensation Tribunal should be conferred on the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Opposition believes there needs to be safeguards even in these circumstances for the rights of appellants such as Mrs Beattie, whom Senator Chaney knows, having intervened in her case. There is a need to ensure that appellants are protected in that they should not be penalised for being test cases against decisions in appeals by the Commonwealth which can use the powers and facilities available to it in such situations. We believe it is a good move that the razor gang, for instance, decided to pull together the administration of Commonwealth employees compensation, something which the Opposition, including me, has been advocating for some years. But all that is no good if the appellants to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal have to pay their own costs. We have been trying to get a definite answer from the Government for some time on this. We hope that in cases which are test cases there will be a standard procedure in future to ensure that people are not penalised or even prevented from taking out appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or any other body because of the costs involved and, particularly, in view of the inequality which will always exist when an individual is appealing against the Government.

The report on social security appeals seems to have been a long time in coming to this Parliament. The appendices attached to the report, which are too voluminous for the Opposition to comment on in the time it has had them, represent investigations which were made in 1978, the findings of which are thus three years old. We have been making requests for a long time that this report come forward and I can see no good reason for such a delay. The Administrative Review Council which has in previous reports stated its dissatisfaction with the appeals system and the protection of the rights of social security appellants and clients, proposes a comprehensive system of external review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of decisions in the social security area. The jurisdiction went to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in April last year and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle announced these changes in September. So it appears again that this report has been held up and we would really like to know when the report was received by the Government and by the Minister and why it has been held up for so long.

The recommendations are comprehensive and, in our view, are well thought out. They include the power to make an order for an interim payment to an appellant who had been receiving unemployment or sickness benefit. They include reasons to be given to the claimant, either orally or in writing, for decisions taken by the Tribunal. Many recommendations pertain to the administration within the Department of Social Security such as: Pre-grant interviews where possible to get as many facts and figures and inform the claimant as to rights and responsibilities; interviewees' statements in departmental interviews should represent both the words and the context in which they were made; claimants should have an opportunity to rebut other material on which the Department might be making a decision; manuals should be freely available to the public and relevant parts given to the interested persons, a matter which has been a bone of contention in the social welfare area for many years; written notification to be given to the claimant as to the reasons for adverse decisions, the same responsibility to apply to the Commonwealth Employment Service as long as the CES has responsibility for the work test. The Commission also recommends legal aid for cases going to the presidential bench of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and that the Tribunal be empowered to award payment of expenses to applicants attending hearings.

We particularly commend the recommendations for the provision of advice and assistance to claimants in the social security appeals process which appear in chapter 7. This program has been recommended by the Council of Social Service and is very close to a recommendation I have been making over the last couple of years for welfare advocates to do this sort of job. Paragraph 7.002 states:

It was suggested to the Council that there was no special need to provide advice and assistance to claimants because many will be able to manage on their own account and because the DSS officers and voluntary welfare groups will be able to provide some help.

If, as I suspect, it was the Department of Social Security that made that suggestion at the time, it demonstrates again that the major welfare department in this country still remains in ignorance of the abilities and the circumstances of its poorest and least literate claimants, particularly in the situation in which they are appealing against bureaucratic decisions. It is ludicrous to state as an analogy, as this unnamed arguer did, that there is no provision for special advice and assistance before taxation boards of review. Social security clients, we suggest and the Council suggests, are in an entirely different position from the usual people going before taxation boards of review. Fortunately, the Council stated:

. . . the Council considers that advice and assistance are of such importance in social security cases that their provision should not be left to the chance that DSS officers and welfare groups will be available to assist in given cases.
It further states:

The difficulty many claimants will have in understanding and taking advantage of a review process is likely to be accentuated for groups facing special problems, particularly Aboriginals and migrants.

It demonstrates that the Administrative Review Council has a much clearer idea of the difficulties and disabilities facing the sorts of people who will receive social security payments in this country, the sorts of people who will receive any of the benefits and who may in fact depend on these benefits for the meagre standard of living they have. It is with some disturbance that one notes the argument that they do not need this because there is an analogous situation with those before taxation boards of review, which was put forward by the Department of Social Security. I shall quote some words of the Council in chapter 8 which I believe we should all take very seriously. The report states:

In the Council's opinion, the present review system, even as modified recently by vesting a limited jurisdiction in the AAT (which, in itself, is a useful step forward), does not meet the foregoing requirements-
The report refers back to the necessary requirements-
and falls short of the standards accepted as appropriate in other areas of jurisdiction.
This is one of the problems. The normal standards accepted as appropriate in other areas of appeals somehow have been neglected in the area of social security. The report goes on to state:

The defects of the present system, in both principle and procedure, have been set out at a number of points in this Report. The proposal put forward by the Council should overcome those defects. It is a structure which is designed fairly to balance the rights of the individuals with the needs of sound administration and to be comprehensive. Each part of the proposal interlocks with the others in making a whole. If only parts of the whole were to be implemented, there would be a danger that the balance carefully struck might be lost. The Council expresses the hope that its Report will receive early consideration by the Government.

Obviously, some of the Council's suggestions have been taken up by the Government, but we take up the Council's suggestion that unless one looks at this in an integrated way, unless, as it says, each part of the proposal interlocks with the others in making a whole, we will end up only with the inequities and the difficulties which arise in the present system. People reliant on social security benefits and on the Government for their welfare should be protected against arbitrary and unfair decisions by the bureaucracy. There are many other ways to improve the system. There are many other ways to ensure that experienced and knowledgeable people are the ones who deal with social security clients. But while we are developing that, we must have a fair and efficient system of appeals-one that cannot be ridden over by any director-general, by any Minister or by any bureaucrat at any level. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In moving that the Senate take note of the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation annual report, I place on record that this development was an initiative of the Whitlam Labor Government. Newspaper reports speak very highly of this development and point out the great benefits accruing to the area as a result of the foresight of the Labor Government. At the same time as this project was initiated, so also was the Monarto Development Commission in South Australia which, unfortunately, is now in moth balls and may even be sold by the present State Liberal Government which at present is looking at every possible means to raise revenue in an endeavour to get itself out of the very severe financial troubles it is in. It is a real tragedy that the Monarto Development Commission had to be shelved.

I am very pleased that the Albury-Wodonga development project is going ahead in leaps and bounds and is conclusive proof that things initiated by the Labor Government in office from 1972-75 were very worth while. It is fortunate in many respects that we have a Labor State government in New South Wales. If it had been a Liberal government, this project might have got the axe as well and might have been treated as a white elephant as the Monarto Development Commission has been treated. No doubt the razor gang had a look at it and tried to do something about it. Nothing has been reported yet. I hope it will not be. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Education and the Workforce

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Davidson Sen G.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, I present a report on the Committee's reference on education and the workforce, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Davidson Sen G.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

My tabling statement, which I will later seek leave to incorporate in Hansard, not only reflects some of the recommendations in the report but also seeks to draw the attention of the community to some of the problems facing education today. The Senate will recall that our reference paid particular attention to literacy and numeracy. In this regard I invite the Senate to study our observations concerning much misunderstanding and disagreement in this area. We have called for dialogue between the areas of education, employers and the community. With the changes in demands which society is imposing, we have drawn attention in our report to changes in required skills and, therefore, changes in training and education. In the future there will be a broadening of the approach to education. Future curricula will become more diffuse and less recognisable as traditional subjects. This broadness of approach reflects the need for modern students to have a broad, comprehensive education which is adaptive and innovative as opposed to being stereotyped and segmented.

The report also gives attention to problems faced by the underachievers and early school leavers and their subsequent difficulty in entering the work force. This relates to their survival in society and particularly to the additional problems of unemployment. There are a number of recommendations in the report. My tabling statement extends some of these and makes general observations on this area of education. I commend the report to the Senate. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the tabling statement.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

This report contains recommendations affecting some 16 major areas of educational concern. These areas range from the concern and responsibility of State and Federal governments, to individual schools, to individual teachers and, more importantly, to individual parents. These recommendations are not designed for the exclusive attention of education departments or governments; rather, they are a plea, indeed a challenge, to each and every one of us to accept the responsibility to improve the educational lot of our forthcoming generations.

For the continued well-being of a society it is incumbent on that society to monitor continually the standards and quality of the education it provides. Given the modern exponential growth in human knowledge and complexity of life, it is important and necessary for society not only to improve continually the existing success of its education system but also to provide for its future progress. This is necessary in order that the demands of modern society and the abilities of the younger generation are evenly matched. Thus society must consider not only the present but also the future.

In putting before the Senate these recommendations the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts believes that these recommendations are necessary if indeed the present and future effectiveness of Australian schools is to be improved, and the tragic loss to society of early school leavers is to be redressed. As the Senate may well appreciate, too often systems such as the education system may grow at variance with their basic aims or objectives. In point of fact the practice of education can diverge significantly from the theory of education; it is therefore important for an inquiry such as this to realign theory and practice.

The work of the Committee on this inquiry began in May 1979 when the Senate referred the terms of reference to the Committee. In the subsequent time that has elapsed the Committee has taken over 3,000 pages of Hansard evidence as well as taking evidence from 143 witnesses representing some 58 organisations. Senators will recall that during this time the work of the Committee was interrupted by the reference to the Committee of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill 1980, insofar as that Bill related to the Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation. This inquiry took the Committee the three months of the 1980 winter parliamentary recess to complete. Again the work of the Committee was interrupted, this time by the 1980 general elections.

Hence this inquiry has been delayed not only by the dimension of the task but also by other important independent events. This report is thus the result of this extensive inquiry. The overall message contained in this report is that conclusions we have drawn from the evidence presented to this inquiry have once again confirmed many independent research findings which have been presented to both Parliament and to education authorities over the last few years. From evidence presented in the course of this inquiry, the Committee could conclude only that many problems largely in existence over five years ago still remain essentially unresolved today. It would appear that the education system has been unable to respond. The Committee would thus argue that, given the wide public importance and interest in education, there is a greater need for firmer and more positive leadership and action from both governments and education departments.

On closer examination, honourable senators will note that there are five central areas of discussion and concern in the contents of the report. The first and most general is the wide community disagreement, or at least, misunderstanding, over the purpose and philosophy of education. Whilst the most obvious disagreement over the purpose and philosophy of education occurred between educationalists and employers, this disagreement was usually expressed in terms of a comparison of the success or failure of students in the areas of literacy or numeracy and over differing generations.

The Committee's concern, however, was not an academic question of comparison between today's and yesterday's standards, but whether present levels of literacy and numeracy could be improved overall, by improving the education system as a whole. The Committee was anxious that this evident disagreement be rectified as quickly and completely as possible. To this end, the first recommendation is aimed at stimulating a wider public debate. The second area of focus of the Committee was the plight of early school leavers. It is now well accepted that 20 to 25 per cent of students leave school without sufficient basic rudimentary skills in literacy and numeracy. Consequently, these young adults are educationally handicapped-many for their whole lifetime.

Literacy and numeracy are essential elements to any person's education. During the inquiry it became evident to the Committee that the foundations of these elements greatly involve the students' home background. The home and school in many ways complement and supplement each other. Failure of any one to reinforce the other leads to weaknesses in the achievement of this educational core, and in particular the achievement of literacy. Whilst much control can be exerted over the quality and type of education provided, little control can be effected over the students' home environment without the active support of the parents involved. Given such limitations of action, the Committee could only recommend that headmasters give greater priority to establishing a closer involvement with the students, and particularly the parents of under-achieving students.

Other recommendations which have a bearing on the overall improvement of literacy and numeracy levels are the heightened need for better trained teachers and the effective implementation of remedial programs, especially in the first two years of primary education. Furthermore, given that once teachers are appointed permanently to positions within schools there must naturally arise from time to time situations for which they have not been trained. Therefore, to ensure that teachers remain up-to-date with their teaching knowledge and methods in-service courses are essential. To this end the Committee has recommended the wider and greater use of such courses.

The next two areas to which I draw the Senate's attention relate directly to the teaching profession and methods by which its effectiveness can be improved. The secret of any good education system must essentially come back to the teaching effectiveness of its teachers. By strengthening the effectiveness of the classroom teacher, we are not necessarily guaranteeing learning success by the pupil, but at least we are placing the odds in its favour. The success of the system therefore depends on the interface between teacher and student. Thus, it is axiomatic that teachers should be properly trained and that the teaching environment within the school should be, as far as possible, positively orientated towards effective teaching. Therefore, the selection and training of teachers is vital. As well, an adequately trained teacher must be assisted in the execution of his profession by manageable class sizes, an effective and efficient school structure and, above all, be aided and guided by the experience and expertise of older teachers. The Senate will note that the Committee has made detailed recommendations in relation to these areas and includes recommendations specifically on school size and design, class size, teacher training and selection, and the effectiveness of the practising teacher as well as the leadership role of school principals and senior staff.

The last major area of concern to the Committee was the structure of the secondary school and the nature of the curricula in general. The Senate will note that the Committee has advanced recommendations relating to the restructuring of the secondary school system and to the introduction of a nationally recognised core curriculum, particularly in relation to the elements of literacy and numeracy. These recommendations place emphasis on those factors necessary to take the education system into the eighties and beyond. They are designed to place schools in a modern perspective and to reflect present and future trends of our society.

I consider it important to delineate between the compulsory and non-compulsory years of education. The youth of our nation are bound by law to attend school up until they reach an age of 15 or 16 years. It is within this time that society largely dictates the learning program these students will undertake. The culture, language and general societal characteristics are imparted within these years. At the finish of this period society says that this amount of education is sufficient for that person to function properly within the wider community. A person's educational coming of age is recognised at this point. It can be argued that within these years the emphasis on a competency in literacy and numeracy is the central characteristic of this education and that there is relatively little freedom for students to embark upon education programs of their own choosing.

Apart from an increase in the provision of vocational orientated programs for early school leavers, it would appear that this situation will persist for quite some time. To provide the foundation of education will still be largely the responsibility on these first 10 years of education, while education for careers or professions will be centred upon the education of the latter years of high school and beyond. It therefore stands to reason that any future modernisation within these years will mainly concern itself with improving the delivery and effectiveness of the material taught but not essentially the substance of what is taught.

Conversely, the non-compulsory years of education, for instance, the latter years of high school and tertiary education, are at the discretion of the student. As well, students within these years are not primarily absorbing the culture or basic educational tools necessary for survival in the wider community. Instead they are studying at their own discretion in order that they may fulfil their own ambition. As such the curriculum and style of education within these years are totally different. As can readily be appreciated the curriculum of these years is much more sensitive to outside influences such as student fashion, technological change, unemployment and the economic realities of modern life. Thus within these years, high schools and other educational institutions must in this respect be more sensitive, more adaptive, more innovative and more forward looking than their earlier counterparts.

In mentioning curricula provided by these higher years of education, we naturally bring to mind the concept of material divided up into traditional subject areas. Yet this traditional classification may no longer be appropriate for today. As the Curriculum Development Centre has stated in its booklet Core Curriculum for Australian Schools-'Our traditional way of packaging knowledge into required subjects no longer satisfies either society or students'. In supporting this belief, the Committee believes that the future curriculum will become more diffuse and less recognisable as traditional subjects. Instead of strictly isolated subjects such as English and mathematics, we believe that modern schooling will gradually evolve to broader areas. For example, if the proposal put forward by the CDC is followed, English and mathematics would become communication, and mathematical skills and reasoning. This broadness of approach is thus reflecting the need for modern students to have a broad comprehensive education which is adaptive and innovative as opposed to being stereotyped and segmented. To accommodate these changes, institutions themselves will have to undergo change and reorganisation. In the future we can expect senior high schools to become institutions for responsible adult education as opposed to schools designed to pass or fail students or to grade them for tertiary studies.

In short, while I expect the early school years to undergo changes and improvement to the art of teaching, the latter high school years will undergo significant changes mainly to curriculum content and teaching structure. Senior high schools will increasingly offer a broader choice of courses to students. This does not mean less rigorous courses but simply a greater variety offered in a more adult climate and under adult style responsibilities. I commend the report to the Senate. It is a response to an area of concern which has both social and educational implications. As I observed when opening the inquiry:

'Education should be united with life to find its mission in co-operation with work and therefore it should become the basis of social reality. This leads to the importance of lifelong education and its process within a human being who learns to express himself-to communicate and to question the world through his experiences and, above all, as a result of his earlier training. Man is an unfinished being and can fulfil himself only through constant and efficient learning'.

The Committee therefore hopes that its deliberations will alert the community to the need for constant and efficient learning. The Committee places on record its sincere appreciation of the work of the secretariat. Attention to the detail of the many requirements of investigating a reference such as this have been faithfully and effectively carried out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the motion because the report is on a subject in which I have taken special interest. The scope of the terms of reference of the report is enormous, but the Committee did not seek to re-invent the wheel or to repeat the many educational inquiries of recent years; rather it sought to give a focus related to actual reform in the education system in Australia. The report is to the point and quite brief. It has 36 pages and its 16 recommendations are quite explicit and affect every area of secondary education and indeed some other areas as well.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make two further points in my brief remarks. The first recommendation of the Committee directly encourages public discussion about areas of disagreement and misunderstanding that are still too prevalent in the community. In commending that recommendation, I suggest that parents' groups, employer groups and school staff rooms, indeed students, could very well extract the 8 pages of the relevant chapter and circulate it very widely in Australia for direct discussion.

The second matter I refer to is that the two other substantial chapters of the report relating to the teaching profession and schools in new perspectives are directly to be taken up by the States in their education departments as well as by the Commonwealth and independent schools. I think it is not necessary for a Senate committee to make apologies for the fact that the findings of this report relate not only to the Commonwealth Government in actions that would flow from the report. There is very much a call for actions and a response by State education systems and by independent schools. Whether this action is taken through the Australian Education Council or in other ways, I know that the Senate in looking to the outcome of this report will be looking for action across the whole field of education in Australia. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Constitutional Qualifications of Members of Parliament

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, I present the Committee's report on the Constitutional Qualifications of Members of Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, in tabling this report entitled 'The Constitutional Qualifications of Members of Parliament' presents to the Senate the results of a thorough examination of the constitutional provisions relating to the qualification and disqualification of members of the Parliament. This inquiry arose out of a private member's Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Holders of Office of Profit) Bill 1978, introduced into the Senate by Senator Colston on 15 November 1978. By resolution of the Senate on 7 March 1979, the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committeee was given the task of inquiring into the following matters:
(a) the desirability to amending section 44 (iv) of the Constitution in the terms proposed by the Constitution Alteration (Holders of Office of Profit) Bill 1978 or otherwise; and
(b) the desirability of changes to other provisions of the Constitution relating to the qualification and disqualification of Members of Parliament.
On 28 February 1980, Senator Mason, by way of a motion in the Senate, sought a re-examination by the Government of:

the requirement, contained in Public Service General Order 3/D/4, that an officer or employee of the Public Service who wishes to nominate for election to a House of Parliament must resign 'before nomination' on the ground that the wording and effect of the provision may be contrary to the provision of section 44 (iv) of the Constitution, which provides that any such person, holding an office of profit under the Crown, shall be incapable of being 'chosen or of sitting' as a Senator or member of the House of Representatives, in relation to which a conditional resignation, contingent upon being chosen, might be regarded as sufficient.

On the same day Senator Mason's motion was amended so that, instead of a request being made to the Government for re-examination of General Order 3/D/4, the question was referred to this Committee to be considered in conjunction with the reference on the qualifications of members of parliament.
Senator Colston's Bill

Senator Colston's private member's Bill was prompted by his concern for the disadvantaged position of public servants and other public office holders, both Commonwealth and State, who wish to seek election to the Commonwealth Parliament. To comply with section 44 (iv) of the Constitution, and in line with the prevailing interpretation of the word 'chose' in section 44, all persons who hold an office of profit under the Crown must resign before contesting a Commonwealth election. However, except in New South Wales, the re-appointment of all such office holders is a discretionary one vested in either the Public Service Board or, in four of the States, in the State Cabinet itself. The effect of such a situation is to disadvantage severely public office holders who, in order to seek election, must place their livelihood in jeopardy.

Whilst Senator Colston's Bill was the catalyst leading to this inquiry, the clear need for widespread changes to the constitutional provisions dealing with members' qualifications and disqualification, along with an anomaly in the amendment proposed by Senator Colston's Bill, have led us to recommend that the Bill should not proceed. We recommend, however, a comprehensive constitutional amendment to replace existing section 44 (iv). In considering this question the Committee has been guided by the following two clear principles: Firstly, any person who holds a State or Commonwealth public service position or holds a position with a Commonwealth or State authority should be ineligible to sit in Parliament; and secondly, there ought not to be any additional disabilities on State or Commonwealth public servants or office holders seeking election to the Commonwealth Parliament than those laid down in the Constitution. In consequence, we recommend a new section 44 which provides that State and Commonwealth office holders, as well as several other categories of persons, shall be deemed to have vacated their office at the time they become entitled to a parliamentary allowance. The effect of this, in the case of public servants, is to enable them to retain their employment until they are sure of their election to the Parliament. This will remove the present disability under which they suffer fear of loss of livelihood if they are unsuccessful in their quest for election to the Commonwealth Parliament. We also recommend a new section 45 which provides that, if a senator or a member of the House of Representatives accepts a position as a State or Commonwealth public servant or, without the approval of the Parliament, accepts a place with a State or Commonwealth public authority, he shall thereupon vacate his place. In the same chapter, we also discuss the ambiguous position of senators-elect, as well as the several categories of persons who are excluded from the operation of section 44 (iv) by the proviso to that section.
The Grounds of Qualification and Disqualification

Although the problems posed by section 44 (iv) commanded the greater part of the Committee's time and attention, the other constitutional qualifications and disqualifications in sections 34, 44 and 45 are also considered in detail in the report. The report initially deals with the matter of the qualifications of members of parliament and then proceeds to a consideration of the grounds of disqualification, each of which is the subject of a separate chapter of the report. I will briefly comment on each of these matters.

The second chapter considers the qualifications of members of parliament contained in section 34 of the Constitution which have been subsequently superseded by section 69 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. These qualifications relate to age, residency, British subject status and entitlement to vote. We recommend that the last three qualifications referred to be deleted from the Commonwealth Electoral Act, and that age, and the new qualification of 'Australian citizenship' should constitute the only affirmative qualifications for membership of the Parliament. Chapter 2 also discusses section 44 (i), which disqualifies any person who has an allegiance to a foreign power, or is a citizen or entitled to the rights or privileges of a citizen of a foreign power. The Committee was concerned that this provision appears to place an absolute bar against persons with unsought dual nationality from nominating for, or sitting in, the Commonwealth Parliament. We recommend the deletion of the constitutional bar, but suggest some necessary safeguards to ensure that candidates and members of parliament have an allegiance to Australia.

Chapter 3 of the report deals with section 44 (ii) of the Constitution which disqualifies on the grounds of treason or because a person is under sentence or subject to be sentenced for a criminal offence where the offence is punishable by imprisonment for one year or longer. We recommend that the disqualification for criminal offences be deleted from the Constitution on several grounds, notably the considerable inconsistency in the setting of penalties for similar offences in the several Australian jurisdictions and because of its general inappropriateness as a yardstick for parliamentary disqualification. We do recommend, however, the retention of the disqualification for treason in an amended form.

Chapter 4 considers section 44 (iii) of the Constitution, which disqualifies candidates and members of parliament who become bankrupt or insolvent, and section 45 (ii), which vacates the seat of a member who takes the benefit of any law relating to bankrupt or insolvent debtors. Our consideration of these provisions made us particularly aware of their ambiguity and hence of the uncertain scope of their operation. Whilst these ambiguities could undoubtedly be rectified by appropriate amendments, we concluded that both provisions no longer serve any useful purpose. Because of changing social and economic conditions, including the community attitude towards bankrupt and insolvent persons, we consider that these provisions no longer indicate the suitability or otherwise of a candidate or a member of parliament, and we accordingly recommend their deletion from the Constitution.

The next two chapters consider the disqualification in section 44 (iv), that of holding an office of profit under the Crown, and the exceptions to this disqualification in the proviso to section 44 (iv). I have already referred to the issues raised in chapter 5 in my comments on Senator Colston's Bill. Another issue arises in the context of the proviso which excludes Ministers of the Crown from the disqualifying provision of section 44 (iv). However, the matter of Assistant Ministers has always been a vexed one. Chapter 6 addresses itself to the issue of Assistant Ministers and Parliamentary Secretaries in the context of section 44 (iv) and other relevant constitutional provisions, principally section 64. Our report discusses, in their historical context, the difficulties which have been experienced throughout the existence of the Commonwealth in appointing and, more especially, adequately remunerating Assistant Ministers. Although we comment on several options which exist within the constitutional framework, we point out that our recommendations in chapter 5, which abolish the uncertain expression 'office of profit under the Crown', will, if accepted, remove the constitutional barrier to appointing Assistant Ministers or Parliamentary Secretaries.

The report then considers the pecuniary interest disqualification in section 44 (v), and the complementary provision in section 45 (iii), which is directed at professional services rendered to the Commonwealth or other services rendered in the Parliament for a fee. We discuss the meaning and likely interpretation of these provisions and comment on their uncertain but potentially wide area of application. The Committee concluded that the whole question of members' pecuniary interests is best dealt with by legislation rather than entrenched constitutional provisions and we recommend that the present provisions be replaced by a head of power enabling Parliament to legislate on the whole question of pecuniary interests and improper influence.

The final chapter examines the various procedural questions which arise as a consequence of a breach of sections 44 and 45 and notes the different effects of a breach as between the two sections. The mechanisms by which an alleged breach may be challenged, namely, sections 46 and 47 of the Constitution, are discussed, as is legislation enacted pursuant to those provisions. Some difficulties and anomalies relating to the various provisions are alluded to, and we make a recommendation in relation to the common informer provisions and section 203 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.
Conclusions

From the brief comments that I have made on each of these constitutional provisions, it can be seen that the Committee has made a series of recommendations which, if implemented, will have the effect of removing almost all of the existing provisions relating to the qualification and disqualification of members and senators. Those few provisions whose purpose requires retention within the constitutional framework are, according to our recommendations, to be replaced by clearer and more explicit language. In deciding to recommend a substantial simplification of the constitutional provisions relating to qualification and disqualification, our motivation has been to achieve a less rigid arrangement so that the question of suitability for parliamentary office can be determined in accordance with changing social conditions. In many cases, we seek to achieve this simply be leaving the matter of a particular person's suitability to the judgment of the electorate. In others, our recommendations seek to deal with some aspects of the matter of suitability by means of legislation, which can, if necessary, be amended to meet changing social conditions and perceptions. Implementation of these recommendations will require substantial alteration of the Constitution which, of course, can only be achieved by means of a referendum. Our inquiry has revealed obscurities, ambiguities, inequities and anachronisms within this area of the Constitution. It is, therefore, desirable that they be put before the people in a referendum to enable the necessary tidying up to take place. I hardly need emphasise the relevance of this report to all honourable senators and to members in another place. Accordingly, I commend the report and especially its recommendations to the study of all members of the Commonwealth Parliament.

Finally, in regard to this investigation and report, which has taken more than 18 months to complete, I pay tribute to the staff of the Committee-Mr Chris Fogarty, its Secretary, and Mr Tim Dodson, its research officer-for very meticulous work done over an extended period in a very difficult area of study. I also thank my colleagues. This is the last report that this particular Committee, this particular band, will present to the Senate as changes will occur. All of my colleagues have contributed well to the work of the Committee. I wish to refer particularly to the work of Senator Evans on this reference, in regard to which his special qualifications and interest have been of great value. Two members of the Committee will shortly be retiring from the Parliament and I will not have an opportunity of saying anything about them hereafter. I am thankful that the Honourable John Wheeldon has been a member of the Committee for a period. I mention especially Senator Chris Puplick, who has been a member for the last three years and who has played a tremendous part in the work on the various references that the Committee has had before it. I have in mind study of the freedom of information legislation and the reference that the Senate is now considering in particular. I believe that Senator Puplick has had the most outstanding record of any first-up senator. I hope that he will soon be back in the Senate to join the Committee and its work. I wish to pay an enormous tribute to him for the work that he has done as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Consitutional and Legal Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report, in common with all of its predecessors from the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs with which I have been associated, comes forward as a set of recommendations agreed upon unanimously. That that is so is at least partly attributable to the chairmanship skills of Senator Missen, whose own contributions to the work of the Committee deserve considerable praise. I endorse the remainder of his remarks concerning the other members of the Committee except, given the constraints of modesty, those that he directed at me, and his reference to the contribution made by the staff. It ought to be said that the completion of this report turned out to be a much longer and more complex exercise than any of us had first envisaged when we took it on. The issues involved are extremely technical, difficult and intricate. At the same time they raise very large questions of principle of general public interest, not to mention, of course, of interest to members and senators of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The origins of the exercise lay in a number of different directions. In the first place, there was that feeling of unfairness which has now become quite widespread and which Senator Colston first articulated as to the way in which the consitutional provisions were being construed and applied with regard to both Commonwealth and State public servants but in particular with regard to those State public servants in respect of whom there was no tradition or law requiring them to be reinstated once they had resigned to contest an election. The second concern was our strong feeling that a number of constitutional provisions governing membership qualifications were out of date, anomalous or likely to cause difficulties out of all proportion to the intrinsic importance of the principles they affirmed. One obvious candidate for those descriptions is the involuntary dual nationality situation to which Senator Missen explicity referred.

The third consideration underlying our report was our feeling that the High Court in the Webster case had not entirely distinguished itself, that the law in relation to pecuniary interests was in a very unsatisfactory state and that the community's judgment in respect of how to change it had not been sufficiently aided by the recommendations of the Bowen committee on pecuniary interests, which committee had left the constitutional questions largely untouched. The final basic concern was the continuing concern that has been expressed by a large number of people from the point of view of public administration; that is, the controversy, stretching back now for a number of decades, concerning the constitutional prohibition, if such indeed it is, on the appointment of assistant Ministers or parliamentary undersecretaries with some additional remuneration other than merely that by way of recoupment of expenses. That concern simply repeats that which has been expressed by a large number of commentators for a number of years-that to the extent that the Constitution did impose significant prohibitions, it represented an undue limitation on the flexibility of operation of the Executive Government and needed to be looked at.

In the event, the Committee has produced a report which makes a number of far-reaching proposals for both constitutional and statutory change. Those proposals essentially speak for themselves, although Senator Missen has very ably summarised their individual import. In conclusion, let me say, firstly, that I hope that individual members and senators will look at this report rather more carefully than they might normally be accustomed to doing with reports emerging from various standing committees in this Parliament because the matters raised in it are of intimate personal concern. The second point I make is that I trust that the Government will respond rather more promptly, not to mention favourably, than it has tended to do hitherto in relation to reports emanating from our Committee. Finally, I make the point that this report, if it is adopted, will require constitutional amendments in a number of respects to implement its recommendations. That strengthens very much the argument for another meeting of the Australian Constitutional Convention in one form or another relatively soon, a matter to which I adverted in Question Time today. I hope the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) takes aboard the implications of this report in that respect when he is discussing with the Cabinet the question of Commonwealth initiative or participation in a further session of the Constitutional Convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will detain the Senate only very briefly on this matter, mainly to thank the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for its consideration and appreciation of the undoubted diminution of the rights of public servants in present practices. This is a matter on which I have had regular and continued representations over the years and I think it is something that is considered very much within the community. If something could be done about that in due course along the lines of the Committee's recommendation-I have not read the report yet, but Senator Missen has made clear what it intends-it would be welcomed by society. I am also rather interested in the recommendation concerning bankrupt and insolvent persons because the situation represents a weakness in many respects in the Constitution. Without having too many flights of fancy one could envisage a situation-personal experience inclines me to this view-in which a large organisation or a very wealthy individual, if they wished, could get rid of a member of parliament by forcing him into a situation in which he incurred very heavy costs as either plaintiff or defendant in a libel action. Costs in such matters now are alarmingly high and unless a person is extremely wealthy he may well involuntarily become bankrupt or have to seek that recourse. Indeed, a member of Parliament might lose his place or be induced deliberately to lose his place because of that one factor alone. I hope that this report of the Committee, which intends to clear some of the cobwebs of the Constitution that have become so irrelevant over the passage of time, will be considered seriously and will not suffer the same fate as many other reports from committees of this place. I would like merely to back up Senator Evans's comment that one hopes some further action will be taken soon to see that these enlightened ideas are brought forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak principally to see that the debate on this report will take place at some later date. Of course, I have not seen the report and all that I have had the opportunity to read at present is the statement brought down by Senator Missen. I have a particular interest in the report because, as Senator Missen said, the inquiry arose out of a private member's Bill which I introduced into this place on 15 November 1978. I had no idea when I introduced that Bill that such a comprehensive report would be furnished with respect to it. Of course, the report deals with more than the Bill which I brought forward-it goes much further-and, therefore, it is such an important report that I think we must debate it in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage I would just like to congratulate the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for the work it has done. It has been remarked to me on a couple of occasions that, had I not brought down that private member's Bill, there would have been far less work for a few honourable senators. But I believe that the work they have done will not only take away that constitutional bar with respect to many public servants that I was aiming to take away but also it will tidy up a great deal of section 44 of the Constitution. It seems to me from reading Senator Missen's statement that other sections of the Constitution are involved as well.

I will not say anything further because I want to have the opportunity to study the report in detail and because I think we should be able to debate it in great detail in this place. I join with Senator Mason in expressing a hope that the recommendations outlined in this report do not end up like many other reports that come before this place and that eventually we will have a referendum throughout Australia to make sure that that section of the Constitution is in a more contemporary form. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SENATE STANDING COMITTEE ON NATIONAL RESOURCES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Alternatives to Petroleum Based Fuels-Government Response: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I seek leave to incorporate the text of the statement in Hansard. It should be noted that where the first person personal pronoun is used, it relates to the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick).

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
On 23 November 1978, the Senate referred the following matter to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources:
The replacement of petroleum-based fuels by alternative sources of energy with regard to: (a) research into alternative fuels;
(b) development and demonstration of practical alternatives; and
(c) fiscal and other measures required to encourage their adoption.

In addition the Committee decided to include the effects of conservation as part of its reference. As the Minister responsible for national energy policy, it is my responsibility to make a statement to the Parliament detailing the Government's response to the report of the Committee, which was tabled on 18 September 1980.

Let me first congratulate the Committee on a most comprehensive report which I believe is a generally fair and objective assessment of Australia's energy problems, an area in which it has been often difficult to obtain bipartisan agreement. In particular I wish to draw the attention of honourable senators to the conclusion of the Committee concerning the Government's import parity pricing policy:

Whilst the Committee acknowledges that the Government's world parity pricing policy covers both old and new oil the significant feature is that all future discoveries in Australia will be covered by world parity pricing and this assurance provides the framework and incentive for further exploration and for the development and introduction of viable alternatives. The Committee supports a world parity pricing policy for crude oil in order to secure access to imports of crude oil, to encourage exploration and the development of alternatives and to promote conservation.

The Committee's report identifies Australia's major energy problem as an approaching problem of liquid fuel supply, particularly as it might affect certain sectors of the economy-mining, transport and agriculture-where substitution by non-liquid energy sources is difficult or impossible. In this assessment of Australia's energy situation, the Committee is broadly in accord with the perceptions and actions of government. The report made 34 recommendations. With the concurrence of the Senate, I incorporate in Hansard a summary of the report's recommendations and the Government responses to them.
The document read as follows-
SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON NATIONAL RESOURCES
Report on Replacement of Petroleum Fuels: Schedule of Government Responses to Report's Recommendations
Recommendation
1. NEAC's fuel economy goals be introduced as mandatory requirements on a fleet average basis for cars and station wagons.
Government response
The Government has indicated it prefers a voluntary approach to vehicle fuel economy goals. Regulations should be considered if the goals are not achieved.
Recommendation
2. A fuel consumption program should be established to facilitate fuel conservation in the road haulage industry.
Government response
The Departments of National Development and Energy and Transport are currently co-operating in preparatory work aimed at the development of a voluntary fuel economy program for trucks and buses.
Recommendation

3. Protection for the motor industry be reviewed with the object of applying a more direct competitive stimulus to the local industry to adopt advanced fuel efficient technologies; the removal of quota restrictions on car imports and variation of local content regulations should be the first steps in such a review.
Government response

Protection for the local motor vehicle industry up to 1984 was the subject of a recent Government announcement (3 December 1980). Energy conservation will be one factor considered when post 1984 policies are formulated.
Recommendation
4. A graded sales tax on engine size or power output be introduced to discriminate against large engined or less fuel efficient vehicles with the lowest rate applying to very economical small cars.
Government response

Under the impact of more realistic fuel prices, consumer preferences have already moved strongly in favour of more fuel efficient vehicles. No further action of the type suggested by the Committee is considered warranted at this stage.
Recommendation

5. A continuing publicity campaign aimed at heightening public awareness of the need to conserve fuel and the methods by which that may be accomplished be conducted by the Commonwealth and State Governments.
Government response

During 1980-81, the Commonwealth is contributing $1 million to the continuing conservation publicity program. The States (except W.A. and Queensland) are supplementing this expenditure. No increase in expenditure is considered to be justified in 1980-81.
Recommendation
6. The Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC) inquire into and make a recommendation on the abolition of standing charges applying to motor vehicle ownership.
Government response
To abolish standing charges imposed by the States, an increase in fuel taxes would be necessary. The proposal is under consideration in a number of States.
Recommendation
7. Comprehensive national standards for the manufacture and use of LPG vehicles be prepared as a matter of urgency.
Government response
A new comprehensive standard is expected to be printed in 1981.
Recommendation
8. The Commonwealth Government require the oil companies to produce an automotive LPG which meets the requirements of the motor industry.
Government response

It is not within the powers of the Commonwealth to require the oil companies to produce LPG of a particular specification. However, the matter of determining a fuel specification for LPG is receiving attention from a joint industry committee.
Recommendation
9. LPG be made eligible for the rural freight subsidy.
Government response
In view of the subsidies already announced for household and traditional commercial and decentralised industrial LPG users, it is not considered appropriate to act on this recommendation.
Recommendation

10. The Commonwealth Government through the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council (NERDDC) and the Australian Transport Advisory Council promote research into, and practical application of, advanced traffic management techniques.
Government response
In view of current activity in ATAC and support by NERDDC in this area, no additional promotion is considered necessary.
Recommendation
11. The Commonwealth Government take the initiative in formulating with the States a national policy to facilitate and encourage the development of electricity co-generation by Australian industry.
Government response

Because of the responsibilities of State Governments for electricity supply, this recommendation should be considered in an appropriate Commonwealth/State forum, e.g. the Australian Minerals and Energy Council (AMEC). The question of co-generation shall be placed on the agenda for the next AMEC meeting.
Recommendation
12. The Commonwealth through the Department of Productivity become involved in providing energy audits and related advice to industry.
Government response

No further action is considered necessary to supplement the existing activities of the National Industrial Energy Management (NIEM) scheme, the National Energy Conservation Program, the Standards Association of Australia and State authorities.
Recommendation
13. Increased emphasis be given to research and development into coal combustion in general and particularly fluidised bed combustion and electricity generation using magneto hydro-dynamics.
Government response

Commonwealth support for these technologies as for other technologies, should be determined within the framework of the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration (NERDD) Program, taking note of support provided by other organisations.
Recommendation

14. The Commonwealth Department of Housing and Construction initiate the establishment of an Australia-wide information service, in co-operation with the States, dealing with energy conservation in buildings.
Government response

The Departments of Housing and Construction and National Development and Energy are currently examining the subject of energy conservation in buildings and the appropriate role for the Commonwealth to play in promoting further conservation in buildings. Arising out of that examination a proposal for appropriate Commonwealth involvement will be made at a later date.
Recommendation
15. The Department of National Development and Energy, in consultation with the oil industry investigate the optimum means of developing hydrocracking capacity in Australian refineries.
Government response
Government involvement in determining which technology option of oil refiners choose to meet changing market requirements is not considered to be warranted.
Recommendation
16. The Commonwealth vary the excise rate applying to 89 to 92 octane petroleum to establish a clear 2 or 3 cents/litre price advantage over super grade (97 RON) petroleum.
Government response
The Department of National Development and Energy has this option under active review.
Recommendation
17. A research project to establish the relationship between lead additives, fuel economy and exhaust emissions under normal usage be set up as a matter of urgency by the Commonwealth Government.
Government response

This study has been performed by the Committee on Motor Vehicle Emissions (COMVE). The study was considered at the February 1981 ATAC meeting. The introduction of lead-free 91.5 octane petrol and the use of catalytic converters was endorsed by that ATAC meeting as the optimum technology for meeting vehicle emission goals.
Recommendation

18. The opportunity be taken to examine thoroughly the environmental, social and economic impact of the Rundle shale oil project with the object of resolving points which are in dispute and producing a standard set of guidelines on these matters which will enable future similar projects to proceed in a context of predictability as to Government requirements and intention.
Government response

The updated information contained in the Commonwealth environmental impact statement on Rundle will permit informed examination of the environmental, social and economic implications of the Rundle oil shale project when it becomes available. At the same time it will be possible to evaluate to the general applicability of guidelines established for its preparation, to other projects of this type.
Recommendation

19. Hydrocarbon plants to be given a very high priority and emphasis in future research, development and demonstration funding and that a combined approach by the Commonwealth and the State Departments of Agriculture be encouraged.
Government response

Under the 1980-81 NERDD Program, support will be provided for an overview feasibility study in this area. The second part of the recommendation has been drawn to the attention of the Australian Agricultural Council. No additional action is considered necessary.
Recommendation

20. The Government establish a large-scale demonstration project involving the actual operation of vehicles using blended fuels with the object of clarifying the effect of those fuels in areas such as fuel consumption, exhaust emissions and driveability.
Government response

As part of the NERDD Program, investigations into the suitability of using alcohol fuels in vehicles have been supported. Shell and CSR are also test marketing an alcohol/ petrol blend in Queensland. No supplementary action is considered necessary at this stage.
Recommendation
21. NERDDC increase its support of research into cultivation and selection of vegetables oils as fuel crops and their utilisation in diesel engines.
Government response

Through the NERDD Program, substantial funds ($270,000) have been made available for research into the production and use of vegetable oils as fuels. No further funding is considered warranted at this time.
Recommendation
22. The feasibility of small-scale vegetable oil extraction plants suitable for on-farm use be examined.
Government response

Under the NERDD Program, nearly $68,000 has been committed to developing improved methods of vegetable oil extraction, suitable for on-farm use. CSIRO and BAE studies indicate that, except in the case of isolated properties, on farm production of oil from oilseeds is currently economically unattractive.
Recommendation
22A Research gives emphasis to crops that do not compete for land with existing food crops.
Government response

CSIRO research results indicate that significant quantities of oilseeds can be grown in the cereal belt without prejudicing existing crop production. Implementation of this recommendation may restrict Australia's potential to meet liquid fuels requirements from biomass, and may eventually distort the balance between land use for meat and fibre production and that used for crop production.
Recommendation
23. NERDDC direct funds to research into the large-scale production of hydrogen and into hydrogen hydrides.
Government response

Hydrogen research is accorded a lower priority under the NERDD Program. Some projects involving production and storage of hydrogen are being supported. No further action is considered warranted at this stage.
Recommendation

24. The Commonwealth in conjunction with the State Governments should take a more positive role in initiating and encouraging research development and demonstration in specific areas which are considered to be in the public interest.
Government response
The NERDD Program has provided nearly $60 million for energy research within the framework of established national priorities for energy R&D. Additional action is not considered warranted.
Recommendation

25. Research and development into electric vehicles receive a high priority and that support be provided for demonstration programs for small passenger/commuter vehicles as well as for commercial vehicles.
Government response

R&D into electric vehicles already receives a high priority under the NERDD program. Support for demonstration programs for small passenger/commuter vehicles will be considered when suitable technology becomes available. No change to these arrangements is considered warranted.
Recommendation
26. Steam engine development for both stationary and automotive purposes receive a higher priority for development and demonstration funding.
Government response

The Commonwealth has provided substantial assistance for the development of steam engines. Because of the poor performance of the engines so funded, NERDDC has not supported additional steam engine projects. No further action is considered warranted.
Recommendation
27. The use of pipelines in Australia for slurry applications be encouraged in future resource projects.
Government response
A number of investigations into pipeline transport of coal are already underway. No additional Government involvement is warranted at this time.
Recommendation
28. The operation of Section 73A of the Taxation Act should permit deductability for demonstration projects leading to commercial production.
Government response
The operation of Section 73A of the Taxation Act already provides significant support to R&D. No further concessions for incorporation into the Section are warranted at this time.
Recommendation
29. Greater emphasis should be given to development and demonstration projects in Australia.
Government response

Considerable support is already being provided for such proposals under the NERDD program. However, demonstration projects aimed primarily at commercialisation, as distinct from assessing technical feasibility, are mainly the responsibility of private enterprise.
Recommendation

30. At the Commonwealth level a joint consultative group be established by the Department of National Development and Energy to provide a formal mechanism by which other Commonwealth Departments can be directly involved in the formulation, implementation and review of the Commonwealth's energy policy.
Government response
Existing channels of consultation between Departments on energy issues are considered to operate in a satisfactory manner and no additional consultative group is considered necessary.
Recommendation
31. The need for the large number of advisory bodies be reviewed.
Government response

Any reduction in the number of specialist advisory bodies would deny the Government the specialist technical advice essential to the proper formulation of energy policy. Larger resources of Commonwealth staff might well be required to maintain the quality of advice to the Government currently provided by these advisory bodies.
Recommendation
32. The Australian Minerals and Energy Council be restructured as the principle mechanism and forum for the development and implementation of co-ordinated energy policies in Australia.
Government response

AMEC could not be reorganised without the full agreement of the States; in practice this could prove extremely difficult. Current arrangements for AMEC have been working satisfactorily, and there would appear to be no good reason for proposing changes to the States.
Recommendation
33. The Income Tax provisions in relation to Section 73A, investment allowances and concessions to individuals, be reviewed.
Government response
The Government already provides substantial taxation concessions for various users. The Government considers that no further concessions are warranted at this time.
Recommendation
34. The application of the existing customs duty criteria be changed so that cases where no genuine local equivalent is manufactured in Australia can be identified and permitted duty free entry.
Government response

A provision already exists to allow imported goods to be entered at minimum duty rates when suitably equivalent goods are not reasonably available from local production. It is considered inappropriate to extend these provisions to give additional concessional treatment to energy conservation measures at this stage.

Many of the report's recommendations are broadly in line with current Government initiatives. Others, such as recommendation 17 dealing with the relationship between lead additives, fuel economy and exhaust emissions, have been acted on already and, in some instances, circumstances have changed so as to make the Committee's recommendations inappropriate. Yet others have some attractive features and indeed have been proposed in the past. Indeed, many of them have been examined by governments, but have had to be rejected because of difficulties that would be encountered in implementation or because of irreconcilable conflicts with existing policies.

In particular, any review of government liquid fuels policy must take into account related issues such as exploration for and development of conventional oil reserves, oil depletion policies, and liquid fuels stockpiling policy. Such policies must be integrated with other government policies, including policies concerning energy related resource development, employment and industrial policies, and inflation and general economic policy. Of necessity however, the Committee's terms of reference could not cover all these issues. The major issues covered by the report can be discussed in the context of existing government policies designed to improve liquid fuel supplies and develop a diversified energy base. These policies cover four main areas:
the conservation of liquid fuel supplies;
the substitution of more abundant energy sources, such as coal and gas, for liquid fuels;
the stimulation of exploration for, and development of, Australia's remaining oil resources; and
the encouragement of the development of alternative liquid fuels.
Conservation

Although strictly outside its terms of reference, the Committee justifiably considered conservation as an area of major importance. It supported the Government's import parity pricing policy as an important instrument for stimulating conservation. The success of Government policies in promoting conservation and substitution out of liquid fuels is already apparent. During the period to 1978 growth in petroleum product consumption averaged 2.3 per cent per annum. In 1979, that is, after the introduction of full import parity pricing, that growth rate dropped to 1.4 per cent and in 1980, consumption fell by 4.4 per cent.
