Taking into account the strong economic growth in recent years-3.5 per cent in 1979, and over 4 per cent in 1980-and the generally recognised short term inelasticity of petroleum product use, these results are a very pleasing indication of the success of the import parity pricing policy. As other non-pricing measures, such as motor vehicle fuel economy goals, begin to take effect, further substantial savings can be expected.

In addition, the report recommended greater government activity in areas such as publicity, public information and education, and energy audits. This is consistent with recent Government initiatives. The 1980-81 Budget approved an allocation of $1m to continue the National Energy Conservation Program, $1m for the Energy Policy Information Program, and $0.5m for the first year of the National Industrial Energy Management Scheme. I shall be proposing that these programs be continued in 1981-82.
Substitution

The Committee again acknowledged the primary role of Government pricing policy in stimulating substitution. The Government has a number of other, complementary policies in place to encourage substitution. These include tax concessions for industrial and commercial users converting from oil to other energy sources such as coal or solar power. In addition, a range of pricing and fiscal measures directed at encouraging liquefied petroleum gas use in automobiles were announced on 8 April 1980. These pricing arrangements have provided an attractive incentive for automotive LPG use in high mileage vehicles.
Exploration

Although the Committee's report does not deal with this subject, a brief mention of it here is essential because of the importance of new oil production to our liquid fuel position. The Government's commitment to full import parity pricing, free of levy, for 'new' oil, coupled with various tax concessions, have been dramatic stimulants to oil exploration activity. Expenditure on oil exploration and development is estimated to be $1,400m in 1981, compared with $781m in 1980 and $430m in 1979. A substantial expansion in Australia's oil reserves has occurred both from new discoveries and additions arising from the fact that higher prices have enabled the development of oil pools previously considered uneconomic. The result of these factors is shown in the fact that our reserves of crude oil at 30 September 1980 were, at 283.88 million barrels, 5.8 per cent greater than they were at the end of 1978 and 33.5 per cent greater than they were at the end of 1976.
Alternative Liquid Fuels

While the Committee discussed the area of alternative liquid fuels at length, few specific recommendations were made. However, since the tabling of the Committee's report, an informative and comprehensive report on this subject has been published by the National Energy Advisory Committee. This report 'Alternative Liquid Fuels', released on 2 February 1981, is a realistic assessment of the hurdles to be overcome before the alternatives to crude oil become a reality on a large scale. Although the barriers to synthetic fuel development are considerable, the policies of the Government have led to interest by private entrepreneurs in alternative fuel development in Australia, particularly in shale oil and coal liquids. In addition to the incentive provided by pricing policies, the Government has in place a number of measures which stimulate alternative fuel development, including tax concessions, facilitating the provision of infrastructure, considerable research and development support, and specific measures to encourage smaller scale alternatives such as LPG and ethanol. The activity being carried on by such groups as Nippon Brown Coal Limited, BHP, CSR, the Australian Coal Corporation and the Rundle partners is clear indication that these policies are having the desired effect.
Research and Development

The Committee devoted considerable attention to energy research, development and demonstration, particularly areas of energy research which should receive Commonwealth support through the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration-NERDD-program. Almost all the areas identified by the Committee as requiring sustained research and development funding are receiving support under the NERDD program, with the exceptions of steam power and hydrogen. Funds under the NERDD program are allocated according to a set of priorities. These priorities were determined only after extensive consultation with over 150 organisations having an interest in energy supply, demand, end-use and research and development. The NERDD program is developed on the recommendations of the NERDD Council, an independent body consisting of persons drawn from a wide range of business, government and research organisations. Under these circumstances, it is not clear that a case has been made for changing the workings of the NERDD program. The Committee's views will, however, be taken into account when the next review of the NERDD program is made.
Energy Policy Machinery

The Committee made a number of recommendations relating to energy policy machinery. It suggested for instance that there was a need to review the number of committees providing advice to the Government in the field of energy policy. Any reduction in these advisory committees would deny me, as the responsible Minister, and the Government, the specialist technical advice essential to the proper formulation of energy policy. Such a reduction might well be self-defeating in that larger resources of Commonwealth staff might be necessary to maintain the quality of advice to Government currently provided by these advisory bodies.

The Committee also recommended the creation of a joint consultative group of Commonwealth departments to consider energy issues. The Government considers that existing channels of consultation between departments on energy issues operate in a satisfactory manner. In view of the Committee's concern on the duplication of energy policy machinery in the Commonwealth area, the Government has decided not to implement this recommendation. The Senate Committee also recommended strengthening the Australian Minerals and Energy Council- AMEC-as the forum for co-ordinating energy policies in Australia. AMEC meetings are, however, already generally structured to facilitate consideration of energy issues and the current arrangements for AMEC are working well.
Conclusion

The Government recognises the crucial importance of liquid fuel supply in the coming decades. It welcomes the inquiry by the Senate Committee in this area and is acting on several of its recommendations, while keeping a number of others under active review. The outlook for Australia's liquid fuel self-sufficiency is considerably improved on forecasts made only a few years ago. Growth of demand in the next two decades is now likely to be lower than was previously estimated, due to higher oil prices and to the impact of the Government's substitution and conservation policies. Oil exploration has increased significantly in recent years and significant additions to oil reserves have been made. Synthetic fuel projects, such as oil shale development and coal liquefaction, will provide additional liquid fuel resources in the 1990s and beyond. These developments will assist in helping to maintain a relatively high degree of self-sufficiency in liquid fuels through to the turn of the century. However, the continued application of government policies, particularly pricing, supplemented where appropriate with other measures, will be necessary if reality is to meet expectations. As the Committee correctly pointed out of course, the secure supply of liquid fuels to Australia's industries must remain a key area of Government concern for the foreseeable future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I will speak very briefly because I understand that the Government will make time available for a proper debate on this report later. I want to make just two points. Firstly, there are several references in the statement of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) to the Government's policy of import parity pricing for newly discovered oil. The implication is that that policy was originally one of the Fraser Government. Such reinterpretations and misinterpretations of history are quite common. The plain fact, of course, is that the policy of paying import parity prices for newly discovered oil-less at that stage only what is now a fairly insignificant levy of $3 a barrel-dates from the middle of September 1975, and was initiated by the last Federal Australian Labor Party Government. It was carried on by this Government. The exploration effects of that policy-nobody would deny that those exploration effects have been significant-are the product of policy common to the present coalition Government and the previous Labor Government.

The other point I make is that recommendation 31 of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources recommended 'the need for the large number of advisory bodies to be reviewed', the implication quite clearly being that the number of advisory bodies be reduced. Senator Durack, in reply on behalf of the Government, has said that the specialist technical advice is necessary and to reduce the number of bodies would deny the Government that specialist technical advice. That may be so. I would not pass judgment on that. However, the point I make is that the next time it seems to be necessary for this Government to pull another political stunt out of the bag, we might find that the number of those committees is, in fact, reduced if precedent from the last political stunt-the so-called razor gang report-is to be taken as any guide. Among other things, in that report the Government abolished the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension which it had established with great fanfare only two years before. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I do not want to take a great deal of the Senate's time. As Senator Walsh has said, this matter can be debated at some time in the future. I think it is important to make the point at this stage that a reading of the statement by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) makes it apparent that this is another one of those sad days for the Senate. The recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, which has done a very good job in opening up a tremendous and important matter, have not really been taken seriously. Apparently the Government does not have any intention of implementing them in any effective way. The providing of motor spirit on which we can continue to run our cars and trucks in the future in a country which, as I have said before in this place, is the most dependent of all the Western developed countries in the world on roads and motor transport and, therefore, on motor spirit is a very important issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The years are passing quite remorselessly. At the moment we may be deceived by the fact that there is a glut of oil products in the world. Prices seem to be going down. There is discounting again in the petrol stations. Because of this, I believe, Australians are being lulled into a totally false sense of security on the matter. The Bass Strait crude is now steadily drying up and no other major oilfield is in sight in this country. Although we all, of course, hope greatly that one will be found, the technical evidence that I have been able to establish so far is to the effect that we are not likely to find one. I think the Government is pulling the wool over people's eyes in its response to this report, especially by talking about oil from coal and Rundle. The image of Rundle has been severely dented in recent months, and, of course, for good reason. As far as many of us here, who think about these issues, are concerned, for a long time it never had an image. The image has been dented because of the almost inextricable difficulties that face this project, no matter which way it is looked at, and which, of course, will not be resolved, regardless of the reassurances of the Government. I can only wonder why the Government persists in trying to make these continual reassurances about Rundle. The Government somehow sees Rundle as a gift to the Australian people, which will solve all of our problems in the future. Again, the processing of coal to oil poses many problems. The technology has yet to be developed, particularly with regard to Australian coals. The advice that I have is that virtually every type of Australian coal will demand a different technology. It is not just a matter of saying that there is a lot of coal in Australia and we will turn it into oil. That is the simple way the solution to the problem has been presented.

One of the things that worries me greatly about the recommendations of the Committee is that I can see no reference at all in the Minister's statement to the idea of making methanol from natural gas. This is a technology which is now being considered very seriously by a neighbouring country-New Zealand-with the Maui Field. The technology for that process is not only thoroughly established throughout the world but also relatively cheap. The lead time for bringing on methanol plants that could give us a significant extender to our petroleum is quite short; it is about two years. I am concerned that, although this matter has been raised with the Government again and again by many people-I think it may have been raised in evidence to the Committee-apparently, for some perverse reason, the Government does not want to go to the natural gas producers of this country and say: 'Why do we not have this valuable national asset-methanol-which could be used as M15, in our own petrol? It would immediately give us the option-certainly within two years-of being able to reduce substantially the amount of petrol that we need'.

On page 3, the Minister mentions that consumption fell in 1980 by 4.4 per cent. This is apparently seen as a cause for self-congratulation. I see it as being very far from that in view of the situation we are likely to face in future on motor spirit and which we may have to face at very short notice if, for instance, things blew up in Saudi Arabia. I would have thought that it should have been possible to reduce consumption very much more than that. If the recommendations of the Committee's report were carried out, indeed consumption would go down very much more quickly than that. On page 4, the point is made that the Government is giving:
. . . tax concessions for industrial and commercial users converting from oil to other energy sources such as coal or solar power.

I ask again: Why are tax concessions being given simply to industrial and commercial users? Why can we not do what is being done in a dozen other countries and offer a decent tax concession to domestic users of solar power so that they can be induced to overcome the large problem, the high capital costs of a solar installation, which prevents many thousands of young Australians putting solar heaters in their homes when they build them. In California there is a 65 per cent subsidy from State and Federal income tax for solar installations. As a result the demand for solar power has grown enormously. The California Energy Commission has found that it will not have to build new thermal power stations in future because the demand for thermal power has fallen. I wonder why the Government is so obdurate and so tardy on that matter, which is now one of great interest to the community.

On page 5, we read of the Government harping back to the matter of shale oil and coal liquids. It mentions the smaller scale alternatives, such as liquid petroleum gas and ethanol. Here again, no mention is made of methanol. Methanol is the obvious fuel; it sticks out a mile. We would have thought that anybody would have quickly come to the conclusion to use methanol. I regret that, on page 5, hydrogen and steam power are seen as not having very good priority. I would have thought that an intelligent program in this area might have been of some service to this country.

I turn briefly to the recommendations. The first four recommendations of the Committee are designed to get rid of the gas guzzling motor car. I think they are highly intelligent recommendations and very much to the point. Yet the Government has indicated in its response that it does not want to do anything about the recommendations. The first recommendation of the Committee states:
NEAC's fuel economy goals be introduced as mandatory requirements on a fleet average basis for cars and station wagons.
The Government's response states:
The Government has indicated it prefers a voluntary approach to vehicle fuel economy goals. Regulations should be considered if the goals are not achieved.

Of course it is a very simple matter when the Government provides the motor industry with the laughably easy goals it has, instead of something of any real significance which might make some appreciable difference to the consumption of fuel in this country. Of course, the voluntary approach will perhaps meet the very easy situation which the Government is now considering.
The Committee goes on to say in Recommendation 2:
A fuel consumption program should be established to facilitate fuel conservation in the road haulage industry.
The Government states that it is:
. . . currently co-operating in preparatory work aimed at the development of a voluntary fuel economy program for trucks and buses.

How many steps are in that? The Government is currently co-operating in preparatory work aimed at the development of a voluntary fuel economy program. There are four steps before anything gets done. I think that this shows the lack of seriousness with which the Government regards this situation. Recommendation 3 states:

Protection for the motor industry be reviewed with the object of applying a more direct competitive stimulus to the local industry to adopt advanced fuel efficient technologies; the removal of quota restrictions on car imports and variation of local content regulations should be the first steps in such a review.

The Australian Democrats could not agree more with the Committee, but, of course, the Government does not. When there are fuel efficient cars like the Daihatsu Charade, which everybody in Australia wants to buy and which has a waiting list, the Government says: 'No, we are going to keep them out'. Why do we want to keep them out? Presumably the Government wants to do that to allow the Australian motor industry to go on with its silly, inefficient current productions, some of which, as I have said, do no more than nine miles to the gallon. I am speaking there of the major manufacturers. Yet we allow that situation to go on.
The Committee did not think that should happen. In its Recommendation 4, it states:
A graded sales tax on engine size or power output be introduced to discriminate against large engined or less fuel efficient vehicles with the lowest rate applying to very economical small cars.
What a sensible, intelligent and rational view! But the Government's response states:
Under the impact of more realistic fuel prices, consumer preferences have already moved strongly in favour of more fuel efficient vehicles.

In other words, it is going to be left to God again, like everything else the Government considers needs doing. I have news for the Government. Because of the soft way in which it is presenting the fuel crisis to the Australian people-it is saying that there is not really a crisis and that Rundle will solve it all-according to motoring writers now there is a move in Australia to go back to driving cars that use a great deal of petrol. I think it is a very serious indictment of the Government that it allows this to happen. I urge the Government to reconsider its response to this report because this is an urgent matter. I urge it to look at this Committee's report and especially to the first four sensible and rational recommendations. I urge it to get to work and to agree with the Committee's recommendations. If the Government simply agreed with those and said: 'We will do these things', I am sure that it would achieve the respect of the Australian people because it would at last have set us on an energy course which would get some significant reduction in petrol consumption. It would also give the Australian people the type of motor car they want. That is not what is happening at the moment.
Recommendation 20 states:

The Government establish a large-scale demonstration project involving the actual operation of vehicles using blended fuels with the object of clarifying the effect of those fuels in areas such as fuel consumption, exhaust emissions and driveability.

That would be a great idea. Other countries are doing it. It has never been done under Australian conditions. New Zealand, which is a much smaller country than ours, can afford to do it and thinks that it is worth doing. But, of course, we do not do it in Australia. The magnificent sum of $270,000 is being put into the important area of support for research into the cultivation and selection of vegetable oils as fuel crops and the utilisation of diesel engines. The Government puts that amount forward as an answer to the Committee's recommendations. When we have time to look at this report in more detail, I think we will certainly have more to say about it. All I can say now to Senator Carrick-I must make a classical allusion to him-is that in this case he is very much our fuel Nero. He is very much fiddling while Rome burns and while time passes and he is doing virtually nothing. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Debate (on motion by Senator Durack) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have before me a statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) on a proposed multinational peacekeeping force for the Sinai and possible Australian participation in that force. I seek leave to incorporate the text of that statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The purpose of this statement is not to announce a decision by the Government on Australian participation in the proposed force-Australia has still not yet formally been invited to participate in the force-but to set before the Senate the facts and information additional to that available when I last spoke on this subject on 14 May, and to indicate the issues which the Government will take into account in reaching a decision. Honourable senators will be aware that the focus of Middle East peace negotiations over the last three and a half years has been the process begun by President Sadat when he visited Jerusalem and addressed the Knesset in November 1977. President Sadat's unprecedented and dramatic visit to Jerusalem led to negotiations between Egypt and Israel, with the United States also involved, which culminated in the Camp David accords in September 1978 and the Egyptian-Israeli Peace Treaty of March 1979.

Essentially the Camp David accords and the Peace Treaty can be divided into two parts. The first dealt with the Israeli occupied territories of the West Bank and Gaza and set out a procedure for implementing 'full autonomy' for the inhabitants of those two areas after the establishment of an elected self-governing authority. The Government regrets that progress on this aspect of the peace process has been disappointingly slow. Nevertheless this aspect of the peace process, while proving extremely difficult to implement, has helped to isolate the issues involved and has contributed to a greater understanding, by those outside the Middle East as well as those directly involved, of those issues. Mr President, it must be emphasised that progress on these complex issues is essential if undertakings in the accords concerning the return of occupied territory in the Sinai are to be met. The Government, for its part, believes that successfully carrying out the accords as they relate to the Sinai, could be crucial in influencing those sections of the Arab world which have strong reservations about whether the complex problems of the Middle East can be resolved by means other than conflict.

Undoubtedly the major achievement of the peace process has been the bilateral peace treaty between Egypt and Israel. This has proved that Israel and an Arab country, despite thirty years of bitterness and war, can negotiate a substantive peace agreement involving basic concessions on both sides. There is no doubt that as a result both Israel and Egypt have received substantial benefit. Israel's security interests have been enhanced substantially while Egypt has regained a good part of the Sinai and is now able to concentrate on domestic economic reconstruction. This is a significant achievement and must not be put at risk. Progress on the second part of the accords, the bilateral aspects of the Peace Treaty, has been good. Diplomatic relations have been established, Ambassadors exchanged and civil aviation, commercial, telecommunications and other links have been established. In addition, and most importantly from the Egyptian perspective, Israel has withdrawn from approximately two thirds of the Sinai. Egypt now controls all of the Sinai west of an interim line running from El Arish in the north down to Ras Muhammed on the southern tip of the Sinai. Annex I of the Peace Treaty stipulates that Israel will complete its withdrawal from the Sinai 'not later than three years from the date of exchange of the instruments of ratification of this Treaty'. Hence by the end of April 1982 Israel is scheduled to have withdrawn completely from the Sinai. It is quite clear from the text of the Treaty that Egypt, Israel and the United States envisaged that United Nations Forces would supervise both the Israeli withdrawal from the Sinai and the implementation of the security arrangements agreed on in the Treaty. Article VI of Annex I stipulates the role and functions of such United Nations forces.

Since the signing of the Egyptian-Israeli Peace Treaty in March 1979 the United Nations has been unable to give any mandate which would enable United Nations forces to operate in a peace-keeping role in the Sinai. The United Nations Emergency Force-UNEF-which was carrying out peacekeeping operations in the Sinai ceased operations in July 1979 when the Soviet Union indicated that it would veto an extension of its mandate. Honourable senators will be aware that an Australian helicopter unit was based at Ismailia as part of UNEF. The United Nations Truce Supervisory Organisation-UNTSO-to which a number of Australian officers are seconded, still has about a dozen or so observers in the Sinai but could not be expected to assume the tasks of a Sinai peacekeeping force without the drastic revision of its mandate and a substantial increase in its numbers in the Sinai. Again it is clear that the Soviet Union, which has consistently opposed the Camp David accords and the Peace Treaty, would not agree to an extension of UNTSO's mandate. In recent months there have been informal discussions in the United Nations about the possibility of obtaining a United Nations peacekeeping force to oversee the final Israeli withdrawal from the Sinai and to implement the peacekeeping functions as envisaged by the Treaty.

On 21 April the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Foreign Affairs of Egypt, His Excellency, Kamal Hassan Ali, requested the President of the Security Council to initiate, as a matter of urgency, consultations with members of the Security Council. The purpose was to explore the role of the United Nations, and specifically whether the Security Council would monitor and supervise the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Egyptian territories, and participate in the reciprocal security arrangements through the establishment of the Force and observers, provided for under the Egyptian-Israeli Peace Treaty. On 18 May in a letter to the Egyptian Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Japanese President of the Security Council, Mr Nisibori, replied to the effect that following consultations with individual members of the Security Council, including the Soviet Union, the members of the Security Council were unable, for various reasons, to reach the necessary agreement to facilitate the withdrawal of the Israeli forces and to participate in the security arrangements provided for in the Egyptian-Israeli Peace Treaty. With the concurrence of the Senate, I incorporate in Hansard the letter from the Egyptian Minister for Foreign Affairs, Kamal Hassan Ali, to the President of the Security Council and the President's reply to the Egyptian Minister.
The letters read as follows-
Following are the texts to the Egyptian letter of 21 April to the Irish president of the Security Council and of the reply dated 18 May from the Japanese president of the council:
Begins:
Excellency,

With reference to the letter dated 21 April 1981 from your excellency addressed to the president of the security council for the month of April. I should like to inform your excellency that the individual consultations I have undertaken lead to the conclusion that the members of the security council are unable, for various reasons, to reach the necessary agreement on the proposal contained therein.
Accept, excellency, the assurances of my highest consideration.
MASAHIRO NISIBORI President of the Security Council His Excellency
Mr Kamal Hassan Ali
Deputy Prime Minister and Minister
for Foreign Affairs of the
Arab Republic of Egypt
Cairo (Egypt)
21 April 1981
Excellency,
Upon instructions from my government. I have the honour to bring to your attention a matter which is directly related to the maintenance of peace and security in the Middle East region.

Ever since the inception of the United Nations, the organization has been called upon to ensure the maintenance of peace and security in the Middle East. At this time, when serious attempts are being made to bring the Middle East closer to a comprehensive peace, it is legitimate to expect that the United Nations, particularly, the security council whose primary responsibility is the maintenance of international peace and security, should continue its established practice in undertaking its constructive role to ensure the durability, and consolidation of peace and security in the Middle East.

The Security Council was seized with the situation in the Middle East since armed hostilities erupted, on November 22, 1967 the council unanimously adopted resolution 242, a resolution which is considered the universally agreed basis for a just and comprehensive settlement to the Middle East problem. Security council resolution 242 (1967) required that the establishment of a just and lasting peace in the Middle East should include the application of both the following principles:
Quote: (1) withdrawal of Israel's armed forces from territories occupied in the recent conflict.

(2) termination of all claims or states of belligerency and respect for and adknowledgement of the sovereignty, territorial integrity and political independence of every state in the area and their right to live in peace within secure and recognised boundaries free from threats of acts of force. unquote . . .
The resolution further prescribed, as security arrangements:
. . . guaranteeing the territorial inviolability and political independence of every state in the area through measures including the establishment of demilitarized zones . . .

In accordance with this resolution, the Secretary-General appointed a special representative to promote agreement and assist efforts to achieve a peaceful and acceptable settlement towards this end, the special representative submitted, on February 8th 1971 an aide memoire, to Egypt and Israel. The aide memoire called upon Egypt and Israel to enter into a peace agreement as a first step towards a comprehensive settlement of the Middle East problem. Such an approach was endorsed by the general assembly with increased majorities when it adopted resolutions 2799 (XXVI) and 2941 (XXVII).

In this context, Egypt and Israel concluded a peace treaty on March 26th 1979 and registered it with the Secretary-General on 15 May 1979 in accordance with article 102 of the charter. Consistent with the underlying principles and basic provisions of security council resolution 242 (1967) the treaty stipulated that Israel will withdraw its armed forces behind the international boundary between Egypt and Israel by April 1982. Within this context and to ensure the durability and further consolidation of peace and security, Egypt and Israel agreed to reciprocal security arrangements and a request that the United Nations provide forces and observers.

In the light of the above, the government of the Arab Republic of Egypt views it timely for the security council to consider, on an urgent basis, the modalities for carrying out the required responsibilities for ensuring peace and security in the Middle East.

Towards this end, my government has instructed me to approach your excellency, with a view to consulting the members of the security council in order to ascertain the role of the United Nations, and specifically whether the security council, would undertake to facilitate the withdrawal of the Israeli forces from Egyptian territories and to participate in the reciprocal security arrangement herein referred to through the establishment of the force and observers provided for in the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty.

In this connection, it may be important to confirm that Egypt's request emanates from its solemn commitment to the principles of the charter of the United Nations, from a deep conviction that the presence of the United Nations is the most appropriate formula for ensuring the maintenance of peace and security, and that this request falls within its sovereign rights in liberating its territories and pursuing a policy aimed at establishing a just, comprehensive and lasting peace in the Middle East.

As we have been conducting informal consultations with security council members for several weeks, I would appreciate receiving at the earliest possible date, the results of your excellency's consultations.
Accept, excellency, the assurances of my highest consideration.
(Signed) KAMAL HASSAN ALI Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Foreign Affairs of the Arab Republic of Egypt
His Excellency
Mr Noel Dorr
President of the Security Council
United Nations, N.Y. 10017

Mr President, I deeply regret that the President of the Security Council's letter effectively rules out for the immediate future at least, any United Nations involvement in the withdrawal of Israeli forces from the Sinai under the terms stipulated by the Egyptian-Israeli Peace Treaty. United Nations involvement in this crucial area is therefore not an option. The Senate will be aware that Security Council Resolution 242, which was agreed on after the 1967 Middle East war, called for an Israeli withdrawal from occupied territories. Egypt has expressed the hope that a non-United Nations multinational force will only be of a temporary nature and that the way should be kept open for its replacement by a United Nations force at a later stage. Against the possibility that the United Nations would not agree to fulfil the role envisaged for it, President Carter in letters dated 26 March 1979 to both President Sadat and Prime Minister Begin undertook, and I am quoting directly, 'To ensure the establishment and maintenance of an acceptable alternative multinational force'. With the concurrence of the Senate, I incorporate in Hansard the letters from President Carter to President Sadat and Prime Minister Begin.
The letters read as follows-
THE WHITE HOUSE
Washington
26 March, 1979 Dear Mr President:
I wish to confirm to you that subject to United States Constitutional processes:

In the event of an actual or threatened violation of the Treaty of Peace between Egypt and Israel, the United States will, on request of one or both of the Parties, consult with the Parties with respect thereto and will take such other action as it may deem appropriate and helpful to achieve compliance with the Treaty.
The United States will conduct aerial monitoring as requested by the Parties pursuant to Annex I of the Treaty.

The United States believes the Treaty provision for permanent stationing of United Nations personnel in the designated limited force zone can and should be implemented by the United Nations Security Council. The United States will exert its utmost efforts to obtain the requisite action by the Security Council. If the Security Council fails to establish and maintain the arrangements called for in the Treaty, the President will be prepared to take those steps necessary to ensure the establishment and maintenance of an acceptable alternative multinational force.
Sincerely, JIMMY CARTER His Excellency
Mohamed Anwar El-Sadat,
President of the Arab Republic of Egypt
THE WHITE HOUSE
Washington
26 March, 1979 Dear Mr Prime Minister:
I wish to confirm to you that subject to United States Constitutional processes:

In the event of an actual or threatened violation of the Treaty of Peace between Israel and Egypt, the United States will on request of one or both of the Parties, consult with the Parties with respect thereto and will take such other action as it may deem appropriate and helpful to achieve compliance with the Treaty.
The United States will conduct aerial monitoring as requested by the Parties pursuant to Annex I of the Treaty.

The United States believes the Treaty provision for permanent stationing of United Nations personnel in the designated limited force zone can and should be implemented by the United Nations Security Council. The United States will exert utmost efforts to obtain the requisite action by the Security Council. If the Security Council fails to establish and maintain the arrangements called for in the Treaty, the President will be prepared to take those steps necessary to ensure the establishment and maintenance of an acceptable alternative multinational force.
Sincerely, JIMMY CARTER His Excellency
Menachem Begin,
Prime Minister of the State of Israel

It has been suggested that the formation of such a force is not a part of the Egyptian-Israeli Peace Treaty accords. Nothing could be further from the truth. President Carter's letter is and remains an essential document accompanying the Peace Treaty ratified by both Egypt and Israel. The failure of the United Nations to fulfil the role envisaged for it in the Peace Treaty represents the basis for the current endeavours by Egypt, Israel and the United States to fulfil their obligations to the Peace Treaty through the establishment of an alternative multinational peacekeeping force.

In the absence of any effective United Nations peacekeeping force the United States concluded an agreement in September 1979 with both Egypt and Israel on interim arrangements in which the already existing Sinai Field Mission, which is an American establishment, staffed by American civilians, would continue its monitoring functions in the Sinai. The Israelis while agreeing to these arrangements made it clear that they were acceptable only in the interim period while they still had a substantial force stationed in Eastern Sinai. It is essential that the Parliament understands, Mr President, that Israel regards the establishment of an effective peacekeeping force as an integral part of the Treaty, indeed as an essential pre-requisite for their final withdrawal from the Sinai.

Put bluntly, in the absence of United Nations involvement, failure to form an effective mutlinational force would risk provoking a refusal by Israel to withdrawal from the final third of the Sinai. The consequences of such a refusal cannot be over emphasised. It would be a very severe, if not catastrophic blow to the Camp David peace process and the Egyptian-Israeli Peace Treaty. Beyond this, and in the absence of any progress on the crucial Palestinian issue, it could imperil future prospects for attaining a comprehensive, negotiated peace in the Middle East. Further, it would seriously dent the faith of two nations who, after decades of conflict and death, have deliberately chosen the path of peace through negotiation and compromise as an alternative to mutually ruinous conflict.

The fundamental reason why Israel agreed to withdraw from the Sinai was that a satisfactory set of arrangements to guarantee their security had been agreed upon. These arrangements quietened Israel's legitimate fears about its security and gave it the confidence to take the decision to withdraw. With an effective peacekeeping force in place in the Sinai Israeli's southern flank will be secure. It is the Government's hope that in these circumstances the Israelis would move with greater confidence to negotiate on outstanding issues affecting the future status of the West Bank and Gaza, including the right of the Palestinian people to a homeland.

Since President Sadat's visit to Jerusalem in November 1977 he has pursued bold and imaginative policies in the cause of a negotiated settlement with Israel. Any failure to fully implement the provisions of the Peace Treaty could react adversely on Egypt's ability to carry out its commitments. Moreover, the uncertain and volatile situation in Lebanon reinforces the urgency of dissipating by peaceful means, the atmosphere of suspicion and conflict which has dominated the Middle East for so long.

Mr President, amongst the factors which will be taken into consideration by the Government if and when a formal approach is made to Australia to participate in a multinational peacekeeping force in the Sinai are: First, that Australia's overall interests are served by maintaining the momentum for the peaceful resolution of conflict in the Middle East. Secondly, the Government will need to consider the means available to maintain the momentum for peace. As I stated earlier, Mr President, the inevitability of a Soviet veto has once again effectively removed United Nations involvement from consideration. Thirdly, is the proposed multinational peacekeeping force in accordance with the Camp David accords and the spirit of United Nations Resolution 242, both of which enjoy the unreserved bipartisan support of this Parliament? Fourthly, can the Government support the formation of such a force? Finally, if Australia is formally invited to participate in such a force, are the conditions of participation such as to warrant consideration of Australia's involvement?

Australia has established a record of participation in international peacekeeping operations, both within and outside the United Nations context, which the people of Australia can be justly proud of. By their very nature peacekeeping operations involve risks. The safety of any Australian force associated with the proposed peacekeeping operation in the Sinai, as well as the possible effects on our overall interests in the Middle East, would weigh heavily in any deliberations by the Government. The factors outlined above accurately reflect the present level, and current state of the Government's thinking. I emphasise again, as I did in my statement on 14 May, that any communications between Australia and the parties concerned can be described as being only exploratory at this stage. Even as I address the Senate today negotiations proceed between Egypt, Israel and the United States about the membership, structure and detailed functions of such a force.

In the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs in the House on 14 May, Mr President, he said that the Government believes that such an exploratory approach is both justified and prudent in the present circumstances. It was in accordance with this exploratory approach that in response to an earlier message from the United States Secretary of State I wrote to Mr Haig, on 27 April. In my letter I pointed out that the Australian Government's preference remained for a United Nations peacekeeping force. I referred to allegations in the media in this country and the United States that the proposed multinational force would have a role beyond the Sinai itself. I also referred to speculation about the future use of air bases located in that part of the Sinai which Egypt is scheduled, under the terms of the Peace Treaty, to recover in 1982. I stated that it was important to dispel such suggestions.

I noted that before the Australian Government could make any commitment to participate in the force it would have to be assured that other participants would give the force a broad geographical and political balance. Moreover, I pointed out that Australia's relations with the Arab world will have to be taken into account. While almost all of these governments have opposed the Camp David peace process they have not been opposed to all aspects equally. I said that the Government would welcome advice about the command structure of the force, its controlling authority and the proposed relationship between that authority and the force. I sought information about the financing of the force and asked advice about the proposed duration of any commitment, mentioning that it would obviously be difficult for the Australian Government to consider an open ended commitment. Finally, I mentioned that because the force would be operating on Egyptian and Israeli territory, any formal approach to Australia should be extended by those two countries.

As I stated earlier, it has become apparent from the information we have obtained that there are a number of aspects of the proposed multinational force on which final agreement has not yet been reached. Negotiations are still continuing, and while I understand that Egypt, Israel and the United States are close to agreement, the final details of the force are still to be concluded. I ask the Senate to keep this in mind.

On 19 May the Secretary of State replied to my letter and dealt with some of the general concerns and provided answers to some of the specific questions I had raised. Additionally, Australian officials both here and overseas have sought, and are continuing to seek further information concerning the proposed Sinai force. It is apparent from the Secretary of State's letter to me, that the United States Administration shares the Government's view on a wide range of issues related to the force. Like us, they believe it to be important that a sufficient range of countries participate to ensure that the force is not narrowly based politically or geographically. The United States believes that third world participation is important. We understand that a number of countries from Asia and Latin America are currently being approached to consider participation and we expect states from other parts of the world, including Europe, to be invited in due course.

Secretary of State Haig has clearly stated that the only role of the proposed force is that of peacekeeping in the Sinai. He assured me that any contribution of a United States contingent is for the specific purpose of peacekeeping. Furthermore, the Peace Treaty states that the airfields in the Sinai will be transferred to Egypt for civilian use upon Israeli evacuation, and that these facilities will be under full Egyptian sovereignty and control. The mandate for the proposed force will be Article VI of Annex 1 of the Peace Treaty. The Government understands that details concerning the command and control arrangments, as well as the composition of the force including its civilian elements are still being negotiated. The Government will require further information on this aspect. This would include details concerning, for example, mechanisms for resolving disputes between the parties, and other aspects of co-ordination.

The parties are presently negotiating the establishment of a peacekeeping force of a size sufficient to carry out the functions agreed by Egypt and Israel. Precise details are being worked out at this time. As we understand current thinking, the force is likely to consist of about two thousand men. In addition to infantry battalions, it is envisaged there would be a need for support elements including logistics and communications units. One or more of these elements might be provided by one of the countries contributing to the infantry battalions, or they could come from different states altogether. As was envisaged in the Peace Treaty, it is anticipated that units of the force will be located in the north in the Rafah area and at Sharm Al Shaykh. The contingents would man check points and observation posts and operate patrols in Zone C as defined in the Peace Treaty. The observers would perform verification functions in Zones A, B and D.

The financial arrangements are yet to be finalised, although the hope has been expressed that those contributing states that are in a position to do so will contribute their services, or some part of them, free of charge. The duration of participation by contributing countries remains unclear. It is not expected, however, that national contingents will be required to serve indefinitely although there is likely to be a requirement that an acceptable force be maintained in Sinai so long as either party believes it to be necessary. Current planning is based on the hope that various contingents would agree to serve for a specific duration.

As I mentioned earlier, the reaction of other Arab countries will also be important to us. Their major disagreement has been over the mechanism for solving the Palestinian issue which they regard as the core of the Middle East issue. They have not taken exception to, nor do they dispute, Egypt's right to regain its territory from Israel. This, I believe, is a major distinction when considering likely Arab reaction to possible Australian involvement in a multinational Sinai peacekeeping force.

In setting out the above details I have sought to give as full an account as possible of the current state of play concerning the proposed peacekeeping force. I emphasise again, that at this stage Australia has not been invited to participate and I have already referred to the negotiations which are still proceeding between Egypt, Israel and the United States. It is clear nevertheless, that Australian participation would be welcomed by those countries and that it may only be a matter of time before a formal invitation is extended to Australia.

Mr President, I believe it would be appropriate to make a further brief mention of Australia's interests in the Middle East. In my statement on 14 May I explained that while Australia has limited influence in that area our interest in the maintenance of stability in that region is not limited. The Government believes that this interest is best served by the process of agreement through negotiation and compromise rather than recourse to war. For many years Australia has had important links with the Middle East. These links included our dependence for many years on the Suez Canal as a major trade route to the Mediterranean and Europe. Thousands of Australians fought in Egypt, Libya, Palestine and Syria in two world wars in the cause of peace and, over the last 25 years thousands of migrants from Arab countries have settled in Australia in search of peace. In more recent times this country has contributed with distinction to peacekeeping operations under United Nations auspices in this region. An opportunity now exists for Parliament to express its views on whether Australia has a possible further role in the same cause. In this context I quote from the speech of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) of 21 September 1978, Hansard page 1308, in which he said, inter alia:

Camp David has been a first step but a critically important one. President Carter's initiative in convening the meeting, and his political skill and courage in keeping it going, have created the essential momentum for the next step, which may well be even more difficult. Our hope is that all the parties, and others whom must necessarily become involved now will maintain the momentum.

The Prime Minister's statement on this matter is a carefully considered one, as is proper in such a complex, sensitive and important matter. I commend him for that and assure him, this House and the nation that on this great matter genuine concern for the achievement of lasting peace in the Middle East is a matter of bipartisan commitment.

In conclusion, Mr President, I hope that, on such an important issue, the debate will be a well informed and rational one. The Government is hopeful that it will be possible to maintain a bipartisan approach towards the Camp David accords, the Egypt-Israeli Peace Treaty and the need to maintain the momentum for peace in the Middle East.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

The statement put down by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), which was made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) in the House of Representatives last week, calls, in effect, for bipartisanship on this issue of the proposed peacekeeping force for the Sinai. There is a lot of rhetoric about bipartisanship. The Minister asks: Can the Government support the formation of such a force? It was pointed out in the House of Representatives that the correct question, if the Government is seeking bipartisanship, would be: Can the Government and the Opposition support the formation of such a force? There are a number of reasons why the Opposition cannot do so, including the history of Australia's involvement with the United States of America in the disastrous Vietnam venture.

I wish to identify briefly the reasons for the Australian Labor Party's opposition to the suggestions contained in the statement, especially to the proposition that Australia should be a participant in such a force. Firstly, I say that as a legal document the ministerial statement is a poor one, containing errors of fact and interpretation. It is misleading in that it refers to President Carter's letter as 'part of the Peace Treaty and Accords'. It is not a part of the Peace Treaty and Accords. In fact, it is materially at variance with the Treaty itself. Article VI paragraph 8 of Annex (1) of the 1979 Peace Treaty clearly specified that the force could not include permanent members of the United Nations Security Council. That would include the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. On the other hand, the Carter letter refers to the establishment and maintenance of an acceptable alternative multinational force. Article VI of the Treaty contains nine references to a United Nations force. There is no reference whatsoever in the Treaty to any force other than a United Nations force. Yet the Government says that the mandate it will claim for this action is Article VI. There is no mandate in Article VI for anything but a United Nations peacekeeping force.

I should say that the Labor Party welcomed the Camp David treaties as an important step in the search for a just, comprehensive and lasting peace, to use the Minister's expression. We emphasised at the time the importance of United Nations Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338, which both referred to the role of the United Nations. Indeed, I should point out to the Senate that until March of this year the Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Country Party, Mr Anthony, persistently referred to the circumstances in which a contingent might be provided by Australia towards a force in the Sinai as being of necessity a United Nations force. Mr Anthony said that for very explicit reasons arising from his knowledge of the area and Australia's trading relationships with many of the Arab countries. It was only after March of this year, when one suspects the Fraser caravanserai got going again in a desire to beat up an issue, that Mr Anthony appeared to change his mind about the desirability of a United Nations force.

Having said that, I say that the Opposition is acutely aware of the dangers involved in what is proposed-that is, Australian participation in such a force which is not a United Nations sponsored force. Direct support for such a force could threaten tension between the super-powers and possibly drag Australia into fighting in the Middle East, something which the Deputy Prime Minister clearly wished to avoid for, if I might be unkind, sordid reasons of trade but which should be avoided for a variety of reasons. Secondly, I point out that other nations could see the proposed force as an attempt to smuggle a United States military presence into the Middle East. That is not a suggestion of mine. It is a suggestion which was made by what was until recently a highly reputable newspaper-the Washington Post. It suggested that such a force would be seen as an attempt to smuggle a United States military presence into the Middle East. Having regard to the rhetoric of Secretary of State Haig about the desirability of a rapid deployment force, confusion about that could easily arise. It could be seen, quite obviously, as an attempt to smuggle a United States military presence into the Middle East. Such a force could also become the forerunner of or springboard for the rapid deployment force to which I have just referred and which the United States Administration plans.

The next point I wish to make is that the departments of Defence, Trade and Resources, and Foreign Affairs in Australia have serious reservations about the actions foreshadowed in Foreign Minister Street's statement. The Department of Defence has reservations for reasons of defence-that is, there is very serious doubt as to whether a contingent from the Australian Army could be adequately equipped as a result of six years of defence administration under Mr Killen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not a little unfair to say that the Foreign Minister foreshadowed Australia's involvement? I thought he was having a dollar each way.

—I did not mean to be unfair on that point. It is not material to my argument. I may have misrepresented the position. If I did, I would certainly seek to withdraw that statement and say that the suggestion, from wherever it has come, is resisted by the Department of Defence, for the reasons I have indicated, the Department of Trade and Resources, for the very simple reasons which were advanced in March by the Deputy Prime Minister in relation to Australia's trading relationships with the Middle East, and by the Department of Foreign Affairs, for very obvious reasons of international relations, especially in the Middle East with Arab countries. Of course, we are now informed that the Defence Committee has expressed very grave concern, very serious reservations, about Australia's participation in such a force. It expressed that concern, those reservations about Australian participation, to the Government before Mr Street made his statement. I remind the Senate that the Defence Committee consists of senior public servants from several departments. A report in the Age of 29 May reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee's strongly-worded advice to the Government was received before Mr Street made his statement . . . Its general tone was a good deal more cautious than that of the Foreign Minister.

The article goes on to refer to the exchange of letters between Mr Street and Secretary of State Haig which clearly suggested that unsatisfactory answers were given to the questions asked by Mr Street about Australian involvement.

I conclude my remarks by saying-I guess I speak more for myself than for the Opposition generally in saying this-that, having regard to the experience of this country under conservative governments involving Australia in external ventures such as that of Vietnam and elsewhere, any parliament of this country would be neglecting its duty if it were not very cautious about any proposal which sprung from a political stuntman such as the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in relation to the involvement of Australian troops in the Middle East, South East Asia or anywhere else overseas. There is a very strong onus on any government which argues that Australian troops should be involved overseas in pursuit of grandiose plans of Prime Ministers or foreign potentates, and any government that asserts that has a very strong onus to establish it to the Australian people after the experience we have had under conservative governments in the past in relation to these issues. For those reasons, the Opposition is very unhappy about some of the suggestions which have emerged in the Minister's statement. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have before me a statement concerning the cost of the new Parliament House. I seek leave to incorporate that statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

There has been considerable speculation recently that the cost of the new Parliament House is rising. This is not correct. The building cost of $220m at May 1978 prices approved by Parliament remains, in real terms, the budget for the Parliament House Construction Authority. The Construction Authority is confident that this budget can be maintained. The effects of inflation on wages and materials over the three years since the $220m budget was set must, of course, be taken into account in establishing the cost of the building in today's prices. The Construction Authority has estimated that the cost of the building is $296m at June 1981 prices. I again stress that this is not a change in the budget but merely a recognition of the effects of inflation.

As a member of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) is aware that the Committee in refining and developing the competition submission has identified the need for some minor adjustments to the building brief. If adopted by Parliament these would result in less than a 2 per cent increase in the building cost. During the Budget session, the Minister for the Capital Territory will be submitting a full report to Parliament on the development of the design prior to seeking Parliament's approval for the Construction Authority to proceed to the next stage. The report will elaborate on the information contained in this statement and will clearly show that the Government, through the Construction Authority, is determined to maintain the budget approved by Parliament.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1981CUSTOMS AMENDMENT (SECURITIES) BILL 1981

That the Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1981 is to bring Australian anti-dumping law into conformity with the revised codes of conduct for international trade which were agreed to at the Tokyo round of the multilateral trade negotiations which were completed in December 1979. The associated Customs Amendment (Securities) Bill 1981 is simply an administrative measure which follows on naturally from the policy decisions involved in the production of the main Bill. The Opposition opposes neither of these Bills which is a predictable enough result, given that it was the Whitlam Australian Labor Party Government which, after all, brought down the comprehensive legislation which updated our then existing anti-dumping legislation and brought it into line with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade anti-dumping code. The arguments in support of our position on these Bills have been put in considerable detail in the House of Representatives and it is unnecessary to repeat them here in any detail.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there are two matters which may bear some short repetition. The first matter that I raise refers to those provisions in this Bill which relate not so much to the anti-dumping code but rather to the subsidies and countervailing measures code which is similar to the anti-dumping provisions in that it enables the Government to protect Australian industries from imports which are subsidised by foreign governments. But the difference between this and the anti-dumping provisions is that it appears that Australia has not acceded to this code, no doubt because of the continued existence of our export expansion grants scheme and perhaps also the exports markets development scheme which would be in conflict with any international treaty of this kind. The degree of hypocrisy is not, of course, unusual in our external trade relations. I cannot forebear from noting that at least one rather flagrant, alleged breach of GATT is presently the subject of detailed scrutiny by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. I do ask in this context: How much longer can the Government expect us to be able to get away with double standards in this area of government export subsidies? The Government is no doubt aware that there is a growing hostility to Australia's export subsidies in a number of countries, particularly in Western Europe.

The remaining matter is that there is a real concern in our minds and in the minds of a number of people who are interested in this area as to the administration of anti-dumping measures of this kind. A stronger code, of the kind that is implicit in this legislation, simply cannot be enforced without an appropriate increment in the relevant staffing resources associated with the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, in particular the Bureau of Customs. It is necessary for complaints of dumping in this area, for example those that have been very publicly made recently in respect of Japanese exported washing machines and Korean exported steel, to be resolved not only fairly and effectively but also speedily in the interests of continued trade comity with the trading partners in question. In particular I repeat the Opposition's concern expressed by our shadow Minister, Mr John Brown, in the other place that the closure of the London section of the office of our representation dealing with dumping matters raises a very real question as to the future of the Hong Kong, Tokyo, Auckland and New York offices in this respect. There is a danger, as we see it, that the razor gang mentality will apply, be counter productive and far from achieving real efficiencies in the way government is administered, will produce that phenomenon of producing fundamental ineffectiveness in the legislative area of regulation.

I repeat that the Opposition is wholly in sympathy with the general principles of these Bills and has no detailed quarrel with matters of detail in respect of any of them because they are in accordance with the policy position that the Opposition has consistently adopted and acted upon in legislative form in the Whitlam days. Rather, our concern is with a number of less immediately central matters which are none the less crucial to the effective implementation of this legislation and also to Australia's continued credibility as a trading nation.

Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1981

The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 to incorporate in that Act the new provisions of the revised General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade Anti-Dumping Code and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code. These Codes were included in a number of understandings reached in the Tokyo round of the multilateral trade negotiations concluded in December 1979. The Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 is based on the principles and requirements of the original GATT Anti-Dumping Code. Australia acceded to that code in 1975. The Government announced on 25 June 1980 that Australia should accede to the revised GATT Anti-Dumping Code. This decision took into account the views of State governments, industry associations and other interested groups within the community.

The Bill contains the minor amendments which are necessary before Australia can accede to the revised code. The amendments empower the Minister to accept undertakings from exporters to raise their export prices to undumped levels. Retrospective dumping duties may be imposed where the undertakings have been violated. The amendments also include additional criteria for assessment of normal values of goods in countries where the Government substantially influences domestic prices. Other amendments are based on measures contained in the Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code. Principally, they empower the Minister to accept undertakings by governments of the exporting country to offset the effect of any subsidy and to impose retrospective countervailing duties. They also include additional criteria for determining the amount of subsidy in the case of goods exported from countries where the Government substantially influences prices.

No final decision on the question of Australia's accession to the GATT Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code has been announced. However, the proposed amendments are desirable in themselves. The Government is of the view that the amendments will strengthen the powers to protect Australian industry against any injurious effects of subsidised imports. The Bill also proposes further amendments designed to remedy deficiencies which have become apparent during administration of the Act since 1975. These amendments are technical and modify both dumping and countervailing provisions. They are expected to enhance the Government's ability to protect Australian industries against dumped or subsidised imports. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Customs Amendment (Securities) Bill 1981

This Bill is associated with the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1981. Its main purpose is to amend section 45 of the Customs Act 1901 to vary the time for which the Customs may retain securities taken for the purposes of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. The amendments are consistent with the provisions of the revised General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade Anti-Dumping Code and the GATT Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code. Both codes provide for the taking of securities as provisional measures pending finalisation of inquiries into allegations of injurious dumping and subsidisation. To conform with the Anti-Dumping Code the provisions of the Customs Act 1901 will need to be amended to allow securities to be held for a period of four months and for the period to be extended to six months if so requested by the exporter of the goods. For the Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code the period of retention is extended from three months to four months. I commend this Bill to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, might I just take this opportunity to explain the situation? Senator Evans spoke at the first reading stage of these Bills and I was seeking to inquire of other Opposition senators whether they wished to speak to the first reading motion. Apparently nobody was ready to speak at that time and when I rose I sought to answer Senator Evans's points raised during the first reading debate. I will seek now to do so during the second reading debate.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I was under the illusion when I came into the chamber that I was speaking at the second reading stage of these Bills, having been summoned at short notice because the Government's legislative program apparently is in such a shambles in the other place that the Bills which were expected to be introduced and to occupy five minutes of our time after dinner were not in fact introduced. I came into the chamber with people screaming that this was the occasion for a magnum opus to be performed on the subject of anti-dumping, so perform I did. I do not think I will trespass on the patience of my colleagues on either side of the chamber to repeat the speech I have made, but I simply ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) to treat it as a second reading response on my part and on the part of the Opposition and to respond accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I wish to answer just one or two points that Senator Evans has made. I think he would agree that it would be very important for the Government to have its legislative framework in shape before it completes its negotiations in respect of the anti-dumping code. Consequently, this line of action has been proposed. As to when this matter will be finally determined, I think that is a matter for the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) and no doubt he will keep us advised from time to time as to the progress of it. I thank the Opposition for its support of the legislation and wish the Bills a speedy passage.

There was a lot of confusion tonight because there were about four Bills listed on the Notice Paper to come before this place before we got to the first reading stage of these Bills. As I say, this causes a lot of confusion and, as we have now witnessed, even the Minister in charge of these Bills has made the comment that it is time the Government got its house in order. I agree with him. If we want to run this place smoothly, the Government should at least give those on this side of the chamber some advice as to what it intends to do. It should not be the case that at eight o'clock in this chamber when the Bells are ringing nobody knows what the Government is going to do because there has been a change in the program. We saw the same thing happen last week because of confusion as to what was going to happen. Surely that should have been a lesson to the Government and the position should not be allowed to continue.
