PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Petroleum (Submerged Lands-Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill and one associated Bill amend the legislation passed last year and the original Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act of 1967. The most important provision of tonight's amending Bill is that it extends the area covered by that legislation to include the Coral Sea. It also corrects an abundance of trivial errors in the 1980 amending Act. I observe that it is a pity it does not correct the fundamental error in the 1980 Act, that is, that the legislation was ever introduced or passed. The Minerals (Submerged Lands) Bill extends the arrangements provided for the exploitation of petroleum within the 200-mile zone by the 1980 Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Acts to all other minerals. The most important provisions of the 1980 Acts, so far as petroleum is concerned, are extended by this package of legislation to include the Coral Sea which in the minerals Bills apply the same administrative arrangements for the exploitation of undersea minerals other than petroleum. The basic provision of those 1980 Bills was to cede to the States authority within the 3-mile zone and to delegate to the States, as a designated authority pursuant to the 1967 Act, administrative control over the area between 3 miles and 200 miles of the low water mark. This provision was extended further by these Bills to include the Coral Sea as well as the 200-mile exclusive economic zone. Joint authorities are to be set up under the legislation. The joint authorities are to be the adjacent State and the Commonwealth Minister, but the day to day administration of mining activities in the area will be taken over by State authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1973, the then Labor Government introduced the Seas and Submerged Lands Act, the intention of which was, firstly, to declare that the Commonwealth had constitutional authority beyond the low water mark and to the edge of the continental shelf, and, secondly, to lay down a code of exploration and mining on that continental shelf. Due to the opposition of the troglodytes who then had a majority in the Senate, the Government of the day deleted from its original intentions the establishment of a code to govern mining and restricted the legislation to the declaration of Commonwealth sovereignty over that area. That declaration was subsequently challenged by at least two State governments. The matter was settled by the High Court of Australia in 1975 which unanimously found that the Commonwealth had authority, that the States had never had authority from the low water mark and could not have authority. Total control rested with the Commonwealth. At least, more accurately I suppose one should say that the matter should have been settled by that unanimous declaration of the High Court.

Last year we witnessed a cowardly and irresponsible surrender of Commonwealth constitutional power to the petty megalomaniacs who abound in State parliaments. The Fraser Government repudiated its constitutional duty. It succumbed to the strident demands of myopic and parochial State premiers, of whom Sir Charles Court and Mr J. Bjelke-Petersen are the prime examples. It succumbed to their strident demands, as it is accustomed to do. It is ironic that these Bills should be debated tonight when at Question Time earlier we heard Senator Carrick speaking at some length of the problems created by divided legal authority with respect to the Murray River and its tributaries. That problem which, at least while State governments maintain their present attitudes, is probably insoluble, was inherited. It is something for which the Commonwealth Parliament, although it is sometimes held to be politically responsible, is not historically responsible. It was an historical accident.

The problems which will be created by the off-shore legislation being debated tonight and that which was passed last year are, by contrast, the home-made problems of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). They are problems which will be removed, I hasten to add, at the first opportunity by a Labor government. Labor will accept its constitutional duty and will reassert Commonwealth authority from the low water mark to the 200-mile limit of the EEZ and also over the Coral Sea. In regard to the question of irony we have the example-a contemporary example-of the extraction of mineral royalties on land. This Government, as we know, as well as abdicating its constitutional responsibilities in regard to the continental shelf, some time ago also abdicated its political responsibilities and refused to consider or apply a resources rent tax, the purpose of which is to appropriate very substantially for the benefit of the citizens of Australia the economic rent which accrues to high quality and/or easily accessible mineral deposits.

Some of the States decided that they would move in to fill this taxing vacuum with de facto resource rent taxes. In Queensland the favoured de facto resource rent tax is railway freights greatly in excess of cost or of those which would apply in a competitive market. When questioned about this Senator Carrick said-in my view quite rightly; and I support him entirely-that, to the degree that the States imposed de facto resource rent taxes of that nature, their funds from Commonwealth sources would be reduced commensurately. I commend Senator Carrick for having expressed those sentiments. The more eccentric and megalomaniacal of the State Premiers responded with wild threats. All hope of rational policy receded beyond contemplation. The only gains which will accrue from that very unsatisfactory situation will be to foreign miners who will be able to play off State Premiers; perhaps, given the history of the 1960s with respect to Comalco, one should say, in some cases, pay off State Premiers.

The causes of that very unsatisfactory situation are twofold: Partly, they are as a result of the abdication of responsibility by the Commonwealth, manifest in its refusal to apply a resource rent tax, and partly, again an historical accident or perhaps one should say misfortune, the fact that legal control of the minerals on the mainland resides with the assorted State governments. But now, in contemplating the off-shore situation, because the Commonwealth has abdicated responsibility, the foundations have been laid for repeating offshore what has happened on-shore, and that is a fragmentation, an unacceptable inconsistency in the rules that apply and, perhaps worst of all, destructive competition between parochial State governments which will benefit only those who are seeking to exploit the resources, and increasingly they are foreign companies.

I wish to make a couple of other points before closing. I have not checked the second reading speech made here but certainly in the second reading speech in the House of Representatives the responsible Minister, Mr Anthony, said that no permits for exploration would be issued within 30 miles of the Great Barrier Reef. I note, as did Paul Keating in the House of Representatives, that there is no such assurance in the Bill. Even if the Statute Law Revision Bill 1981, which was introduced in the Senate last week and which seeks to give some guidance to the courts in the interpretation of legislation beyond that which is actually written into the legislation, is enacted I do not expect a reference in a second reading speech to the effect that no permit will be issued for exploration within 30 miles to have any legal validity. The statement does not appear in the Act and therefore there is absolutely no guarantee that that will be so. Likewise, I suggest there is equally little doubt that the great majority of Australians, including the great majority of Queenslanders, would be strongly opposed to the reef being jeopardised in that way. In fact, the only way in which the reef can be adequately protected is for the Commonwealth Government to accept its obligation to declare it a marine park.

The Opposition considered whether an attempt to amend any or all of these Bills would be justifiable and came to the conclusion that it would not because they were flawed beyond redemption. We will be opposing all of the Bills. I serve notice, as did Bill Hayden and Paul Keating in the House of Representatives, that a Labor government will get rid of these Bills and all of the associated Bills which were enacted last year just as soon as it can. It may do so through the Parliament or by way of a challenge to the High Court regarding the constitutional validity of the Act which transferred authority within the territorial sea, within the 3-mile limit, to the States. At the first opportunity, whether through the courts or through the Parliament, a Labor government will get rid of all the legislation before us tonight and all of the associated legislation that was passed in May of last year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Sen H.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are dealing with a group of Bills in a cognate debate. One of them, of course, is the Petroleum (Submerged Lands-Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1981; others deal with off-shore mining of minerals. There are two main areas in the Petroleum (Submerged Lands-Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill. One of them deals with the fact that, as has been mentioned by Senator Walsh, last year legislation was passed in this Parliament to give the States jurisdiction over the 3-mile territorial sea with regard to exploration for hydrocarbons. The Commonwealth's jurisdiction extended beyond the 3-mile limit to what was once known as the area of exploitability. This included the continental shelf. If Australia eventually decides to go to the 200-mile economic zone, that area would be covered by this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for mentioning this aspect in this legislation tonight is the fact that in the amending legislation of last year we dealt with the proposal that the States would amend their off-shore oil legislation. It has been decided since then that, because of constitutional requirements, it would be better if we were to amend the Federal legislation and the States were in turn to re-enact their legislation, not just amend it. That is the reason for the Bill we are dealing with tonight. Another area concerns extension into the area of the Coral Sea of exploration for hydrocarbons and, under the other Bills in the cognate debate, the exploration for and possible exploitation of minerals. One could go on and expand more on the aspect of the Coral Sea, but the only comment I would make is that it is sitting well out in the continental shelf of Australia and, with regard to both oil and minerals, one has already seen the situation on the north-western side of Australia where oil exploration has extended well out into the continental shelf and into the off-shore areas of Australia.

The Minerals (Submerged Lands) Bill is virtually a flow on from the previous Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Bill, which was introduced into this Parliament in 1967. Perhaps I should give a little history about the period when the Bill was introduced into this Parliament. At that time the matter of sovereignty over the off-shore areas of Australia had not been resolved. There was a grey area. The States were claiming that they had sovereign rights and that the continental shelf was a continuation of the land mass into the sea area. The Commonwealth was saying that it would have the right and authority over the waters beyond the 3-mile limit. The irony of the situation at that stage was that internationally Australia was recognised as a coastal state and as such the Federal Government of Australia was recognised by an international court of law as having authority in those off-shore areas. Of course, it was a highly contentious issue with six States and the Federal Government each claiming their rights in the off-shore areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was pretty clear, but you people made it confused.

—At that stage it had not even been legally decided who had what in that area. No claim could be made because there had not been a court decision on it. This had not been resolved. It was such a grey area that legislation regarding it was introduced in the six State Parliaments of Australia and in the Federal Parliament. In those parliaments it was identical legislation-what was then commonly known as mirror legislation. When it was introduced in this place strong criticism and genuine concern were expressed. Perhaps the most outspoken were former Senator Wright and a former member of the other place, Mr Bill Wentworth. I shall state some of their main grounds of criticism. Firstly, they said that since there were seven pieces of legislation, six originating in the States and one in the Federal Parliament, it would be very difficult ever to amend it. Secondly, they and other parliamentarians were gravely concerned that there was not enough Commonwealth responsibility for the overall administration of the off-shore areas in regard to the exploration for, and exploitation of, oil. The fact that oil had been found in Bass Strait had created a need for the legislation and there was about its consideration an element of urgency.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, because of these and other reasons, it was decided to establish a Senate select committee. That was done in late 1967. The Committee met first in January 1968 and among its members have been such illustrious senators-they are still in the Senate-as Senator Justin O'Byrne, Mr President himself and Senator Keeffe. I was also a member of the committee, as were many other senators who have now retired from the Parliament. The Committee sat over some three and a half years and took, as honourable senators will appreciate, great amounts of evidence. It brought down its report in 1971. The report included many conclusions and recommendations for the guidance of the Parliament. The major problem was still as to where the real authority in the off-shore lay. There had still been no legal inquiry, or High Court decision, regarding the matter.

In 1975 the High Court did reach a decision which spelt out clearly that the paramount authority lay with the Federal Government and extended from the low water mark. Nevertheless, because of co-operative federalism that had existed between the Federal Government and the six State governments, discussions were held with the Premiers as to how the overall situation might be resolved. It was decided that the States should have authority to the 3-mile limit, or area of the territorial sea, and that the Federal Government should have jurisdiction in the waters and on the sea bed beyond that limit. From those discussions emerged the amendment to the Seas and Submerged Lands Act which was introduced last year.

Therefore, the off-shore legislation has passed the test of time. In the off-shore areas exploration activity has increased. To my knowledge, in no area have grave problems been experienced. The State administrations have conducted the whole exercise in their areas in a most exemplary manner and to my knowledge the oil industry has expressed no genuine criticism or concern in regard to overall administration.

I realise that tonight the Opposition has referred to this legislation in strong terms. It has been concerned about, and highly critical of, the fact that the Federal Government has seen fit to continue to allow the States to possess authority to the 3-mile limit. Basically, it comes back to a difference in political philosophy concerning responsibilities. The Australian Labor Party has always sought centralised and total control in Canberra, whereas the Liberal Party has always worked for what it has called co-operative federalism, which involves the spreading of authority throughout the nation. That concept has been applied; that philosophy has continued to be held. One could continue on this subject and begin speaking about exploration and how it fell away as a result of Labor's term in office. That has been said so many times in this place that I do not intend to repeat it tonight. But I would emphasise that the basic differences that have produced the criticism and opposition tonight are related to differences in political philosophies regarding responsibility.

The Minerals (Submerged Lands) Bill, which relates to the off-shore mining of minerals, follows closely the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) legislation which has been in existence since 1967. That legislation did operate even though there was in existence a Senate committee with regard to its effectiveness. It had been introduced in the parliaments of Australia-I emphasise the word 'parliaments'-in 1967. Perhaps one of the big things to come out of the legislation last year is the fact that Commonwealth responsibility has flowed right down through the States themselves; the Commonwealth Minister himself is now regarded as responsible to the Federal Parliament in this matter. In the original legislation that provision did not exist.

As the Minister pointed out in the second reading speech, the Minerals (Submerged Lands) Bill has many facets. As I said of the off-shore oil legislation, which was amended last year and which it is proposed to amend again tonight, the Commonwealth legislation will apply beyond the 3-mile limit and the State legislation will apply out to that limit. There is a difference in regard to the mining of minerals. Because of the needs for efficient administration, underground mining which extends from the shore will be excluded. It will be controlled by State legislation. That demonstrates the sense of realism of the Government. In some cases coal mines are already in existence and extend well out beyond the low water mark in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —How far?

—I cannot give the honourable senator the details and it would be improper to make a wild guess. A mine shaft may not be out very far today but it may be one of these days. This legislation is not being made just for today. It is being made for the years ahead. This will be very effective legislation. Foresight dictates that the States, which have been operating efficiently in this area of activity, should continue without interference from the Federal Government. Again, as in the off-shore legislation, joint authorities will exist. The Minister for National Development and Energy in the Federal Parliament will work in conjunction with the Minister for Mines, or Minerals, Energy or whatever may be his designation in the particular State, in regard to all mining operations beyond the 3-mile territorial sea, or State area.

SPEECH.PARA: The important thing that comes through here is the fact that the Commonwealth Minister will have the final say in regard to any area in respect of which there is disagreement between the designated authorities, or, to put it in parliamentary language, between the two respective Ministers. This is a very important point. The Federal Parliament will still have the final responsibility. Firstly, the designated Federal Minister for National Development and Energy will be responsible to this Parliament. Even though he will work as part of a joint authority with the respective State Ministers, when it comes to any disagreement at all he will have the final say. The joint authorities will cover many major areas. They will deal with such things as the titles to be issued, the granting, refusal or transfer of licences, if any of the exploration companies are fortunate to find anything, and with any farm-ins. In fact, the overall administration of who will have licences or permits and how people will operate in those areas will come under the auspices of the joint authorities. But I emphasise again that the Federal Minister is the man who will have the final say if there is disagreement. So let us not have any criticism from the Opposition that this Parliament or Government are abrogating their responsibilities, because they certainly are not.

The overall day-to-day operations will be policed by the various State mines departments or whatever those departments may be called. That provision is identical to that in the off-shore petroleum legislation because, I repeat, that legislation has stood the test of time. I am delighted to see that we are following the same pattern of successful history with regard to mining of minerals in off-shore areas because, quite frankly, it would be farcical if a Federal government were to have its departments in each State as well as the States having their own departments, with a consequent duplication of administration and extra costs. So it is good to see the Government basing this legislation on previous legislation which, as I have said many times previously in this speech, has stood the test of time.

The overall administration of off-shore oil exploration in Australia-I am not talking about drilling success rates-stands second to none. When one looks at the problems of Canada and the United States of America, one sees that Australia stands way out in front in efficiency of operation and in co-operation and co-ordination between the Federal Parliament and the State parliaments. Although we came to the off-shore oil scene well after Canada and the United States of America, we possibly learned by their mistakes. I know that there are some in those countries who would like today to have the same legislation that we have in this country because of the efficiency of operation in Australia. One could go on to other areas and deal with such things as royalties. Again there is to be a sharing of royalties between the Commonwealth and the States. Of course, the States are entitled to their share. Administrative costs will be picked up by the States, but they will get income from licence fees, permit fees and other things to assist them with those costs.

In supporting this legislation, particularly the fact that it parallels and in many ways is identical to the off-shore petroleum legislation, I am pleased to see that the Federal Government is bringing in legislation dealing with the exploration and the possible exploitation of minerals in off-shore areas. As I said earlier in my speech, we had more or less to rush legislation through the Australian parliaments because oil had been found in Bass Strait and there was a need to get some uniformity in off-shore legislation in this country. This Government is preparing the way now for off-shore exploration for minerals and, we hope, for their exploitation. Of course, overseas a lot of work at present is being done with regard to seabed mining, including mining in deep and international waters. It is known that there are rich amounts of minerals in many areas of the seabed. One does not know the costs or many of the techniques with regard to exploitation of those minerals, but with the advances in technology these days we will no doubt see mining operations taking place in the off-shore areas in the not too distant future. Already two off-shore permits have been issued in New South Wales and one in Queensland.

No doubt when this legislation comes into force it will give a lot of confidence to many companies which will be prepared to do some exploration in the hope that they can be successful and can move into exploitation. This legislation will give those companies and this country confidence to move out into those areas. I hope that one of these days we, as a nation, will reap further rewards from the challenges that lie in the off-shore areas. I have much pleasure in supporting these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are very concerned at those aspects of this legislation which to our mind are virtually a blueprint for major disaster at some future time and which could effectively destroy the Great Barrier Reef as a natural asset, not for all time but perhaps for decades or even for centuries. There is no real guarantee that a major oil spill which affected the reef could ever be effectively cleaned up. I suggest that we are looking at that order of disaster. There has been a long battle on this question concerning the Great Barrier Reef. It seems to have recurred constantly in this decade. I refer to the necessity for conservationists and others, including members of this Parliament, to protect the Great Barrier Reef against the depredations of the Government, of State governments of a similar political complexion and of their financial backers. Basically that is what it amounts to. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume), in his second reading speech, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The opportunity is being taken in this Bill to extend the application of the off-shore petroleum legislation to the continental shelf in the Coral Sea area. This is one of the last areas of the Australian continental shelf virtually unexplored for petroleum. It is considered to be prospective and the petroleum industry has expressed keen interest in exploration there.

There the Government's motive is expressed-it wants to serve the petroleum industry. What the petroleum industry wants, the Government, by a knee jerk reaction, immediately does. It is like the old saying in the United States of America that what is good for the car industry is good for America. It did not really work out that way on the whole. But I think the theory of Liberal-Country Party governments in Australia is that what is good for the overseas multinational petroleum industry is good for Australia. I suggest that is something which not all of us are going to accept without a grain of salt. The Minister, later in the second reading speech, said:

In regard to the areas adjacent to the Great Barrier Reef region the Government is very mindful of its undertaking to protect the reef and it has therefore been decided that no commitment will be given to issue exploration permits within 30 miles of the reef . . .
We are expected to swallow that preposterous proposition as if we are school children, when the history of the last 20 or 30 years--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not 30 miles beyond the definition of the area proclaimed in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act, not just 30 miles beyond the reef?

—I have just quoted from the Minister's second reading speech. It was a precise quotation-'no commitment will be given to issue exploration permits within 30 miles of the reef'. Presumably the Minister knows what he is talking about. I suggest the honourable senator take the matter up with him if he wishes any further discussion on it. When we get a printed second reading speech here, I take it that what is in it is correct. I find it rather surprising for a Government senator to bring up the point that it might not be correct. However, I suggest that he take that up with the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: A little while ago Senator Young talked about political philosophy. If it is Liberal political philosophy to exploit, no matter what dangers there might be in the future, honourable senators are welcome to it. I suggest that the Government is being found out because the Australian public is now beginning to drop to it and to understand that, despite all its cosmetic operations and all its attempts to show itself as being different from what it is, it is being revealed as the creature of outside interests who manipulate it like a pawn. What it does rather than what is says is important, and this legislation is something which it proposes to implement. The Australian people will judge the Government on that and not on what it says. Senator Young in his speech also mentioned Commonwealth responsibility. He said that this Parliament has all sorts of powers and influences and can do all sorts of things. I ask him: If there were a blow-out similar to the one that occurred in the Gulf of Mexico when oil drifted many hundreds of kilometres and the spill was more than 100 kilometres in extent-some people say it was as much as 250 kilometres-what would we, sitting here, do about it? Of course, it would be too late. Whatever powers one has here would be of no help at all.

What could exist is a momentary situation in which a well that was drilled blew out and could not be capped. There would be nothing anybody on God's earth could do to stop the consequences, least of all those of us in this Parliament. I suggest that our job in this Parliament is to see that things such as that do not happen. We have powers to try to see that something does not happen which will be such an incredible disaster.
As I have said, this has been a long battle. I have no doubt it will continue to be a long battle. For us it started on 28 February 1979 when my colleague, Senator Chipp, moved:

That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment: Oil Exploration in the Great Barrier Reef area, including all the possible effects on any such exploration.

That reference was modified subsequently to be the inquiry on marine science of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment on which I have the honour to serve and whose inquiries are almost complete. It has some things to say about this area too. On 24 May 1979, the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, a man whom I respect, made a statement to the Press which:
gave an assurance that the Federal Government would not permit any activity which could in any way damage the Great Barrier Reef.

I would have thought that that was a clear enough statement. He said with no equivocation 'that the Federal Government would not permit any activity which could in any way damage the Great Barrier Reef'.

I will spend a little time reminding honourable senators of the uniqueness of the Great Barrier Reef and the extent of the responsibility which we have. It appears to me that the Government regularly forgets this. It may be under the influence of people in other parts of the world who probably regard the only land of any real asset as being land on which one can grow peanuts. That is evident from that State Premier's view of the land he gave away to Mr Iwasaki which he described as waste land but which I would describe as one of the most beautiful and interesting parts of the Australian coast. So honourable senators can see that we have a difficulty with people who may be well-intentioned but whose judgment is faulty on matters of this kind.

The Great Barrier Reef is the largest, most complex system of coral reefs ever to exist on the earth as far as we know. It is 1,900 kilometres long. Its total area is twice that of England. It consists of over 2,500 individual coral reefs, all of which are interconnected. It has been said by experts on it that so delicate is the interdependence of the ecology that one cannot destroy any large area of it without destroying the whole reef effectively. Between 1,000 and 2,000 species of fish live in the reef. Some turtles such as the leatherback and the green turtle are endangered species and are peculiar to the reef. The same applies to several species of birds found in that area.

At this stage, having established that we have on our hands something which is regarded by the world as being of the most vital importance and as a unique asset which cannot be replaced, I think we should look properly at the weather circumstances and the currents which operate in the area in which the Government now proposes to permit oil exploration. In winter the surface currents of the Coral Sea move generally from east to west and then move along the reef and the Queensland coast. That is nicely designed so that if ever the Government's scenario, which it is trying so hard to sell to us now, of allowing drilling for oil 40 miles or 50 miles off the reef comes to pass, there is no way, if there is a spill in those circumstances, that those currents will not carry that oil spill on to the reef. It would not only carry the oil to one part of the reef but also distribute it down the entire length of the reef. That is basically what we are talking about. Those are the winter currents.

In summer the surface currents move generally from north to south so that any oil slick in summer would move either on to the reef or down the Queensland and New South Wales coasts and even beyond the reef. I refer to air currents and winds. The Coral Sea area is subject to cyclonic weather which would spread an oil slick further and faster than could occur merely through the actions of surface currents. On-shore winds are common. So we have a situation in which, if an oil spill occurred, it would be very difficult indeed to halt it or do anything about it before it reached the coral areas. What would happen when it reached the coral areas? I had the advantage of being able to fly across the whole extent of the coral reef with my Committee during our current inquiry.

What impressed me more deeply than anything else was the tremendous inaccessability of most of the reefs. We flew for mile after mile over huge areas of shallow water. We saw reefs which are exposed at low tide and places into which one could not even get a rowing boat at low tide. I cannot think or have I read of any kind of device which could clean up an oil spill and which could be brought into that area once the oil was there. Once the oil got there it would be there to stay. That would be the consequences of what we would do. I will not take the time of the Senate unduly over this matter. I make one final point. I think honourable senators will find that the figures justify this statement. If there were a well blow out of Townsville of the size of the Ixtoc No. 1 well blow out off Campeche Bay, Mexico, in mid 1979, even if it occurred very much further out than the suggested limit of 30 miles from the reef, that oil slick would cover the reef completely from Cairns to Rockhampton.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Petroleum (Submerged Lands-Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1981. I make it quite clear at the outset that I have no intention of supporting the Bill because I am very concerned about the Great Barrier Reef and the Bill that will give the opportunity for people to do surveys off the Barrier Reef with the ultimate aim of drilling for oil.

SPEECH.PARA: I made a speech in this chamber on 22 May 1979 in a debate on an appropriation Bill when I spoke about this issue. At that time, I said:

Let us consider the Great Barrier Reef. It has some 2,500 islands. It has 60 to 70 sand cays. It extends for some 1,900 kilometres down the Coast of Queensland. It covers about 2,700 square kilometres, which is an area the size of England. I believe that we have had an example of the damage an oil spillage can do to the Barrier Reef.
At that time I was referring and I drew the attention of the Senate to the fact that on 4 March 1970 the oil tanker Oceanic Grandeur ran aground on the reef. My speech continued:
The oil spillage caused concern to Australians at that time and caused a great deal of damage.
It caused damage to many parts of the reef and to many industries which were concerned with the Great Barrier Reef. In my speech at that time I said:

Apart from the damage it did to the coral, to the fish and to other parts of the Barrier Reef, it had a devastating effect on the growing of pearl shells in the Torres Strait. Although I am told the the Prime Minister today has made a statement that there will be no drilling on the Reef, I ask: Just exactly what does that mean? Does it mean drilling actually on the coral? Is he talking about drilling through the coral? Is he talking about drilling alongside the coral or off the edge of the reef?

What was the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) actually talking about? Today we find what the Government is actually talking about. The Government is talking about drilling or allowing exploration off the Barrier Reef. Today I had some time in discussions with the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) who is responsible for this Bill. He told me that there will be a so-called buffer zone of some 30 miles or 45 kilometres off the Barrier Reef. I am still not satisfied that there will be protection of the Great Barrier Reef. To me the Great Barrier Reef is not just something of which the Australian people should be proud and about which the Australian people should be doing everything possible to ensure its preservation. I believe, as I said in my speech on 22 May 1979, that the Barrier Reef is not just a phenomenon ranked as one of the wonders of the world. We have the responsibility of being the custodians of the Great Barrier Reef. I believe that that is a tremendous responsibility for the Australian people. The reef does not belong to the Australian people. It does not belong to any single person or identity. It belongs to the world. I repeat: It is one of the wonders of the world. We have a tremendous responsibility because we are the custodians of that wonder of the world.

Today we are debating a Bill that could have tremendous effects on the Great Barrier Reef. I am not convinced, despite all the rhetoric that has been spoken, that the Government will ensure that oil spills or blowouts of wells 40 miles off the reef will have no effect on the reef. That is a lot of eyewash as far as I am concerned because oil travels. It floats on top of the sea for many miles. The Great Barrier Reef extends from the Cape York Peninsula to about Gladstone on the coast of Queensland. I do not need to tell you that, Mr Deputy President, because you are a Queenslander.

I am not convinced that the Government has taken the necessary steps to ensure that the reef will be protected. If one looks at what has happened in other parts of the world with oil spills and blowouts, one will see the damage that can be caused. It is all very well to say that no exploration or drilling will take place near the Great Barrier Reef and that there will be a zone of some 30 miles and, outside that zone, there will be another zone of 30 miles or 45 kilometres, whichever one likes to call it, so that we are looking at a total distance of about 60 miles. In looking at oil spills we have to take into account tide movements, winds and the other conditions that prevail at sea. I suppose that I would have as much experience, if not more experience, as any of the members of the Senate in diving and swimming in the Great Barrier Reef area. I have dived for shells and I know what the tides, the prevailing winds and other things can do in the area of the Great Barrier Reef. We are talking about putting up rigs and drilling, say, 60 miles off the Great Barrier Reef. What does that mean in actual terms? It means nothing. I wonder how many of the people in this chamber tonight realise and understand what happens on the north coast of Queensland. It has a cyclonic season. South-east winds blow in those areas. Let us assume for the moment that a rig is drilling for oil 60 miles off the Great Barrier Reef and it finds oil. That would be a great boon for Australia. But what would happen if a cyclone occurs the next day and it completely destroyed the rig and caused an oil blowout into the air? That oil must come down sometime. Where would it come down? It would come down on top of the water. What would happen to it? It would be carried by the tides or the winds, whatever the case may be. Where would it carry the oil? It would not carry it out to sea.

TALK.START.PARA: —It had better not carry it down to Tasmania.

—No, it will not carry it down to Tasmania. That is too far down. It would carry it to shore, over the coral reefs, and destroy one of the great wonders of the world. This concerns me. I know that there are many people-not only Queenslanders but also New South Welshmen, Victorians, South Australians and Western Australians as well as people from all over the world-who are concerned at the possibility of the destruction of one of the great wonders of the world, the Great Barrier Reef. It happens to be off the shores of our great continent, but it is not just our property; it is the property of the world. I believe that we are only the custodians of it. I want to quote an example of what happened in another part of the world. I am sorry if I do not pronounce some of these words correctly. That may be due to my ethnic background. I quote from a letter from the Australian Littoral Society of 26 May 1981, which states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The Ixtoc No. 1 well blow-out off Campeche Bay, Mexico released an oil slick that travelled at least 1,125 km across the Gulf of Mexico and caused pollution problems along the Texas coast of the United States. At one point in the nine month period before the well was finally capped on 23 March 1980, it was estimated that oil covered about 10 per cent of the surface of the Gulf of Mexico-that is about 185,000 square kilometres.

In all, at least 3.1 million barrels of oil spilled from the well. The semi-submersible Sedco 135 drilling rig was destroyed, and Mexico spent $US132 million on capping the well and attempting to contain the environmental damage, and lost $US87 million in oil revenue. Residents of Texas are seeking over $US250 million for damages. This well was drilling in only 50 metres of water.

It was drilling in only 50 metres of water. When I was in my prime in diving along the Great Barrier Reef for trochus shells and the like, I would probably have dived that distance with an aqualung or something like that. Yet here we have this kind of thing happening in only 50 metres of water. We are talking about drilling off the continental shelf, which is a greater depth, and yet we are told that there is no possibility of damage to the Great Barrier Reef. I do not believe that and I am not prepared to accept it. Therefore, I am speaking tonight strongly against the possibility of drilling for oil off the Great Barrier Reef. It is all very well for the Government to say: 'All we are doing at the moment is giving permission for people to investigate and conduct research in this area'. The Government cannot tell me that companies will put millions of dollars into exploration for oil and, after they have found oil, say: 'We are not going to drill. We do not want the millions of dollars worth of oil down there. We are only investigating. Now that we have found out, we are going to wait until someone says that it is safe to drill'. They will not say that at all. I know, as an Aborigine, that the almighty dollar is all important to the average person in this country, particularly to the people who will put these dollars into exploration. Once they have put that money into the exploration they will want their money back. If there is the possibility of finding oil down there, they will get it out. Whilst I have the greatest respect and admiration for the current Minister, with all due respect, he will not always be the responsible Minister. What truly worries me is what will happen with the next Minister, whether he be a Liberal, Labor or Democrat Minister. I do not give a continental damn about his party. I am concerned about the protection of the reef.

TALK.START.PARA: —As long as he is a Queenslander.

—In this case, I do not give a continental damn about that. I am concerned about the protection of the reef. I do not want to see any possibility arising of damage being done to one of the great wonders of the world. As I said earlier, the Government may claim that oil drilling may be allowed in the Coral Sea area without any risk of significant harm to the Great Barrier Reef. If this legislation is passed, many Australians, including the members of the Littoral Society, will regard it as a betrayal of the Government's promise not to allow any exploitation that could harm the reef until the results of both short and long term research are known.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been told that there have been all sorts of investigations into this matter but no one yet, not even the Minister, has been able to give me a total assurance that drilling outside the Barrier Reef will be safe. No one has been able to assure me that if we drill one mile, two miles, 10 miles or 100 miles off the reef and there is a blow-out, it can be contained. Technology has not yet reached that point at which I, the Australian people and the people of the world can be given an assurance that no matter what happens, if there is a blow-out or damage is done to the oil rig or anything else, we can protect the reef, we can stem the flow of oil. No one in this Parliament, including the Minister, can give me an absolute assurance that if there is drilling and oil is found, whether there is a blow-out, damage to the rig, to the pipes or to anything else the oil flow can be contained so that there will be no damage to the Great Barrier Reef. I do not care whether drilling takes place, 30 miles, 40 miles, 60 miles or 100 miles away from the Great Barrier Reef; if we are stupid enough and insensitive enough to allow drilling with the risks that can be incurred, we will not be living up to our responsibilities as the custodians of one of the greatest wonders of the world. Therefore, I speak tonight against this piece of legislation. I assure the Senate that even if I am the only person who votes against this Bill, so be it. All I say is that if honourable senators allow a rift to occur whereby one of the greatest wonders of the world is destroyed, it will be on their heads. They are responsible to the people of this Parliament and to the future generations not only of Australians but also of the people of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure Senator Bonner that he is not alone in opposing the legislation before the Senate. The Opposition is also opposed to the Bills. I wish to state quite clearly the number of reasons for our opposition to the Bills. Senator Bonner and other members of the chamber will realise that back in the late 1960s when we set up a Senate select committee to look at the off-shore petroleum resources in Australia, which committee sat for some three years, we went into very great detail on the possible dangers to the Great Barrier Reef if a hydrocarbon prospective area were found in the vicinity of the reef, and exploration and exploitation were to take place in the reef area. The Committee was unanimous in its opinion that this was one of the great dangers to the reef, that if we decided to explore in that area it was possible that irretrievable damage would be done to the reef.

SPEECH.PARA: I was amazed when the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) said recently that he felt that drilling in the Coral Sea outside the 30-kilometre boundary-he apparently set that arbitrarily-would cause no damage to the reef. That is, in fact, a fallacy. The tidal area in the Coral Sea extends well beyond 30 kilometres. It probably goes out to 150 kilometres or 200 kilometres. If oil were found in that area and there were a break in the pipeline or at the wellhead, damage could be done to the reef. Let us look back in history to when a major oil tanker was in trouble in the Torres Strait. We were told all sorts of stories by the government of the day to the effect that there would be no permanent damage. The pearl oyster industry in the strait was wrecked. It was wrecked not necessarily as a result of the oil spillage but it was certainly aggravated by the detergents used in the area in an effort to clear up the oil spillage. Today that industry has practically disappeared from the Torres Strait.

I refer to the hydrocarbon prospective areas. I suppose the Queensland Government is partly responsible for this legislation because in a deal that was made in the mirror legislation of the day, we took over an area in the Coral Sea in a direct swap with Papua New Guinea for areas south of the Papuan Gulf. This protected the Queensland Government because certain elements of the Queensland Government, including Cabinet Ministers and the Premier, had leases for exploration in the area north of Cape York. I think they believed at the time that this was the area in which oil would be found. A geologist, now retired, has told me that the Barrier Reef is probably not one of the best hydrocarbon prospective areas in Australia, nevertheless he has stated to me in a written document that without doubt there are probably large deposits of natural gas in the area, particularly in the Middle Reef area. Since then other geologists have apparently said that the Coral Sea area, the part to which this legislation refers, is a hydrocarbon prospective area.

I hope that no government in this country will be idiotic enough to believe what the Deputy Prime Minister of this country has said, and that is that we could drill within 30 kilometres of the reef and not damage it. That is not true in any circumstances, because of the way in which the tidal area operates in that part of the Coral Sea. That has been spelt out quite clearly in documents published privately and by governments. I see no reason why this government should knuckle under to the transnational companies, which would be absolutely delighted to obtain leasehold areas in that area for their own exploration purposes. But it is tied in with more than that. It is tied in with the reluctance of this Government to grasp the nettle and declare-we can do it under Commonwealth legislation-the whole of the Barrier Reef area a marine park. All we have done so far is to declare one small area a marine park. I note with some interest that at the weekend the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said that if the Queensland Government was not prepared to come to the party-he did not use precisely those words but the message was the same-the Commonwealth would use its own powers to declare the Barrier Reef a marine park.

TALK.START.PARA: —Piecemeal, of course.

—It will be done in a piecemeal fashion. Senator Bonner is dead right. The Government wants to do it in a piecemeal fashion, little bits at a time. We have one little piece. That is the only piece that has been declared a marine park. Every Queenslander and, I hope, every Australian will realise that the Great Barrier Reef is one of the unique wonders, if the not the main wonder, of the world. There is no other such area in any other part of the world. But the Government has been reluctant to declare the whole area a marine park. It is not at all necessary to say that we must declare it in zones. We can put a blanket cover on it and say: 'This is a marine park and as such it is protected against the exploiters of the marine resources of the area'. This would apply not only to minerals on the floor of the ocean. That aspect is very much in its early stages. Probably some of the best uranium deposits are to be found on the floor of the ocean. Certainly, a number of minerals are ready for harvesting. We do not want to see this sort of thing happen. Probably the prospective areas of the Great Barrier Reef can be exploited to the greatest commercial extent that the world search for minerals has seen.

SPEECH.PARA: I respectfully suggest that the whole of the Barrier Reef be declared a marine park and let us work out the zones later. We do not have to pick it off piece by piece or knuckle under to holy Joh because he and his numerous companies want to exploit the area. Those mining leases which are now frozen-they are still locked up in a safe somewhere in the Queensland Government system-are ready to go at the first opportunity. This legislation provides the first opportunity for exploration effort and exploitation effort in the areas thought to contain hydrocarbons.

Most honourable senators would realise that north Queensland, particularly on the east and west coast of Cape York Peninsula, is subjected to an average of up to eight cyclones a year. This year was an exception. In fact, this year the nearest we have been to a cyclone was last Wednesday and Thursday week when a low pressure influence off the coast of Townsville brought most unseasonable rain and winds. But that is not the norm. In most other years at least seven fairly destructive cyclones have hit that area and many of them originated in the Coral Sea and the Gulf of Carpentaria. So if a prospective well in the Coral Sea, even if it were 100 kilometres from the Barrier Reef, reached the producing stage, it is quite possible that a severe cyclone could rupture the pipelines and that would be the end of the Barrier Reef in that area.

Over 60 years ago a very rough cyclone off the coast of Mackay damaged the Barrier Reef to a very considerable extent. This has led to higher tides in that area than on the rest of the north Queensland coast. It is possible that that section of the Reef will never fully recover. It may recover, but we do not know what will happen in the next 100 years. But there will be no opportunity to save the Reef in the next 100 years if we are mad enough, at this stage in our political history, to allow drilling in the Coral Sea that close to the Reef. If those people who want to drill in the Coral Sea win, the next step would be to drill in the middle reef area and in a whole number of other prospective areas. If the Federal Government is responsible, it has a duty to ensure that the Reef is protected. It will not be acting responsibly if we pass this legislation which will allow a piecemeal operation to provide enough evidence that the Reef is a hydrocarbon area where possibly great profits can be obtained.

Let us look at this matter in the long term. Australia is not short of natural oil. Bass Strait provides some 70 per cent-together with the contribution from the Roma basin-of Australia's requirements of petroleum products. It is true that we do not have the heavier types of oil that we need and that we have to import all or most of them. But we do not know what the new finds will produce. There has been no public declaration of the quality of the oil coming from the new areas. We do not know what the North West Shelf will finally produce. We do know what Barrow Island produced. Probably one of the great sins of the Australian Government is that it allowed the Wapet company and other people associated with it to explore Barrow Island to the point where it became a public scandal. At that time a number of wells were allowed to be drilled in that area in order to put the type of subsidy that we pay on indigenous oil into their financial coffers.

It is well known in the geological world and in the world of oil exploration and exploitation that if we force indigenous oil out of the ground at a very fast rate, up to 40 per cent of the exploitable oil will be left behind. It is not a commercial operation to take the oil out of the ground after water and gas pressures have been used to bring oil to the surface. That is what happened at Barrow Island. I am not sure whether it is not happening in Bass Strait, but at the moment there is no written evidence which enables me to make a conclusive decision on the matter. If we do find oil in this area, it is almost certain-because of the general weather conditions, the possibility of cyclones, et cetera-that there will be an attempt to get as much oil as possible in the quickest possible time in a world that is hungry for fossil fuels. We will probably exploit wells in that area at well beyond their capacity to produce.

I suggest that if we allow the Bill to pass this chamber in its current form, we will sell our posterity, we will not be fair dinkum in our attempt to subscribe to the policy of preservation of hydrocarbon fuels and most of all-it is the greatest damage that we can do-we will possibly destroy the Barrier Reef. Following in the wake of the destruction of the Barrier Reef will be a change in the tidal patterns on the whole coast of north Queensland. It is possible that where we now have industrial plants and many residential areas, the increase in the height of tides will be sufficient to be totally destructive. We know what a cyclone can do in terms of tidal surges. That was emphasised to a degree by both Cyclone Tracy and Cyclone Althea. On both those occasions the tide was nearly at its lowest ebb.

The tidal surge from Cyclone Althea which hit some northern suburbs of Townsville was as high as 28 feet. It was never lower than 10 feet and that was at low tide. Some people have said that the highest tidal surge ever known was at Bathurst Bay. The tidal surge measured approximately 40 feet under the old imperial measurement and cost the lives of some 300 people. But only a few of those were counted as lost because the rest were black and in those days nobody counted the number of black people killed. So the published figures show only a few white people being killed on that mission. The rest were Aboriginal people. Nevertheless, the death toll was in the vicinity of 300 people. Only three people died as a result of Cyclone Althea but 329 people received hospital treatment. In the case of Cyclone Tracy, more than 50 people lost their lives and a very large number of people were injured. If a cyclone of the magnitude of Tracy or Althea were to strike an area where oil exploration or hydrocarbon exploitation were carried out, there is no way in the world that the flow of oil from ruptured pipes could be prevented from reaching the Barrier Reef and ultimately the coast. So if we are wise people, interested in the preservation of our greatest natural asset, all of us will oppose this Bill. I hope that that applies to honourable senators on both sides of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it eight pieces of legislation, all of which relate to seas and submerged lands issues. Two relate to petroleum and the other six are new-type legislation relating to minerals. They provide for minerals a similar set of circumstances to that which is being introduced for petroleum. The petroleum measure seeks to do two things: It seeks to tidy up a number of anomalies which have emerged in the 1980 legislation arising out of our need to work with the States to gain joint co-operation and it seeks to define an area of the Coral Sea for possible exploration. Of the minerals Bills, the main Bill, that is, the Minerals (Submerged Lands) Bill is supported by a Minerals (Submerged Lands) (Royalty) Bill, a Minerals (Submerged Lands) (Production Permit Fees) Bill, a Minerals (Submerged Lands) (Production Licence Fees) Bill, and a Minerals (Submerged Lands) (Registration Fees) Bill. Those six Bills seek to do for minerals off-shore in submerged lands what has happened to petroleum. It is well to remind the Senate that in the past, and particularly in 1967, arrangements were made by Liberal governments of the time with the States for certain State responsibilities. In 1974, the High Court gave a ruling indicating that the powers of the Commonwealth extended from the low water mark. Nevertheless, this Liberal Government indicated that it believed that it was sensible, on a continent of this size and on a continent which operates with one Commonwealth Parliament and six State parliaments, to have joint co-operation to get both the petroleum and minerals exploration and development effectively under way. The Government obviously had before it quite clearly that State governments in the past had dealt with the main problems off-shore of their States. It was quite clear also that they had both the administrative capacity and a considerable expertise and therefore, even though the constitutional power lay quite clearly at low water mark and outwards for the Commonwealth, an arrangement was made whereby the States would operate in the territorial seas beyond that out to the continental shelf. While the Commonwealth itself would have the authority, the administration would be done by the States. There would be a designated authority, being the States and a joint authority, being the Commonwealth. Therefore, what we have before us tonight, in terms of petroleum, is the need to do some tidying up and the need for a Coral Sea definition and, in terms of minerals, a mirroring, virtually, of the petroleum provisions, with, as I think Senator Young pointed out, the States having the right to underground tunnelling and mining but with the Commonwealth nevertheless sharing the royalties from that. So, it is quite clear that the minerals legislation follows the pattern of the petroleum legislation in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate tonight has tended not to concentrate on some six of the Bills or upon part of the petroleum Bills but to look--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is because we want to save the Barrier Reef and you are prepared to sell it.

—That kind of argument by cliche gets tiring even for the parrot on occasions. Let us put aside cliches. I simply direct myself to a very simple situation. It is this Government which has brought down legislation for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. If, indeed, wisdom had been with the others, with the noisy ones in the past, why was all this legislation not introduced when they had the power, the authority, to do so but in fact did not?
—Because the High Court judgment hadn't been given.

—There is a suggestion that they did not know of the High Court judgment. The Whitlam Government asserted that it had the authority. The then Attorney-General, standing in this chamber, asserted that his Government had the authority. It could have acted on that assertion. That Attorney-General quite frequently asserted that the Government should bring down legislation and then have it tested if it so wished. The fact is that my Government has acted to define a Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. It has looked at and put under study--

—Mr President, I take a point of order. The Minister is totally distorting the whole story. I think there must be a relevant Standing Order which provides for the fact that policy should not be distorted in the way in which the Minister is so doing. It is true that certain things were done in the Whitlam years. It is equally true that the then Opposition, the present Government, consistently blocked all the legislation that the Whitlam Government attempted to get through the Parliament at the time to protect the Barrier Reef. I object to the Minister's remarks.
—There is no point of order.
—The fact is that this Government has made it abundantly clear that it will protect the Great Barrier Reef in all aspects of that reef.
—The 30 kilometres-you don't even know what you are talking about.

—The report of the royal commission is available for honourable senators to read. The chairman of the royal commission said that there should be no further exploration for petroleum in the Great Barrier Reef region and that there should be no renewal of petroleum exploration permits in the region until the results of both the short and long term research are known. This Government has not only accepted that without question but also has gone further. We have said that we will allow nothing to happen to the Barrier Reef or in the Barrier Reef Region which will in any way damage the Barrier Reef.
—Why don't you get Mr Anthony to say that?
—But you have not defined the region.

—If all honourable senators would pay attention and listen as I did when they were speaking, we might be able to get some understanding of this situation. The fact is that this Government is quite emphatic that nowhere at all beyond the boundaries of the adjacent area will it in any way allow anything to happen which will damage the Barrier Reef. Let me define this situation. There is a region which provides a 48-kilometre buffer around the reef. Beyond that is an adjacent area which extends into the Coral Sea and the definition of that area is contained in one of the Bills. It is not to be presumed that, simply because an area is defined, there will be drilling or an open season in those areas. The Commonwealth Government has said emphatically that it will not allow any action at all to be taken which will threaten the reef. Before any kind of drilling would be taken anywhere, there would be action under the Commonwealth environment impact legislation to insist that we had before us the best of all information. For that to happen we would have available to us the top ecologists of Australia and of the Australian Institute of Marine Science and all those who could come to us and say: 'If you do this, you will do damage'. So, quite clearly, the test would be one to each area and that applies whether it is on the edge of the adjacent area or further out. The Government is second to none on this matter. It is a form of intellectual arrogance that believes that one person has a monopoly on the right to protect the reef. Everyone in the Govenrment wants to protect the reef. If one looks at the Bill one will see quite clearly indeed that the Government has said that. There has been some suggestion that a State government might do this or that. Let me make it abundantly clear that it cannot do so.
—Of course it will. You are scared stiff.

—Mr President, I am grateful for the help. It reveals the lack of understanding. The fact of the matter is that there is a designated authority, the State; but the joint authority, the Commonwealth Government, has an overriding decision, a final decision, and nothing can be done unless the joint authority, the Commonwealth Government, says so. The Commonwealth Government gives a clear undertaking that it will never do anything to harm the Great Barrier Reef, whether it is done 48 kilometres or 100 kilometres off-shore. Let me make that clear. That point is to be understood because in that undertaking the Commonwealth Government will not universally approve permits or drilling unless an environmental impact statement, compiled with the best scientific knowledge there is, states that the drilling could proceed. Within that context the government has acted in the best interests of the royal commission. It has acted on the best advice available. I give an unqualified assurance to the Senate in the same terms as the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) gave. The Government will do nothing, either on the Great Barrier Reef or in any region adjacent to the reef, which in any way will harm the reef. That region has no limit to its extension. If in fact it is shown by any action at all, by any environmental impact study, by the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics or by any scientist that harm will occur, we will take no action. We will protect the reef. I want to make that abundantly clear. With that statement and with that knowledge, I commend the package of Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am shocked at the reply to the debate by the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick). It is a well known fact that his Government said in 1975-76 that it would reach the stage at which the Great Barrier Reef would be declared a marine park--
—We gave leave to the honourable senator, but the honourable senator knows the forms of the House. I thought he wished to make some statement outside those forms.
—A personal explanation.

—Yes, Mr President, a personal explanation. In fact the honourable senator has his opportunities. He not only has them but also had them. In no way do I wish to stop debate in this place, but I think, in fairness to us all, that we ought to abide by the rules.
—Senator Carrick, what you said is quite correct. Senator Keeffe, I thought you had a personal explanation to make. You have spoken to the Bill. You cannot speak a second time.
—Mr President, the Minister had a right to object when I sought leave to make a statement. I am now speaking to a point of order. There was no objection from the Government benches--
—Senator Keeffe, what is your point of order?
—There was no objection from the Government benches to my making a brief statement. When the Minister found out--
—Wait a minute, Senator Keeffe. What is your point of order?
—I propose to make the statement anyway.
—You will not do that without permission.
—What I say now is that the Minister has sold out the Great Barrier Reef.
—Order!
—He has refused--
—Order!
—His Government has refused to make it a marine park.
—Order! Please be seated, Senator Keeffe.
—And now has sold out the rest of it.
—Order!
—If I may speak, my point is that leave was granted irrespective--
—Senator Georges, unless you raise a point of order, I cannot hear you.
—It is a point of order.
—Senator Keeffe, in my opinion you sought leave to make a personal explanation. You cannot re-enter a debate in which you have taken part. That is my ruling on the matter you raised.
—As far as I am concerned, the Great Barrier Reef is to me and to every Queenslander, and ought to be to every Australian, a very valuable area.
—Order! Senator Keeffe, you are out of order.
—He is telling us he is going to sell it to the transnationals.
—Be seated! When I rise, you will be seated.

—Mr President, I wish to raise a point of order. My point of order is this: Leave was sought and granted. The rule of this chamber-I have seen this occur many times-is that when a debate is closed by someone seeking leave to continue his remarks later, and that should be the end of the matter, leave is sought to make a statement and leave is granted.
—Not this time.

—In this instance leave was sought and granted. The Senate granted leave to Senator Keeffe without asking Senator Keeffe what he intended to do. It gave Senator Keeffe leave. The point of order I am making is that leave was granted. It was not conditional leave; that is, that he should do anything else, such as make a personal explanation. He sought leave. In this place we have freely been giving leave, sometimes contrary to the intention of the Standing Orders. In this case it may have been contrary to the intention; nevertheless leave was granted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Georges, I admire your intention and your endeavour, but the fact is that under Standing Order 410 a senator, having spoken to a second reading speech, as did Senator Keeffe, may rise to make a personal explanation. That was what I thought he would do in the full knowledge that the honourable senator would have known of that. That completes the matter.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.

DIVISION.DATA.PARA: The President-Senator the Hon.Sir Condor Laucke

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise in the Committee stage some of the objections that I raised earlier tonight when apparently it was not quite the right thing to do. I say now that I was shocked at the reply of the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) to the debate. I am shocked at the contents of the Bills. I am amazed that a Government which said four or five years ago that it was prepared to declare the whole of the Great Barrier Reef a marine national park has failed to do just that. The Government has declared one tiny piece of the reef as a marine park, but it has failed to do anything about the rest of it. I know that a joint committee has been formed with the Queensland Government. The Queensland Government refuses to meet with the Commonwealth representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said at the weekend that if necessary the Government would use the Commonwealth authority to declare the area a marine park. The Government has done nothing about the matter. It has no intention of doing anything about the reef because it lives in craven fear of the Premier of Queensland and everything he stands for. The Government has repudiated not only the marine park but also its obligation under the 1967 legislation to the Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders of this country. It has repudiated its promises on Medibank and on a whole lot of other issues. I do not want to go into all the details because it would lead to a very lengthy debate in this chamber.

We will soon get an omnibus Bill setting out all the razor gang's recommendations. I mention what we saw in King's Hall today. I never want to see again in my lifetime the brutality demonstrated by this Government. It threw out defenceless women and kids from King's Hall into pouring rain without any thought for anything except its own political skin. This followed the events of the last few days where the leader of the Liberal Party in New South Wales was deposed from office in a most ignominious ceremony and where the respected Premier of a State was thrown out because big business said he had to go. Let me tell the Committee that a gentleman, Mr Smith, on the weekend prior to his resignation from the Victorian Cabinet had discussions with the Prime Minister of this country as to how they could bring about Hamer's downfall. That is the sort of thing that is going on. The whole thing is corrupt.

Tonight we are selling out to the transnational companies one of the greatest national assets this country has ever seen. I never thought I would see this Government, after all its promises, sell out to the transnational people and to the Premier whom they fear most, the Right Honourable Johannes Bjelke-Petersen.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not a right honourable. He is not entitled to that.
—I will take the right part off this title. I refer to the Honourable Johannes Bjelke-Petersen, a man who has a very dubious political history.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I wish to take a point of order.
—Now the Minister is jumping to his feet to defend his master. He is defending his master. Let him defend his master.

—I raise a point of order. Every honourable senator knows that it is a very severe breach of Standing Orders to reflect upon a member of this Parliament or another parliament, and to suggest that any member of this or another parliament has a very dubious history is offensive. I ask that the remark be withdrawn.

—I wish to speak on the same point of order. Senator Carrick should be the last person to raise such a point of order. I have in my desk many extracts from Hansard showing that while speaking on loans Bills he used more offensive words than that against members of the Whitlam Government. He accused the then Prime Minister and his Ministers of being corrupt, dishonest and deceitful. Senator Carrick ought to be the last person in this chamber to ask for a withdrawal of those words. He was the person who created the precedent of using such words in this chamber. If he persists with his point of order, I shall take the time of the Committee to read all of his remarks into the Hansard so that everybody will know that those on that side of the House, particularly the Leader of the Government in the Senate, are adept at using double standards. I suggest that he does not continue with his point of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

INTERJECT.PARA: No Senator shall use offensive words against either House of Parliament or any Member of such House, or of any House of a State Parliament . . .
The words used reflected on a member of a State parliament. I ask the honourable senator to withdraw those words.

—The honourable senator can speak to the point of order.

I think this is the most dangerous legislation, so far as Queenslanders are concerned, that has ever been brought into this Parliament. For all practical purposes it repudiates any promise the Fraser Government has ever made about the preservation of the Great Barrier Reef. I said in my party meeting about a week ago that the legislation was very dangerous. It represents a knuckling under by this Government not only to the gentleman I referred to in rather uncouth terms a while ago-I refer to the Premier of Queensland-and those who stand behind him but also a knuckling under to the transnational companies which want to exploit the area. Let us get over this charade of energy conservation, and particularly that of fossil fuels. There are companies in the world which are prepared to exploit the energy resources. We know of the sell-out over Rundle when Ministers of this Government told us what a magnificent show it was, and now the companies are not prepared to go ahead with the project. There are enough shale oil deposits around Queensland to provide a substantial portion--

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I was waiting, in fact very patiently, to see whether any reference would be made in the honourable senator's speech to the point of order. In fact, Senator Keeffe has been talking on entirely different subjects, not ones related to the point of order.
—My ruling is that, under Standing Order 418, the words used were offensive. The honourable senator may wish to rephrase them, but first I must ask him to withdraw them.

—I will withdraw nothing, because what I am stating is the truth. This Government cares nothing for what happens to the Great Barrier Reef or for what the trans-national companies are doing to the energy policy of this country. It cares nothing for all of the other matters that were dealt with in the razor gang report. I have no intention of withdrawing anything that I have said; it is all true.
—Do you want to be thrown out?
—If one is to be thrown out of this Parliament or reprimanded for--

—We know that Senator Lewis is not often here; it is easy enough for him to go home. On matters of principle, I have never withdrawn anything-even going back to the days of the Vietnam war. If this Government is ever going to be fair dinkum about anything--
—Your colleagues want you to withdraw.

—I have great friendship with all my colleagues but I still do my own thing. If one is to be honest, one must stand up and protest because everything that has been done about the Great Barrier Reef by this Government has been less than honest. We were told that the whole of the reef was to become a marine park. Legislation to that effect has been brought down but nothing has been done about it. This Government has sat back in total, craven fear--
—I raise a point of order. I do not think that Senator Keeffe properly understands your request, Mr Temporary Chairman.
—Of course he does.

—How about letting me speak? I do not think that the honourable senator has properly understood the request of the Temporary Chairman that he withdraw the word 'dubious' in reflecting upon the Premier of Queensland. I believe that, on reflection, he would comply and use another opportunity in a more substantive way to reflect upon members of the Queensland Parliament. There are many reasons why we should do so and many ways in which that could be done. I believe that, on reflection, the honourable senator would withdraw the word 'dubious' and continue his remarks. —I withdraw the word 'dubious' and replace it with the words 'doubtful value'. I have replaced it with two words, so you have twice the value for your money. That is true not only of this Bill but also of all of the other areas of activity of which I spoke earlier.
