We will have sold out more than 50 per cent-probably 70 per cent or 80 per cent-of Australians who have expressed a view in regard to the Great Barrier Reef. This Government is only interested in selling out the natural heritage of the Australian people because it is under the control of the trans-national companies and of a Government in Queensland which has sold its minerals and everything else that it can bargain with at basement prices. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could ask some relevant questions on the subject matter of this debate. I have listened to some of the remarks that have been made tonight and I certainly regret that I do not know more of the details of this Bill. Unfortunately, for reasons which I cannot understand, it has not been before the environment committee of our party. Thus, I have not had an opportunity to study its details. There are a number of associated Bills, the complete complexion of which escapes me. However, I wish to raise certain matters because the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick), in replying to the second reading debate, gave very strong undertakings that not only would there be no drilling on the reef but there would be none that would in any way damage the reef. That is very important because in recent days many of us have received a number of representations from many organisations that are concerned with the preservation of the environment and with the maintenance, in all respects, of the reef as a part of the world heritage. As one heard Senator Bonner speak tonight, one was greatly concerned and supportive of the matters that he brought forward. Our concern is that in no case can there be damage to the reef.

SPEECH.PARA: Among the representations that I have received has been a letter from Mr Edward Hegerl, the Director of the Australian Littoral Society, in which he states, among other things:

Because of prevailing winds and currents any oil spilled in the Coral Sea would be expected to move westward toward the Great Barrier Reef and would then, depending on the season and location of the spill, either be distributed northward or southward along and through the Reef system.

It has always been my understanding that there was great danger and that therefore there must be a considerable distance between any drilling and the reef before one can be sure that there will be no danger. I realise that many steps must be taken before drilling will occur in the area; that environmental impact statements, permits and so forth will be required. Also, I appreciate that the Minister and the Federal Government hold a considerable power under these arrangements, whereby they are designated as the controlling authority. Mr Hegerl's letter continues:

Mr Anthony has said in the Bill's second reading speech in the House that 'no commitment will be given to issue exploration permits within 30 miles of the Reef', suggesting that the Government believes that to allow drilling at some slightly greater distance will prevent harm to the Reef.

Obviously that is a different situation from what I understood the Minister to be giving us an undertaking about earlier tonight. As the Minister knows from a question I asked today, I am very anxious that all the areas of the marine park should be proclaimed as soon as possible. As I understood it, the Minister said-it seemed to me to be at least reasonably acceptable-that there was the reef, the marine park and then a buffer zone of 30 miles, and that it was beyond that zone that drilling was possible in the Coral Sea. That is very different from saying 'within 30 miles of the reef'. It would be very concerning if drilling were to be allowed within just 30 miles of some of the most magnificent reefs to be found anywhere in the world, particularly because of the currents. I would like to know which is right. Is the area that we are guaranteeing under this legislation to be 30 miles from the marine park and, therefore, outside that buffer zone, or is it to be just 30 miles beyond the reef? That is one thing I would like to know from the Minister.

The second thing I would like to know is: To what extent are inquiries and surveys being made which are not just dependent upon drilling taking place? Is it possible, in the present state of exploration, for there to be a spill? Therefore, is it possible for surveys of the currents to be made now, so that even before drilling or exploration goes on we know that there will be no danger in that operation-not just in the operation of actually taking the oil out but in the operation of exploring for oil? I would like to know from the Minister, before this debate finishes, which of those conclusions is true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am bemused by the 3-mile limit. I would like to get some understanding of the distances involved with regard to Queensland and the Great Barrier Reef. Great concern has been expressed here. I am pleased that it has been expressed because at one stage I thought that the debate would lead to a quick passage of the legislation without any references to the new and emerging danger to the area. What does the 3-mile limit mean with regard to Queensland waters and the waters of the Great Barrier Reef? Has anyone made any sort of estimate as to what will happen with the overlap that could occur? What distance from the main coastline of Queensland will the 3-mile limit take us to? It would be interesting to know how far State responsibility will now go. How far have we ceded responsibility to the State Government?

SPEECH.PARA: Some of us are still concerned that the State, having been given sovereignty in effect and having made a decision to do something under the rights ceded to it, would then be in a dominant position. The State would make a decision within the powers ceded to it and then the Commonwealth would have to impose-I hope it would still be able to do so-the rights of the people of Australia. It may seem idle to talk about this, but there are quite a number of islands and substantial reefs. Does the 3-mile limit surround those islands and reefs? I come back to the overlap. Could the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) let us know the answer? Of course, it is possible that he has taken that matter into consideration. But how far does the 3-mile limit go?

To save my getting up again, I would like to ask whether it is possible that a considerable amount of mineral exploitation other than that mentioned by Senator Young could take place. Could there be limestone mining on live sections of the Barrier Reef which have not been declared to be within the protected zone? How far out could that mining take place under State responsiblity without the Commonwealth being involved? All sorts of other aspects of mining could take place on the continental shelf. What protection has the reef from such activities? The reef is one ecosystem and to disturb one section of it would be to endanger the whole. If mining were allowed in one section under this legislation, the delicate balance of the reef would be seriously damaged. The reef is already under threat from a number of sources, including starfish, pollution from rivers, and depredations of man and tourism. The reef is under substantial threat. Any degrading of the reef and of the importance of the reef from an ecological point of view could lead to the destruction of the whole. That is my concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) said that, if research took place and oil were finally found on the Great Barrier Reef, the Government would have the final power to say whether mining or drilling shall take place. I am not prepared to accept that because the Government's track record in its use of reserve powers has been found lacking in recent times. In a referendum that was carried out in 1967 the Government was given power over the States if the States were to override the Commonwealth and carry out things that they believed they should carry out with respect to Aboriginal affairs. The Government has not been prepared to take on those States. I refer mainly to the States of Queensland and Western Australia. So I am not prepared to accept the Minister's assurance that the Government has the final power to say whether drilling shall take place on the Great Barrier Reef which could have the consequence of destroying the Barrier Reef. I am not prepared to accept the Minister's assurance that in this case the Government has that so-called reserve power to say whether mining or mineral development or drilling shall or shall not take place off the shores of the Great Barrier Reef. I will not accept that because the precedent has already been set. The Government was not prepared to accept the reserve power in relation to Aboriginal affairs given to it in the referendum which was carried in 1967.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to the various questions by taking the last point first. It is not a question of whether the Government would or would not act under the existing legislation. Nothing can happen until the joint authority, part of which is the Commonwealth Government, makes a positive decision that it shall happen. So any comparison with what may or may not have happened in relation to Aboriginal affairs is not pertinent. I make that absolutely and perfectly clear. The first thing that happens is that there is a designated authority. The designated authority has no authority until the joint authority has confirmed or rejected it. I will now proceed backwards. With regard to Senator Georges's questions, the fact is that there will be no ecological change in limestone or anything else because there will be no mining of any kind on the Great Barrier Reef or in the Great Barrier Reef region. I say emphatically and without qualification that there will be none at all. There will be no change to the ecology in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act the area of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park has been defined. If, indeed, part of what is considered to be the marine park should be within the 3-mile limit it will come under the management and authority of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and will not be under the influence of a State alone. So the Authority has that quite clear responsibility. The Commonwealth Government has made it abundantly clear that in no way at all will it alllow anything to happen which overrides its statement that nothing will be done to damage the Great Barrier Reef, whether on the reef or in any area adjacent to it. So the distances in themselves are irrelevant to that. That has been defined.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to Senator Missen's remarks. I shall mention two matters. Firstly, a number of surveys are going on. After the Wallace Royal Commission, a short term survey and a long term survey were set up. Nobody quite knows what the length of the short and long term surveys will be. The Australian Institute of Marine Science, which is a highly respected body, is carrying out a continuous survey of the whole ecology of the reef. It is supported by scientists around Australia. The fact of the matter is that that is not just a survey of the reef but a survey of the currents, the tides and the whole of the movement of flora and fauna throughout the whole general area. One must understand that the knowledge of the movements of the tides, the very threats, would be constantly before them.

Also, the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics, in order to help in this matter, is arranging seismic surveys-not so much to find oil or to find anything but to get an understanding of the geological strata that underlie the reef. We might get schisms, dangers or threats. To understand the whole matter there will be a step by step seismic survey. I have no doubt that it will also give some clues as to gas or oil, which are important to us for the very important reason that in many places around the world there are natural escapes of gas and oil. Therefore, we must know of these kinds of situations.

The reef is a very difficult thing to describe because it is not one composite body of coral polyps at all. It is a series of different things-of reefs and cays. There is, firstly, a general area one would call the reef, which includes a bit of buffer water around it and into it, to form the marine park, comes 48 kilometres of buffer, so that there is the marine park itself-the reef, tidied up into an area with 48 kilometres of water around it. I want to impress upon Senator Missen that in many ways it is irrelevant whether it is 48, 96 or 150 kilometres because wherever a project for drilling was suggested there would be, firstly, an environmental impact study. We are not relieved of the need for an environmental study by added distance. I think that perhaps that assurance should be kept clearly in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is still no buffer zone outside the marine park.

—Outside the marine park, no. There is an adjacent zone and theoretically it would be possible for someone to grant a drilling permit close to the border of that area. The practicability of that is that that would suffer an intense survey. There would be no way in which a State could act unilaterally. It would have to come to the Commonwealth. It would have to be part of government. It would have to be part of the scrutiny of both the Executive and the Parliament. I put it to Senator Missen that the fundamental situation is to realise that distance in itself does not really solve the matter, although it does buy a bit of time, as I think Senator Puplick said to me privately. I acknowledge that. It buys a bit of time. That would be taken into account by all these marine studies. They would know what would happen in tides and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat, in commending the Committee stage, that this Bill has the clear and emphatic understanding that this Government will do nothing-not just in a region but anywhere at all-which can be shown to be likely to cause any damage. So we are not talking about the region. We are talking about the whole of the ecological system, just as the Australian Institute of Marine Science is dealing on the reef with things that are starting to happen hundreds of miles away. So the whole of that ecological system is put under study. I put it to honourable senators that this Parliament and this Government would have the capacity to act pretty fast should there be an aberration on that. I commend the Bill to the Committee.

I hope that the people of Australia will realise that the people of Aurukun were certainly let down by this Government.
