SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The provisions of the Bill fall into two main parts and there are also some clauses which go to matters of a tidying up nature. The Bill seeks to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 to do the following: Firstly, provide a procedure whereby members of an organisation at a particular place of work may apply for, and the Commission order, a secret ballot in respect of industrial action in which they have been directed or requested to participate; secondly, provide for technical amendments to certain provisions of the Act to overcome some apparent shortcomings within the Act; and thirdly, provide for the appointment of members of the Commission to constitute the Industrial Appeals Tribunal of Christmas Island.

Obviously, the introduction of the right to call for a secret ballot is the major source of this Bill. The proposal for secret ballots was presented to the Australian people in the policy speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in September last year. It was also foreshadowed by the then Minister for Industrial Relations in a ministerial statement on 18 September 1980. Following consultations with the major employer and union councils in the National Labour Consultative Council, the Government is now in a position to proceed with the proposal. The Government would have presented the secret ballot proposals in the summer session last year, but in deference to the NLCC's wishes, it deferred this action to allow more time for the NLCC to consider the secret ballot proposal.

The secret ballot provisions of the Bill represent a further development of a major theme of policy which the Government has sought to implement over the years. They are policies which encourage the democratic control of industrial organisations by their members and strengthen the rights of individual unionists against the central authority of officials.

These provisions of the Bill represent the Government's response to frequent requests from members of organisations-and from the public-to have access to the ballot box either before industrial action is taken or during the course of such action.

The Government has carefully examined the various proposals which have been put to it and has concluded that what is in the Bill is a practical way of giving effect to the principle that opportunities should be available for people to express their own personal views on industrial activity. The logical and practical course to the Government appears to be to extend and modify the secret ballot provisions already contained in section 45 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

Many trade unions are administered in a manner consistent with democratic processes and they are run by conscientious, hard working officials. Some organisations become centralised in their decision making processes and they may fall out of touch with the aspirations and attitudes of their members. So there is a need for a safety valve-a mechanism by which the rank and file can express their attitudes upon a particular matter. Surely there can be no valid objection to this principle.

Section 45 allows the Commission to order a secret ballot of members where it thinks that the prevention or settlement of a dispute might be encouraged or assisted by finding out the views or attitudes of the members. The Bill will build on this. It will enable a prescribed minimum number of employees at a particular place of work who are members of an organisation which has called for the industrial action to apply to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for a secret ballot so that the views of the members at the place of work on whether or not they approve or want to participate in the industrial action can be ascertained. Two hundred and fifty of the members concerned at a place of work or a number equal to 5 per cent of them, whichever is the lesser, but no fewer than four, may make the application.

The Commission, constituted by a presidential member will be required to order the conduct of a ballot to indicate whether the members of the organisation concerned support particular industrial action involving them unless the Commission is satisfied that to do so would not encourage the cessation of industrial action. Alternatively, the Commission may order a wider ballot of all or some of the members generally under its existing powers in section 45 of the Act.

Unlike the existing secret ballot provisions, under which there is no review of the decision of the Commission, a refusal to order a place of work ballot must be reviewed automatically by the President of the Commission. Thus whilst there is a discretion given to the Commission it is designed so that the grant of a ballot will be the rule rather than the exception because it is primarily an aid to the exercise of the rights of individual members to express their views. In other words, it will be the primary duty of the Commission to order the ballot but a subsidiary discretion is given to the Commission in the context of its conciliation and arbitration power. Where a ballot is ordered, it will be a secret ballot officially conducted by the Industrial Registrar or the Australian Electoral Office.

The Commission will be required to have regard to the outcome of the ballot in any conciliation and arbitration proceedings before it that relate to or are connected with a matter subject to the ballot. Furthermore, and more importantly for an individual member, if the vote is against the industrial action all the members at that place of work are relieved of any obligation under the rules of an organisation to obey a direction or request to engage in or support the industrial action concerned, notwithstanding any rule or practice of the organisation or branch concerned.

This is an important new initiative in strengthening the individual rights of the membership of a union deciding as a collective group of employees at a particular place of work that they do not want to participate in industrial action directed or requested by the union's decision making body. What it means in practical terms is that a group of employees dissatisfied with a call for industrial action by union officials will have the right to dissent firmly placed in their own hands backed by the protection of the law. To take it one step further, the effect of this Bill, through the operation of proposed new section 45C, is that it would be unlawful for a union to impose or try to recover a fine under its rules against a member not participating in industrial action as a result of a ballot.

This is in addition to the existing provisions of section 188 which by sub-section (1) (d) and (e) allow an individual member not to join in industrial action by making it an offence for an organisation to impose, or threaten to impose, a penalty, forfeiture or disability of any kind upon a member of the organisation with the intent to coerce the member to join in industrial action. No ballot may be ordered where the industrial action is in contravention of a 'bans clause' inserted in an award pursuant to the Act. I might add that these provisions will be in addition to the existing right of an individual or organisation to seek the conduct of a secret ballot under the present section 45.

Persons who apply or propose to apply for a ballot, or have participated in a ballot or who act upon a ballot will have the protection available of sections 5 and 188 as amended by this Bill against victimisation, intimidation or coercion by the organisation of which they are a member or their employer. Honourable senators will recognise the several benefits of the proposed amendments: They give the employees at a particular place of work the right, under the protection of the law, to determine for themselves whether or not to participate in industrial action; the existence of the right to petition for a ballot will, when availed of, alert the Commission to the fact that support for the industrial action may not be unanimous; the Commission will be able to test the strength and depth of that feeling and take it into account in coming to a settlement of the dispute giving rise to the industrial action; the organisation itself will be made aware of the existence of any strong dissent from its call for industrial action and will consequently need to re-assess its objectives; the general public will be alerted to the true situation and may bring legitimate pressure to bear upon the organisation concerned to cease the industrial action.

I have described in broad outline the purposes and operation of the Bill and the importance of this new right to a secret ballot in the hands of the rank and file of an organisation. There are several matters of detail I would point out to the Senate: By new sub-section 45 (8) 'place of work' in relation to any group of employees of an employer is defined to include any place at which the employees included in that group are required to report, whether in person or by telephone or any other form of communication, for the purpose of being allocated work by the employer or for any other purpose connected with the carrying on of the business of the employer. Thus, the legislation operates for the benefit of employees at a readily identifiable location like a shop or factory, so that the employees there who do not want to take part in the industrial action directed or requested by the organisation to which they belong may petition for a ballot. It equally operates for the benefit of employees who do not stay in the one place in carrying out their work or do not work at a single identifiable location. Air hostesses, pilots, salesmen and saleswomen, timber workers and the like who are required to report to a place for or in connection with their work can likewise petition for a ballot as if the place at which they are required to report is their place of work.

New section 45 (3D) makes it clear that the applicants must all belong to the one organisation, and work for the same employer at the one place of work. This permits particular work groups to indicate their desire to opt out of industrial action. New sub-section 45 (3G) provides that only a presidential member will be able to consider an application for a ballot at a place of work. New sub-section 45 (3P) ensures that a ballot is confined to those members employed by the same employer at the one place of work who may petition for a ballot. New sub-section 45 (7) deems a direction or request to engage in industrial action that is made by a committee of management or by an officer or officers, or by a member or a group of members acting pursuant to the rules of the organisation or branch to be a direction or request of the organisation or branch concerned.

New sub-section 45 (8) is important because it extends the definition of 'industrial action' in sub-section 4 (1) of the Act, to the situation where industrial action occurs in connection with an industrial dispute before an award is made prescribing, wholly or partly, the terms and conditions of work affected by the industrial action. Industrial action, as here defined, also includes 'industrial action' as defined in sub-section 4 (1) and also means any action in connection with an industrial dispute that results in work being performed in a different manner than is customary, or in a restricted, limited or delayed way; and the performance, acceptance, or offering for work being banned, limited or restricted.

With respect to the amendment dealing with the Industrial Appeals Tribunal of Christmas Island, Clause 4 of the Bill inserts a new section 16A to provide the President with the power to designate members of the Commission to constitute the Industrial Appeals Tribunal of Christmas Island to hear and determine appeals from the Christmas Island Arbitrator. This proposed section will complement amendments to the Industrial Relations Ordinance 1976 of the Territory of Christmas Island which provide for the establishment, powers and functions of the Industrial Appeals Tribunal. Technical amendments are made by clause 5, clauses 10 to 15 inclusive and 17 of the Bill.

The then Minister for Industrial Relations in his statement on 18 September 1980, referred to the Government's objective of encouraging the formation of industry based unions. The creation of industry based unions is an established policy of both Government parties and the ACTU. Work has been done, in consultation with the NLCC, on amendments to the amalgamation provisions of the Act on the basis of a criteria of the community-of-interest of unions desiring amalgamation. However, the Government parties wish to consider the full implications of such a criteria for amalgamation and its relevance to meeting the objective of encouraging the formation of industry based unions before proceeding further with any such amendments.

The Government parties will be examining what other means might be available to achieving the formation of industry based unions and also, within that examination, the possibility and practicability of the formation of enterprise based unions as part of the concept of industry based unions. The Government will be doing this, Mr President, because of the belief that the general public wish to see a stronger movement towards industry based unions. The public see such industrial organisations as far preferable to the demarcation dispute-prone situations which so often wrack the great industries and the small businesses of this nation. Whilst the objectives are formidable ones, if something can be achieved in this direction, a significant service will have been done for the people of Australia. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1981. I begin by quoting from what is not necessarily the most reliable source, the Australian newspaper, of 20 November 1980, which mentions this legislation. The article by Malcolm Colless had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government was told by its senior advisers several months ago that legislation for secret union ballots, which it deferred on Tuesday, would be unworkable.
But despite getting a number of submissions detailing the major legal and industrial problems involved, Cabinet and party hardliners insisted the legislation should be pursued.
In fact, the proposed legislation became central to the government's industrial relations policy during the federal election campaign.

The article went on to record the speech by the penultimate Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Street, on 18 September 1980. The article in the Australian commented on the legislation and on the words used by Mr Peacock, the then Minister, who was opposed to the legislation. It had this to say:
To make matters worse for the Government, not only does the legislation have no support from the unions but employers have also shown no interest because they believe it will open up a can of worms.
For example, they point out there is no guarantee that rank and file employees moving for a secret ballot on a strike will not be victimised.
And if there was a split vote, would those favoring a return to work do so, and what about those who opposed this?

It then goes on to say that the legislation is open to manipulation. I referred to that article because it could have been written about any piece of industrial relations legislation introduced by the Fraser Government since it has been in office. What the article in the Australian is really saying is that the employers are not keen on the legislation and the unions are not keen on it, but it is another stunt by the Fraser Government in pursuit of some mythical political advantage. That has been a typical example of the industrial relations policy of this Government ever since it has been in office. If there is one particular area that can be singled out and which has not been well served by thoughtful policies which recognised the realities of industrial relations, it is that area to which I have referred.

This legislation is in a very real sense an example of the way that this Government conducts itself. A certain degree of contempt for the Australian people was displayed before the last election and contempt for the trade union movement and the principle of consultation and co-operation with trade unions. Just as in the case of the new health arrangements, the razor gang report, or the Government's approach to the freedom of information legislation, there was a lot of ideological sound and fury associated with it. But the realities are something of a different order. In terms of facing up to some of the hard questions of industrial relations, the legislation signifies nothing. I make the point at the beginning that there is a conspicuous absence in this Bill and there is an absence of legislation, which the Bill was designed to facilitate, such as union amalgamation where there is a community of interests. That is, with respect, one of the major issues in Australian industrial relations which this Government, because of a variety of ideological hang-ups, has never been prepared to tackle and that is the achievement of a more rationally structured trade union movement and in particular the need for industry based unions, where that is possible. The case for industry based unionism is overwhelming if we are to improve industrial relations in Australia. If the Government spent less time talking about what it is pleased to call 'small government' and if it spent less time talking about the size of the bureaucracy and the innate goodness of private enterprise, it might look at some of the facts of the industrial relations system and the perceived causes of strikes, for which plenty of information is available from the Bureau of Statistics and elsewhere.

One fact that the Government might look at is that there are only three countries in the Western world which maintained full employment through the 1970s. They were Norway, Sweden and Austria. They all happen to be countries with democratic socialist governments. They are all countries with healthier public sectors than the Australian public sector and more interesting and more important to this legislation, they are countries that have much more effective consultation and co-operation between the government and the trade unions than has existed in Australia for a very long time. They are all countries with industry-based unionism. I am not so naive as to say that it would be an easy task to change the basis of Australian trade unionism to industry based unionism in the foreseeable future, but there is scope for consideration of union amalgmations on the basis of the community of interest concept. On 18 September last year, prior to the last election, the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Street, had this to say:
If re-elected the Government would move to facilitate the amalgamation of trade unions.
He went on to say:

The new amalgamation provisions are yet another demonstration of how the Government is meeting its responsibility to provide an industrial relations framework which takes account of the views of the parties and meets their needs, while paying due regard to the public interest.
That was said on 18 September last year as part of the build-up to the election on 18 October. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in his policy speech for that election has this to say:
The Government proposes to . . . legislate to facilitate the amalgamation of unions where there is a 'community of interest'.

I repeat that he said the Government proposes to legislate to facilitate the amalgamation of unions where there is a community of interests. We were not told a lot of things in the course of the last election campaign. We were not told about the changes which were to be made to the film legislation. We were not told about the changes which are proposed to the broadcasting legislation. We were not told of any of those things, yet the respective Ministers seem to have devoted most of the last three months to dealing with these pieces of legislation in respect of which-if I can use the old-fashioned term-the Fraser Government had no mandate whatsoever. But it did have a mandate in relation to union amalgamations. It suited the Government, in the policy speech and in the context of the speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations on 18 September last year, to talk about the significance of union amalgamations because if it looks at the figures on the causes of industrial disturbances, for example, it will see that something in the order of 15 per cent of all identified industrial stoppages are attributed to demarcation disputes between unions. So in that context the Government was able to talk at the election about the importance of facilitating amalgamations where there is a community of interests. Now we are told by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner)-the third Minister in a year in this important and difficult area and the Minister least inclined to consult or co-operate with trade unions-that the Government parties wish to consider the full implications of the proposed legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that.
—I do not wish to speak to Senator Chipp as a new boy, but I remind him that he was not here at the time.
—No; I do not believe that the Government parties said that.

—That is what the Minister says. I hope the honourable senator is calling him a liar, not me. That is what he said. I sat here in 1975 and saw legislation providing for union amalgamations brought into this chamber three times. It was tossed out by honourable senators then sitting on this side of the House. We were told, in the context of the 1975 election, that the then Opposition was going to do something new and different about union amalgamations. It was going to do something on the basis of industry based unions. Mr Street was the then Minister and he gave a number of undertakings about that. This issue goes back to 1975, when there was a quite mindless rejection of union amalgamation legislation by the then Opposition. Here we are now, in 1981, having received a promise before the last election, in contradistinction to a whole set of other areas of government activity, that legislation relating to union amalgamation would be introduced and that it was a priority of the Government. The Minister now says that the Government parties want to consider the full implications of the legislation. Six years later, this Government is now thinking about the implications of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the legislation has already been prepared. It was said to be legislation seeking to give effect to a report of the National Labour Consultative Council. The National Labour Consultative Council is a creature of the Fraser Government. That Government created it. Over a year ago, the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Street, said of the National Labour Consultative Council and its work on union amalgamation:
This achievement shows that government, employers, unions can work together and produce tangible results for the benefit of each other and the community.
That was what Mr Street said about the work of the National Labour Consultative Council on union amalgamations.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a fair comment, too.

—Of course it was. I could not agree with it more. Governments, employers and unions can work together to produce tangible results. This is the sort of thing that we were promised by the then Leader of the Opposition in 1975 when he talked about industrial relations problems being solved by an attitude of mind, a willingness to work together. We have not seen much evidence of it in the last six years, except, perhaps, in that promise given before the last election. I say of Fraser Government legislation: 'Now you see it, now you don't'. We have had promises of union amalgamation legislation, with the Minister making a virtue of co-operation between unions, employers and government in relation to union amalgamations but the Government has done nothing about those promises. We are told that the Government parties wish to consider the full implications of the legislation, six years after they ought to have been considered. If they now want to consider the implications of union amalgamation legislation, what were they doing in 1975? Were they voting mindlessly against Labor Government legislation without considering the implications of the legislation? That is the implication of what is now being said.

SPEECH.PARA: Out of three years of hard work, the National Labour Consultative Council produced proposals agreed upon unanimously by all the participants-unions, employers and government representatives. That was the result of three years of hard work-not spectacular work, stunting work or work designed to influence the public in relation to the spooky sort of view on industrial relations which this Government propounds. It was the hard work of the three principal participants in industrial relations. That was before the election. 'Now you see it, now you don't', is all that can be said of Fraser Government legislation. We do not see anything now, except the Government's wish to examine the matter further. The one piece of constructive industrial relations legislation arrived at by agreement between the parties since this Government came to power, the one industrial relations measure which would have had the support of both employers and unions, has been shelved. The cost of that action to trade unions and to employers in terms of problems of demarcation and so on is very significant. For example, do not the unions covering the clothing trade, the boot trade, and the textile workers, in any terms in which this Government faces up to manufacturing industry in Australia, have a community of interest? What community of interest is being considered by the Government in delaying this legislation?

Instead of dealing with the question of amalgamation, this Bill contains provisions for secret ballots concerning strikes. The idea of secret ballots always sounds very good. The secret ballot, the stump jump plough and-I forget the third contribution but it was probably Gough Whitlam-are said to be the three major contributions of Australian civilisation to the Western world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you agree to trying a few in here now and again?
—Trying a few what?
—Secret ballots.

—As I have said, the idea of secret ballot legislation sounds very good. It is a popular theme in any discussion of what constitutes a democracy. However, in this area the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commision already has power to order a secret ballot to be taken when it believes that it could help prevent or settle an industrial dispute, which is the function of the Commision. When we realise that fact, the legislation begins to look a little like a stunt, a stunt which is premised on a principle which is at variance with the facts. This Government is completely captive to the view that the big bad shop stewards lead all strikes and that workers go out on strike reluctantly. It is not a view which is supported by any evidence here, in Great Britain, where some work has been done on this matter, or in the United States of America. Indeed, if we look at the terms of the legislation to which I wish to refer in a minute we see that the way in which it is structured is quite absurd. If one goes closer to the scene and looks at the idea more dispassionately, it again becomes less impressive. Sir John Moore, the President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, is on record as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Compulsory ballots for unions contemplating strikes would not be as effective as many people believed in reducing strikes.
He said that in January of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Gosford meat workers dispute proved that. They had a ballot and after six weeks they reaffirmed the decision to stay out.

—I accept the view of Sir John Moore, the President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and I accept the addendum added by my colleague Senator Mulvihill to that view. The fact is that the Arbitration Commission has failed to order ballots in most disputes-perhaps 99 per cent of them-which have come before it. Why is that so? It is because those who are near to industrial relations as an art form-if that can possibly be said about industrial relations-unlike this Government, know that strike ballots are not the panacea which this Government presumes them to be. For example, the report of the United Kingdom Royal Commission on Trade Unions and Employer Associations, the Donovan commission, said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is little justification in the available evidence for the view that workers are less likely to vote for strike action than their leaders; and findings from our workshop relations survey, already cited, confirmed this. Experience in the USA has been that strike ballots are overwhelmingly likely to go in favour of strike action. This is also the experience of Canada, where strike ballots are compulsory in the provinces of Alberta and British Columbia.

Let us look briefly at the facts in relation to the Australian situation, in particular one situation of current origin. On 27 May of this year members of the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association took a secret ballot on strike action. The cause of the dispute was not the manipulative, bellicose shop stewards we hear about from this Government. It was the intractability of the Government which has prevented management of Telecom Australia from negotiating with its employees-that is a matter of public record-many of whom are skilled tradesmen earning about $25 a week less than skilled tradesmen employed by the instrumentalities of the various State governments in Australia. Despite the fact that for over a year Telecom management has sought to negotiate with its employees, the union took a secret ballot. In New South Wales, 98 per cent of the members of the ATEA voted for strike action. In Australia overall, 96 per cent of the members of that very important union who are employed by Telecom voted for strike action. They voted for strike action because they had a documented grievance in relation to salaried relativities for skilled personnel. In spite of that, the Government went ahead with its amateurish stunts in relation to these matters. Admittedly the Bill is an improvement on some previous legislation and documents such as the razor gang's report in that nothing has been inked out on the last day. But it is full of practical problems and evidence of hasty approaches dictated by ideological prejudice rather than informed opinions.

Let me say, firstly, that the machinery for implementing the ballots is far too time consuming to be of any effect in a great many disputes. Honourable senators only have to look briefly at the Bill to see that. It is a time consuming and cumbersome procedure. A petition by a number of employees-250 members or 5 per cent of the union, whichever is the lesser-must be presented. There must be a hearing before presidential members of the Commission. If the Commission does not order a ballot, the President may, and arrangements to hold the ballot must then be made by the Australian Electoral Office or the Office of the Industrial Registrar. The ballot must be held and the results must be forwarded. At that stage a result about the intentions of the membership of that union in a particular place or at large must be achieved. In my view these provisions are logistically incapable of applying to a great many, probably most, strikes.

I draw the attention of honourable senators to one provision in this Bill which illustrates its absurdity. It says that after a ballot has been held the Commission must take account of the ballot result. All sorts of things can be done if employees vote against strike action. What happens where, as in the case of the Telecom union, 98 per cent of union members vote in favour of strike action? What does the Commission do when it takes account of the views of the membership of the union? How can the trade union officials, who represent those people, seriously negotiate a settlement of a strike when the Commission is under instruction to take account of the views of the members, 98 per cent of whom, in the example which I have cited, have voted in favour of industrial action? What will the poor old Arbitration Commission do then? I think it will run back to this Government for a bit of patch-up legislation because it will have no idea what to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —The parties may well have virtually reached a settlement.

—Of course they may have reached a settlement. All sorts of things could happen. There are procedures up to the time of the ballot result, for unlocking the parties and for unlocking the intentions if a settlement is reached but, after that, we are jammed. If honourable senators look at the definition of industrial action in this Bill, they will see that it is absolutely absurd. For example, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: 'Industrial action' means-(a) any action in connection with an industrial dispute, being-(i) the performance of work in a manner different from that in which it is customarily performed, or the adoption of a . . . restriction or limitation . . .

Industrial action means the performance of work in any manner different from the way in which it is customarily performed. I do not know how naive honourable senators on the Government side are, but if they seriously think that they can get a go-slow or a work-to-regulation in a plant as a result of an order from some mythical demonic union offiical into operation, I say to them that they are very naive, if not bonkers-for want of a better word. There is no way that a go-slow campaign can be effected in an industrial situation by order of a union official. It just cannot be done. We must have the co-operation of the employees concerned if there is to be an effective interruption of work as a result of working to regulations, a go-slow campaign, or whatever. The definition of 'industrial action' in the context of this Bill is quite absurd. So we get another farcical situation which is illustrated by a quick reference to the provisions of this Bill. The provisions of the Bill are logistically incapable of working. They will cause, as most Fraser industrial legislation has, more trouble than they are worth. They are based on an ideological commitment which displays an appalling ignorance of industrial relations. They are not based on the views of those people who are involved in industrial relations. Of course they show a complete naivety about the causes of strikes. Many minor strikes involve matters which are extremely volatile, quick to start and quick to finish, but which are not susceptible to the provisions of this sort of legislation.

Also there are all sorts of loose ends in the legislation. There is no provision for the sort of vexatious litigant type of people, employed in a small plant, who go to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission every fortnight to complain about some threatened industrial action. There are things in the legislation which could be a real problem, given the tactics of some extreme activist groups which operate within the union movement at present, indeed as always. Those problems are present in the legislation. There is absolutely no provision for dealing with the possibility of dramatically increasing the work load of the Arbitration Commission and the Electoral Office to absolutely no effect. The legislation ignores the very real possibility that it might more successfully promote the interests of pro-strike militants than help more conciliatory groups. It would do this by providing the opportunity for such people within a union to pre-empt and prejudice negotiations by securing a pro-strike ballot. If members of a union are locked into a pro-strike ballot there is less room, less manoeuvrability for conciliation and negotiation-the objects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. This would be all right if the Government were acting in blissful and stupid ignorance on its own, but it is not entirely doing that because it has had the advice of its advisers that these things are the achilles heel of this centipede of legislation. In fact it has 100 achilles heels. The Government has acted against that advice because it has other things in mind than the good government of this country.

A strike ballot having been held and the union members having voted in favour of strike action. Firstly, how do we develop the process of conciliation? Secondly, how do we unlock the strike once this monster has been launched on society not as a result of some hydra-headed union official but as a result of the decision of members of a union employed by a particular organisation? I would like to hear from the Minister or the Government spokesman how we unlock the problem when it has got to that situation. This Bill is one of a growing list of measures taken by this Government which are cheap ideological stunts, based on prejudices at the expense of a rational and thoughtful approach to questions of good government in this country. For that reason the Opposition opposes the Bill very strongly as we have done on other occasions in this place with respect to legislation which we have said at the time will not work and which demonstrably has not worked.

Ever since this Government has been in office there have been pre-election stunts about industrial relations, what an important issue it is in Australia and how the Government will fix it up. Honourable senators can cite the record anywhere they want regarding what has happened to industrial relations in this country. I will be delighted to hear if it proves the point in any way of all that rhetoric that we have had over many years about this Government's industrial relations policy. We strongly condemn the Bill not only for its stupidity and naivety but also for its intrinsic wrongness in the sense that the Government ought to know better because it has had better advice than it has displayed in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this Bill to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. (Quorum formed). This Act has been amended some 70 times since its enactment in 1904. That may sound extraordinary but, on the contrary, it is perfectly reasonable because we are a fluid society, we are a community in which changing circumstances and changing interests are constantly the way of life. The fact that an Act as important as one which endeavours to control and to set up the machinery for industrial relations should be amended on a great number of occasions is an indication of the responsible concern of the community in just that area.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button, who has just finished speaking on this Bill, claimed that it was little more than an ideological stunt. I do not believe that that sort of definition can stick in any way at all. It is quite the opposite of an ideological stunt; it is a genuine attempt by a government to implement a capacity for trade unionists, for workers in a place of work, to seek in privacy, through a postal vote, through a secret ballot, the consideration of their members referable to a certain line of industrial action on which they have been launched by the leadership of their union. Surely that is well short of an industrial stunt. I believe that the people of Australia would agree that that sort of provision-the capacity to seek as individuals and as groups of individuals, by secret ballot, the views of the membership on a proposed, often an instructed, industrial disruption-should be available to those members. That certainly is the objective of this amending legislation.

This is not a debate about trade unions or trade unionism. I believe there is no doubt that the position of trade unions and trade unionists in this country is recognised as basic to the development of the whole Australian circumstance. Rather, this is a debate about the sorts of individual freedoms that should be freely available to the membership of Australian trade unions. That, I believe, is the object of this legislation-to provide a real measure of freedom in coming to a decision on certain proposed industrial stands by way of secret ballot, by way of a private opportunity to express one's opinion.

The importance of industrial relations in this country does not need to be stressed. Indeed, it cannot be overstressed. I assume that every Australian recognises that the successful solution of the industrial relations problem is probably the most important single contribution that a government and the people whom that government represents could possibly achieve. The successful solution of industrial relations must surely be the objective of every genuine Australian. There was a time then I believed, looking at the bases and the derivatives of the institutions in this country, that maybe the Australian Labor Party could produce just that-an industrial relations situation in which we as a vast country, a vast community, could achieve our massive and exciting potential. Regrettably, that was not the case because the Australian Labor Party, when in government, failed very significantly to solve the industrial relations problems. We inherited a situation that was in real measure worse than the situation that exists today. It is the earnest endeavour of this Government to overcome those problems in the industrial relations area. This piece of legislation is one attempt to create an avenue, a machinery, for freedom of expression which may well contribute to the solution of the problems.

I am not naive enough and the Government is not naive enough to assume that any form of legislation, of itself, can necessarily solve any specific problem. The point I make is that unless we as a government, as a Parliament and as Australian people have the determination to make legislation before us work then, of course, that legislation will not contribute to the real solution of the problems that confront us. I would have hoped that the Parliament would have looked at this legislation and at what it attempts to do and admitted that it is not, as Senator Button quite rightly said, the panacea to all the problems and worries of industrial relations in Australia. Of course it is not. But it is a real attempt, a conscientious attempt, to provide machinery that may well improve those relations.

We should not imagine that this Government or any other government will produce some sort of infallible machinery of options and deterrents that will solve all the problems related to the industrial relations area. But we would be less than honest and less than determined if we failed to try and, indeed, failed to solve those problems, for the public itself, besides governments and besides parliaments, is earnestly concerned that we, as a people and as a government, come to grips with the problems that relate to industrial relations. To preserve the rights of the individual, to preserve and safeguard the public interest and to promote industrial peace must be the basic objective of a government in this country. The objective of this legislation is neither more nor less than a genuine attempt to preserve those very things and to establish in this country a real measure of industrial peace.

It is very easy to stand by and make some cynical reflection on what this legislation fails to do, but let us try to be constructive. Indeed it is a cynical reflection that not only is it the province of the political oppositions in this country and in this Parliament but also in some measure regrettably it seems to be the attitude of the media that, in the first place, these sorts of things have to be regarded as incapable of providing any form of solution. If society is to be convinced of this by headlines, speeches and oratory there will be no solution. It is in our own hands. My appeal would be to examine the legislation and to admit that it has within it a real measure of responsibility and that it is an attempt to give to the trade union movement another access to a capacity to seek a secret ballot and to make a decision in privacy relative to industrial action that very often is thrust upon members without the sort of total consideration that should realistically be necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even the employers are against it.

—The employers would, I am sure, be interested in the operation of this legislation. Senator Chipp's remark brings me back to my original statement when I suggested that no legislation of itself can be a total solution. But there is a real possibility that this could be and should be a forward step in providing the sort of total involvement of the workers or unionists-call them what you will-in this country in the solution of industrial relations problems.
—Why should they have total involvement when half the senators in here are asleep?

—I am not sure whether they are asleep. If they are, I am not sure whether that is a reflection on Senator Button or on me. Be that as it may. (Quorum formed). We must relate the prosperity of all Australians to the importance of compromise, discussion and industrial peace as a result of those two elements. Once again we have to create in this country a pride and a determination in our capacity to supply the goods. Today around the world there is in some measure a view of Australia as an unreliable supplier. That may well reflect on management and on unionists alike, but it is a circumstance of which we must be totally aware. We must rub it out of the context of Australia as a great international trader. It can only mitigate against everyone's interest in the long term. Consequently, all Australians have a very real involvement in the solutions to the problems about which we are talking tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall return very briefly to the Bill which seeks, as I have indicated, to create secret ballots on industrial action by certain groups of people-rank and file members of unions-in certain employment at certain work places. Of course, the Bill defines a work place and types of employment, and so it should. It has been criticised already in regard to the definition of these two elements. Whatever piece of legislation one provides there will be criticism of the definition. It is one of the most difficult areas. Indeed if definition was not so difficult there probably would be no lawyers in this chamber, and there certainly would be few, if any, in the rest of the community. I suppose it can be said that the fact that definition is attempted is courageous. The fact that it is there will create a continuing problem which we will never be without in whatever part of our economy we determine our emphasis.

The Bill before us involves a closer concern and involvement of the trade union movement in solving the problems. It seeks to avoid any form of coercion and intimidation in the determinations of people. Indeed it is a sad commentary on a free society that we should need to legislate in a manner that will make the avoidance of coercion very much simpler. It seems to me, as I said, a sad commentary that that sort of legislation is necessary, but so be it. It should encourage more people to be involved in the determinations of the problems that surround not only their employment but also the economic and social development of this great country. Since 1928 the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has had the power to order a secret ballot but it has done so on very few occasions-five or six, I think. This is a step forward because it moves away from the Commission the sole power to order a secret ballot insofar as it gives to the membership of unions, in appropriate numbers-250 or 5 per cent as long as the number is greater than four--

TALK.START.PARA: —At a certain place of employment.

—At a certain place of employment and in a certain industry, and it defines those matters. It gives to them the opportunity to seek a free and secret revelation of their view of industrial action. That, unquestionably, must be a step forward in the industrial relations atmosphere of this country. I do not choose to go through the detailed administrative features of this Bill. I think that is unnecessary. I have chosen to make the point of the extreme importance of the industrial relations field. I have chosen to indicate that what is happening is not extraordinary; on the contrary, these pieces of legislation should be amended on numerous occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than go into the detail of the administrative technicalities of the Bill, let me conclude my remarks with one or two references to the matters that were brought forward by Senator Button when he opened for the Opposition in this debate. He devoted very little time to the question of whether a secret ballot was a reasonable, proper and effective instrument for the membership. He seemed to concern himself with the absence in the legislation of propositions for amalgamation of trade unions.

Of course, we are concerned that amalgamation provisions should be legislated for. It is an area of immense width which needs the ultimate of consideration. If by amalgamation we merely make it easier for one trade union to take over another and if we merely make it easier mechanically for trade unions to become monolithic giants in our society, we may not be serving thoroughly the interests of a whole range of trade unions which historically have grown from the craft unions and which historically are dependent for their pride and effectiveness on their size which may not be great. Consequently, I believe that before amalgamation decisions are made and provisions are brought into this chamber, we have to examine in great depth and at great width all those matters which contribute to the ultimate amalgamation of trade unions.
Senator Button mentioned the value of industry unions. Of course, the Government is involved in an examination of this area to the nth degree.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it has been for years.

—Indeed, the examination has taken six years. Industry unions are an interesting concept, and they appeal to Senator Button, I imagine, because of the difficulty of defining community of interest. Senator Button said that community of interest relates obviously to the textile and clothing trade. I assume that those trades would equally be concerned with transport, fuel, energy, retail aspects and advertising. Where is the community of interest? These are the problems that a responsible government has to examine in co-operation, I hope, with the trade union movement. It is our intention so to do. I have outlined the provisions of this legislation. I believe it is a constructive contribution to the capacity of Australian workers to seek a private view amongst themselves of an action that may be imposed upon them. I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I supplement the views that have been expressed by my leader, Senator Button, I want to make two comments on the speech by Senator Scott. The first one, and it does not relate to him personally, involves a case of me-too-ism. We often ask: What is a justifiable strike? Senator Scott spoke about the detrimental effects of strikes on our exports. I suppose the classic illustration is the coal miners in Collinsville who were aided and abetted by the local National Party member, Pinky Lester. I think Senator Bjelke-Petersen, the new senator from Queensland, will say 'amen' to the point I am making. Her husband, the Premier of Queensland, said: 'Yes boys, Howard is wrong. You are entitled to some rebate on your rent in an isolated area'. This led to a classic major dispute. I can assure honourable senators that, as a reader of Common Cause which I receive every month, I know that all criticism in that case was aimed at the Federal Government and John Howard. There was not one bit of criticism of the Queensland National Party Premier or Pinky Lester.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it can be said that the whole of the mining communities and the attendant unions-I refer to the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union and the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association-never had any need for such legislation. Nobody would deny that. The unions were unanimous. They were the victims of a tax injustice. I make the point that in situations where there is conflict between a group of people and a federal law such things will happen again. Even if we had used secret ballot provisions, the miners of Collinsville and attendant areas would have voted again and again as they did. The Queensland Premier was all for them. I understand that Senator Collard differed in his opinion. The fact is that, when a Premier-a non-socialist Premier at that-says that miners have a grievance with Canberra, different ingredients come to light. It is not a simple matter.

The second point I make relates to the latter part of Senator Scott's speech in which he replied to Senator Button. He mentioned monolithic organisations. The fact is that there is an insecurity in the mind of the average trade unionist today. If he is in his twenties and has an expected working life to 60 years of age-we hope one day it will be reduced to 55 years-he expects to have to change his occupation a couple of times. Therefore, if he is in an industry which is in the front ranks of change, he has to be pretty vigilant. I say that as a preface to the need in the containerisation industry for greater amalgamation of unions. At the moment there is an internal dispute within the Federated Clerks Union. At the risk of having people criticise me, I point out that I really believe that a tally clerk would be better off in the Waterside Workers Federation or the Federated Storemen and Packers Union than in a union covering other clerical people but away from the hurly burly of the waterfront industry.

At the moment it is a titanic task to get a successful ballot because of the fact that two unions will be participants. Let me put a hypothetical case and assume that the residue of the Federated Clerks Union in New South Wales were to have a ballot with the Transport Workers Union, the Storemen and Packers Union or the Waterside Workers Federation and that consensus of 50 per cent of all the parties had to be obtained. New members would not matter much to the Waterside Workers Federation, the Storemen and Packers Union or the Transport Workers Union which have big memberships. The new members would not disturb policy. But we will never have a successful ballot with the provisions contained in the Bill. In turn, some of the turmoil in the containerisation industry is caused by people feeling that their job opportunities are in jeopardy because of the coverage of a rival union.

Let me take this fear complex a bit further. It is expected that the membership of the Australian Railways Union which is 20,000 at present will be down to 13,000 within the next eight to 12 years. It will not be that everybody will be out of work, but there will not be the same rate of promotion and opportunities for signalmen. Obviously there will be arguments about various allowances to protect them. As Senator Button said the average rank and file member today is far better educated than was the case 10, 15 or 20 years ago.

We find that the inevitable pattern of agitation comes from site committees or area committees. It does not matter whether it comes from McBeatty of the Transport Workers Union or Carmichael of the AMWSU. I assure honourable senators that the drive and thrust comes from the bottom and it comes largely on an issue of relativity. I suppose we could say that one of the negative aspects of television is that we see all the posh advertisements showing that Jack is as good as his master and that everybody has to get things quickly. That acts as an inspiration, to use the capitalist term, to market forces. People want that relativity. That is what this is all about.

What is the usual pattern? I take the example of a dispute with the Public Transport Commission in New South Wales. The workers could be asking for an industrial allowance of $25. The PTC could come up with an offer of about $8 and say that the demand for more is not on. In such a situation we may have a series of walkouts. The dispute could go on for seven, eight or 10 days. That is usually as long as it goes. I can refer to other disputes that have never left us but did go for longer periods. But what is the pattern? The union asks for more. Premiers and Prime Ministers get into the act. The workers will probably not get their $25. But after seven or eight days they find ways and means of dressing it up again and might get $12. Then they go back and might get another $3, or penalty rates are adjusted. People may say: 'It disrupts the economy of the country.' Maybe under fascism everybody can be put into a slot and kept there but that cannot be done in a free society. Therefore, we must live with this situation of wage relativity.

No doubt some honourable senator will quote the situation in western Europe generally. In return I would quote the situation in the Scandinavian countries, or in West Germany. One of the in-built stabilisers in those countries is that the State keeps a pretty close rein on hospital and medical charges generally. I have never claimed that there is such a thing as a free lunch but those societies are more equitable than ours. Whatever wages are paid, if a process worker has to pay as much for his health coverage as does a production manager you will get dissatisfaction. The Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) may not know it-he may not have been involved at the time-but as long ago as 1967 the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) asked the Australian Council of Trade Unions how it would react in regard to future wage claims if he more or less stabilised Medibank somewhat in line with the Labor Government of 1972-75 idea of a flat rate levy. Under such a scheme you would know during the year, if you had received a good deal of overtime, that you would face a higher levy for health coverage than you would in a lean year. These are all components of the wage system. The Government has ignored that factor for six years, but it is a feature of the Scandinavian and West German trade union wage structure. If we leave Europe and go to the United States of America, the home of private enterprise, with its collective bargaining, the workers may not be as well off as ours would be in regard to holidays but we would find that many private pension schemes are better than the state would provide.

We could argue all night, and balance one factor against the other, but what are the ingredients of a dispute? Most major disputes in New South Wales result from the prodding by the rank and file of the union's officers. Under this legislation, in a dispute, the commissioner is to take note of the result of the ballot. Let us imagine that negotiations are at a stage at which the employer has offered $8 and the unions are seeking a site allowance of $25 or $30. If one votes 'no strike' one is pretty certain that one will not get much more than $8 or $9. Most Australians are inclined to indulge in a little gambling. There is no doubt that if they vote yes, for a stoppage, in the classic illustration given by Senator Button, they will then get $12 or $14. There is no way that they will not. People would be stupid to take any other attitude.

On the other hand, if one has a bald recommendation and a vote taken on the basis: Are you prepared to strike for a $30 site allowance? And a yes vote results, and somewhere down the line, the employers offer $12 or $15, the union, as Senator Button knows, is locked in. It has to go back to the rank and file for instructions. Let us take another case-a dispute on a construction site. There have been disputes in which a motion has been put, then three amendments, and ultimately one of those amendments has been carried. Honourable senators have spoken of people being denied their rights. Let me quote an illustration from a union that is in the middle range of unions. I refer to the Federated Rubber and Allied Workers Union of Australia. The employers offered the union a mixed bag, involving extra leave and extra pay and, on the other hand, what one would sacrifice. The dispute involved three shifts of about 600 men each, in metropolitan Sydney. Interpreters were provided and the proposals were put. I respectfully suggest that there is no way in which a ballot-it is not a simple yes or no matter-could produce a proper consensus, compared with going to and fro by way of motion and amendment.

In the 1950s, we used to be told that there were cases of intimidation. There may have been, but a dispute is not a tea party. At a trade union meeting, although someone may be a bully boy, there are always others with the courage to get up and express a contrary point of view. I have said time and time again that, when we speak of achieving a consensus, the classic illustration was provided by the history in Sydney of the introduction of the one-man bus. In that case the men were arguing from the standpoint of safety. They wanted the tickets collected so they would not have to worry about timetables and do that too. Also, if the bus went, say, two miles out of Sydney as an express service there would not be the same setting down and having to watch people leaving by means of bus mirrors which were not always the best. That dispute was on a stop and go basis for weeks. Finally, in spite of the conciliation commissioners offering extra money, the dispute continued. Suddenly Mr Justice Robinson, a very fine judge of the Arbitration Commission, realised that the important matter involved was safety. When he presented a proposal with that in mind, the men accepted it. It is history now that, because of safety and other reasons, the use of one-man buses has been expanded. My point, which has been supported by Senator Button, and by Senator Chipp by way of interjection, is that it is more a case of speaking in sorrow than in anger because the practicalities are simply not there.

Let us take the matter a little further. The bane of most trade unions is keeping their records up to date for the 3 year elections. I may have something to say at the Committee stage of this Bill on the matter. I have never opposed postal ballots for union elections or their being under the control of an electoral officer, but I know that keeping the address list up-to-date is the bane of the unions. We have a mobile society. Many people move every year or so to a new suburb. They do not always tell the union. If there is one thing that can create a problem, it is that. There might be a situation in which a secret ballot is conducted. It may be a tight vote, in which a tiny majority will say: 'No, we do not want to be involved in this dispute.' Then people will run to the Press and say: 'We did not get a ballot paper; it went to the last address.' The whole thing will then be called a stew and people will feel that they have been cheated or conned. That already happens. I know of trade union ballots-and this does not represent a reprimand for the Commonwealth Electoral Officer-in which ballot papers are not sent. The union member says: 'I told the union of my new address' and so on. These are some of the problems involved. In this Bill the Government is backing a loser. There is no way to get over that situation.

We hear much talk of irresponsible militants. I doubt whether any honourable senator would describe the Air Pilots Guild as comprised of left wing militants. I do not suppose that that could be said of even the air traffic controllers, many of whom live in Sydney. Certainly, those who live in the electorate of Bradfield have not a left wing member in David Connolly representing them-far from it. Let us get away from the use of labels and the talk of irresponsibility. There is a fear, an uncertainty, among any group, whether they be shearers, waterside workers or railwaymen. In trying to have a perfect private enterprise system-in the Government's eyes-and saying: 'The State keeps out of it', you may be locked in.

I have already mentioned the situation in western Europe and the effectiveness of the State's playing a bigger role in achieving stability and holding down the costs of health coverage. In a number of those countries the state may also pay heavy subsidies on basic commodities. All of this would cost the Treasury of the country money. The Prime Minister and the present Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) could call on the trade unions and say: 'We want a bit of sanity. We do not want excessive wage demands.' But, on the other hand they must say: 'In lieu of your going for an increase we will stabilise the cost of meat and potatoes', or conversely: 'I am making a very big effort to maintain health coverage on a more equitable basis, a levy upon taxable income.' Those factors are absent and that is rather significant.

I notice that Senator Scott in a vague way mentioned that the Government was still considering trade union amalgamation. In many cases a fear concerning the future of those in long term occupations arises and conflicts result. In many cases the employer is powerless to act. These are matters that should have been dealt with, but they have not been. A host of the top line Chamber of Manufactures people-those who are involved in heavy industry-know that what the Government is doing will not resolve the situation one bit. The United States coal miners have had a 13-week stoppage and look like reaching some decision today. So lengthy strikes are not a phenomenon restricted to Australia. I mentioned West Germany. Workers in that country are having their problems now because obviously inflation has eroded their wages. They are in a difficult situation and some of their unions are no longer taking a passive approach.

I return to this idea of directions with regard to stoppages coming from the top of a union. Invariably they come from the bottom because of a new style of rank and file member. But there are two other points in this situation. Safety provision is one difficulty which today looms largely in many industries. Frankly, sometimes it is only when a certain piece of equipment is suddenly declared unsafe that people stop work and inspectors go in. Recently we were discussing the Industrial Relations Bureau and there were a lot of platitudes about its work. But when we look at its performance in the field, we see that no figures can be given about how quickly and regularly it carries out inspections. I feel that had the Government wanted a package deal, although we found the ballot system unworkable, and had it put out an olive branch and accelerated some union amalgamations, there is no doubt that that would have been taken as evidence of good faith. I do not doubt that if the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), with his charisma and reasonableness, still held the portfolio of industrial relations he would not have been a party to this legislation. After all, the Government has nothing to lose by it. If the Government gave us our head in relation to trade union amalgamations and found that there was still a high degree of unruliness, it could say that the unions had let it down.

The Government has talked about technological changes and we have a mass of material on the research it has done. Despite that, the current dispute with the communications unions and the situation concerning Justice Mary Gaudron show that it is quite obvious that we cannot have one simple format to meet all these situations. People in industry feel that if they get behind it is very hard to get parity again. When we get amalgamations of unions it is surprising what can be done. Senator McIntosh could tell the Senate of the situation of the shipwrights union-a small craft union and very jealous of it. In the shipbuilding industry, with flexibility from such unions as the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, there was no Custer's last stand about people protecting their jobs. Again that was done on a craft basis. Unquestionably in the container industry, which is run on a non-craft basis, at some stage there will have to be an absorption of tally clerks into the Waterside Workers Federation or the Federated Storemen and Packers Union. That cannot be done at the moment because of the lack of leadership on merger proposals. That is an area in which the number of strikes can be reduced dramatically. As I said, I will have plenty more to say on one or two other aspects of this legislation in the Committee stage.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chaney) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chaney) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This will be a very short burst. Senator Carrick is not in the chamber, but I think it is time the Government put its flag to the mast, as it were, and indicated to us its attitude with regard to the format of committee operations in the next session. I will illustrate the situation in this way: In the weekend Press there were indications that among the Vietnamese community a sort of Tong war appeared to be going on with people chopping off other people's fingers. This shows the mess we have got in. The logical thing would be for Estimates Committee D, a very talented committee which looks after immigration, to meet and to call before it immigration officials and people from the Vietnamese community to probe whether those reports are wrong or grossly exaggerated. That is an illustration of how Estimates committees could be ongoing.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kathy Martin and Senator Kilgariff have expressed the view, which I and others on this side share, that Estimates committees should do much more than consider Supplementary Estimates and then meet again in September, because things happen between those meetings. If we had ongoing Senate committees we would be able to get to the heart of matters and get quick answers, whether they be with respect to finance, which Senator Martin has been going on about, or with respect to administration, in my case. I just picked the allegations with respect to the Vietnamese community as a classic point. If Laurie Oakes can hint that something has been decided, I think honourable senators here should get from the Government some indication of what is going to happen.

In the next session there will be new honourable senators on both sides of the chamber. What functions will they have on these committees? I expect Senator Chaney and Senator Durack, who are at the table, to say not later than Friday that next session Estimates committees will be ongoing and will meet situations such as I have instanced. Conversely, they may feel that the various ministries should be apportioned to standing committees. I know that honourable senators opposite are asking for answers, and we should have them.

Every time the United States has serious problems it sets up committees. It did so when there was an exodus from Cuba after Castro had switched on a few doubtful people who were supposed to be running away from communism but some of whom were perverts and gangsters. The United States was stuck with them. I do not apply that situation to our immigration program, but I think we have a responsibility to have a committee, whether it be Estimates Committee D or some other committee, which meets all year round to consider such matters and to oversee what is happening. It may well be that immigration officers will have some interesting explanations to give.

Anybody who perused the transcript of proceedings of Estimates Committee D a month or so ago would have seen that the Committee heard a long story about what Fairfield had done to placate people. That may be all right, but the Queensland branch of the Waterside Workers Federation would give a different story about how one or two of the Vietnamese here are still fighting the war over there. If they had shown as much militancy in fighting there as they are showing here, they might have got a different result. My view is that some of them represent a merchant class that lived off black markets and prostitution, and now they have come here. I would like to have some of their leaders before a Senate committee to get the answers which people do not get when they are interviewed.

I make no bones about what I am after. We should have these ongoing committees. We should be able to probe such situations to find out what the truth is because, whatever views I might have, when something is written in a newspaper it is not probed. The United States Senate and House of Representatives have committees which move in quickly and to which people can put their points of view. If some people in the Vietnamese community thought I had been a bit harsh, they would have an opportunity to come before a committee and explain to me how I had been conned by a newspaper report. So I am being very charitable.

I speak for every honourable senator on this side. We are entitled to know, before the session ends, what the Government's plans are for Senate Estimates committees. The various newspapers are hinting that something has been decided. As a matter of fact, there is a rumour about Senator Rae. I have a lot of respect for Senator Rae as a parliamentarian. I understand-I am indebted to Michelle Grattan of the Age for this rumour-that he is to become a second Deputy President to round up all the committes. That may be good. We get a lot of talk at times about the functions of committees and how they can be improved. I agree with that talk. But before the Parliament rises, which I do not think will be before next week, Senator Carrick has to tell us what he has in mind. If he does, he will find that the Senate will work better because, when the new senators arrive, he will be able to tell them what committees are available. I notice that Senator Kilgariff is in the chamber. I think he agrees that I have given him an endorsement. He believes in what I am saying-or Laurie Oakes says that he does. I leave it at that. I hope we will get an answer from Senator Carrick. He is the chief helmsman in this place. He has to give us an answer before Friday or the middle of next week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I note the matters raised by Senator Mulvihill on the adjournment. Unfortunately, I am not in close contact with either Michelle Grattan or Laurie Oakes so I am not fully apprised of honourable senators' views. I will refer the matter to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Carrick. However, I think that most honourable senators would accept that the development of the Senate committee system and, indeed, its functioning is not a matter which proceeds on the fiat of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Indeed, most changes have followed extensive expression of views by honourable senators in the chamber, at meetings of the Standing Orders Committee and in the other forums which honourable senators have for this purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: It may not be possible for Senator Carrick to respond in the simple and direct way he has been asked to by Senator Mulvihill this evening. I suspect that if he sought to do so a large proportion of the Senate would find that quite objectionable. I will refer the matter to him. I think it is generally accepted that sorting out the direction of the committee system is never at an end. It is a matter in which the developments of the last 10 years, I think, have raised new problems for honourable senators who are functioning in committees. I trust that we will be able to come up-if not by Friday then in the slightly longer term-with answers to the questions raised by the honourable senator.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 12.2 a.m. (Wednesday).
