The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Treasurer aware of a scheme promoting Adler Business Machines Pty Ltd advertised in the Bulletin dated 17 February 1981.
(2) Does the scheme advertise a 'fantastic tax-free bonus' of a 'cruising holiday free' for five days in return for the leasing of a typewriter.

(3) Has this offer been investigated by the Commissioner of Taxation to determine whether the benefit constitutes non-salary income; if so, what action will be taken in response to any investigations which have occurred.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treaurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) The taxation issues arising from this offer have previously been brought to the attention of the Commissioner of Taxation. Because of the secrecy provisions of the income tax law, he is unable to comment specifically on the taxation affairs of the company concerned or of any of its customers. However, by way of general comment, the Commissioner advises that the income tax implications of any purported 'tax-free' schemes which are drawn to his attention are investigated to ensure that any tax payable is correctly brought into account.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 24 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any studies been carried out by Australian departments into the radiation levels present in marine life in the Pacific Ocean; if so, (a) where and when were these studies carried out; (b) what was their scope; and (c) what results were obtained.
(2) Are any such studies being carried out at present.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am not aware of any studies that have been carried out by Australian departments into the radiation levels present in marine life in the Pacific.
(2) I am not aware that any such studies are being carried out at present.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 25 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has there been an outbreak of 'dieback' among trees on the banks of the Mary River in Queensland; if so, has the Federal Government any authority to investigate this problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am not aware of 'dieback' occurring to any significant extent among trees on the banks of the Mary River in Queensland.

The Commonwealth may investigate problems such as 'dieback'. However, State authorities have prime responsibility for investigating particular plant disease outbreaks. If they wish, they may request assistance from appropriate Commonwealth authorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 25 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the sewage treatment and disposal plan for Jabiru, Northern Territory, have: (a) a treatment plant consisting of four oxidation lagoons with a design retention time of 37 days, (b) an anticipated effluent quality similar to that at Leanyer Treatment Lagoon, Darwin which will contain high nutrient concentrations as well as algae; and (c) effluent disposal in the wet season by way of discharge to Magela Creek at a point just upstream of Gulungul billabong.
(2) What alternative treatment strategies were considered and on what grounds were they rejected.
(3) What special chemicals including, inter alia, pesticides, disinfectants, oils from service stations, et cetera, will enter the sewage sytem and how will the treatment cope with these.
(4) Was there any consideration of adding the sewage effluent to the Ranger tailings dam.
(5) Was any consideration given to passing the treated effluent through a special macrophyte pond before discharge so as to reduce the levels of suspended solids and nutrients.
(6) What changes will be caused in the immediate vicinity of the sewage discharge in Magela Creek and further downstream, particularly in backflow areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (b) Yes, however the nutrient concentrations will be below that expected from a conventional secondary sewage treatment plant, for example, activated sludge treatment because of the long detention time.

(2) Activated sludge systems were considered to be inappropriate because of the more complex and expensive plant which would not produce effluent as good as that from oxidation lagoons, are more prone to mechanical breakdown, and do not have the shock loading capability of lagoons which are ideally suited to the Northern Territory climate.

(3) Special chemicals will not enter the sewage system. Special provisions are made for the collection and disposal of service station oils, as part of building permit conditions. Pesticides are more likely to be present in stormwater drainage.

(4) The Office of the Supervising Scientist expressed concern about the disposal of sewage effluent into the tailings dam because of the added potential for biological growth and the subsequent attraction to birds.

(5) The containment of macrophyte growth, for example, salvinia in a pond would present serious problems with the possibility of marked adverse effects if such plants escaped to the water courses in the area.

(6) A small increase in the quantity of suspended solids and nutrients will occur in the Magela Creek in the immediate vicinity of the effluent outfall. However, it is expected that this increase will be quickly dispersed and will have little effect on conditions downstream.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Australia capable of producing enough highly enriched uranium by the laser process to operate a small scale nuclear weapons program.
(2) How much enriched uranium has been produced by the laser program in Australia and of what level of enrichment has it been.

(3) Is the laser uranium enrichment research conducted by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission (AAEC) covered by International Atomic Energy Agency standards; if so (a) what are these safeguards; (b) which documents are they written into; and (c) are those documents available to the public.

(4) Have there been any papers published by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission on the laser separation of uranium isotopes; if not why have no papers been published on the subject given that the AAEC has been working on the laser separation of uranium isotopes since the early 1970s.
(5) What efforts have been made to weigh up the benefits as well as the risks of Australia developing laser uranium enrichment.
(6) Have any Governments been advised that Australia is developing what has been described as 'the best proliferation option yet'.
(7) Does Australia have suitable planes and ships for the delivery of weapons developed by the laser uranium process.
(8) What role has been played by the University of New England in the development of laser uranium isotope separation facilities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. In any event, by its ratification in 1973 of the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT), Australia accepted an obligation not to develop a nuclear weapons program.

(2) Australian work on enrichment using the laser uranium isotope separation process has been confined to a program of AAEC laboratory studies and only milligram quantities of uranium have been involved in the experiment. Enrichment levels achieved are confidential.

(3) Yes; enrichment research work at the AAEC Research Establishment involves safeguardable nuclear material which is subject to International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards implemented pursuant to Australia's ratification of the NPT. The safeguards Agreement between the IAEA and Australia is available as the IAEA document INFCIRC/217 dated 13 December 1974 and is also in the Australian Treaty series, 1974 No. 16. As noted in the annual reports of the Australian Safeguards Office, the IAEA has indicated that Australia has satisfactorily discharged its safeguards-related obligations assumed under the NPT.
(4) Some unclassified work arising from the laser isotope research program has been published where it was assessed that publication would not constitute a risk of proliferation.
(5) The full range of implications for Australia of the development of this technology is the subject of continuing study.

(6) Successive Commonwealth Governments have been kept informed of the AAEC's research program on the use of laser technology for uranium enrichment. As regards the non-proliferation aspects of the program, see (1) and (3).

(7) The enrichment process used in preparing weapons-grade material should not, of itself, have any effect on weapons design. Many conventional weapons platforms, including some of Australia's, could also be used for the delivery of nuclear weapons. As noted in (1) however, Australia has accepted an obligation not to develop nuclear weapons.

(8) The University of New England was involved at an early stage of the project through an unclassified research contract to provide advice on laser technology. It has not been involved in the AAEC uranium isotope separation program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the joint Federal-New South Wales Police task force established in 1979 to investigate drug trafficking offences still operating.
(2) How many Federal officers are attached to the task force, and what has the cost of Commonwealth involvement been so far.
(3) How many drug traffickers have been arrested by the task force so far.
(4) What quantity of heroin has so far been seized by the task force.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) At present 15 members of the Australian Federal Police as well as one administrative officer and two typists employed by my Department are attached to the task force. The estimated operational costs of Commonwealth involvement (including salaries and allowance of the administrative support staff and purchase or hire of plant and equipment) until the end of the current financial year are $380,919, being the net result of a gross Commonwealth outlay of $600,646 and reimbursement of $219,727 by the New South Wales Government under a cost sharing agreement. Each parent police force meets the salaries of its police officers seconded to the task force.

(3) The method of operation of the task force was laid down by the Williams and Woodward Royal Commissions, namely, to target drug trafficking groups, particularly some which the Royal Commissioners indicated would take some time to investigate. Recently both the New South Wales and Commonwealth Governments required the task force to investigate the drug related aspects of the Nugan Hand Bank and persons involved in drug trafficking in any association with the operation of the Bank-in conjunction with the Corporate Affairs Commission of New South Wales.

I am informed that up to 1 May 1981 the task force, constituted by officers of the New South Wales Police and Australian Federal Police-in liaison with the Corporate Affairs Commission of New South Wales, had broken up five major groups (that is involving at least four persons each group) with one group of 11 persons involved in the importation of heroin as well as one major and three minor groups supplying heroin and one minor group supplying morphine (six major and four minor groups). In consequence a total of 66 offenders has been charged on a total of 186 counts, 40 per sons in relation to the import or supply of heroin and three in relation to the supply of morphine.
(4) Up until 21 April 1981 a total of 718.5 grams of heroin had been seized by the task force.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neal Sen L.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details of the work of the World Tourism Organisation of which Australia is a member.
(2) What does Australia gain from participating in the World Tourism Organisation.
(3) What nations are members of the Organisation in the Asian-Pacific region.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The fundamental aim of WTO is to encourage the development of tourism with a view to contributing to economic and social development, paying particular attention to the interests of developing nations.
Major activities of the WTO are:
firstly, offering National Tourism Administrations and Organisations the machinery enabling a multinational approach to international discussion and negotiation on tourism subjects,
secondly, providing a world clearing-house for the collection, analysis and dissemination of technical tourism information,
thirdly, providing technical assistance to national and regional government tourism agencies relating to organisation, administration and other management functions,
fourthly, fostering the adoption of measures and policies directed to removal of governmental barriers to free movement of travellers,

fifthly, providing the machinery for international conferences, seminars, study commissions, task forces and other means for focussing up-to-date information and expertise on matters relating to tourism development,
sixthly, encouraging, carrying out and publishing research studies on matters relating to international tourism,
seventhly, assisting in matters concerned with vocational training with a view to contributing to the establishment of adequate training programs, and

eighthly, serving as spokesman for tourism at the international level and collaborating in tourism development planning with other international agencies both as a participating and executing agency where appropriate.

(2) Full membership of the WTO allows Australia access to comprehensive statistical data and extensive information on regulations, facilities and special events. Given the rapidly increasing importance of the tourist industry to the Australian economy, the information is a useful aid to decision-making by Commonwealth and State Governments as well as by the Australian tourist and travel industry.
Membership also allows Australia to develop closer liaison with WTO member countries particularly in the Pacific/East Asia region.

(3) The following nations, comprising the WTO's Regional Commissions for South Asia (CSA) and East Asia and the Pacific (CAP), of which Australia is currently vice-Chairman, are full members of the Organisation in the Asian-Pacific region,
firstly, in CSA; Afghanistan, India, Nepal, Pakistan, Republic of Bangladesh, Sri Lanka,
secondly, in CAP; Australia, Democratic Kampuchea, Indonesia, Japan, Lao Peoples Democratic Republic, Malaysia, Philippines, Republic of Korea, Socialist Republic of Vietnam and Thailand, and
thirdly, the United States of America, Mexico and the Union of Soviet Republics, though not members of CSA or CAP are full members of the Organisation.

(2) What research has been conducted in this area of child education and what have been the results and recommendations of such research.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My Department is aware of the work of Dr Glen Doman, who has written books about the education of children of pre-school age, in particular with regard to the teaching of reading and mathematics. He has had experience with both normal and brain-injured children. Dr Doman advocates the introduction to reading at the age of two to three years. The approach is generally one of getting children to recognise initially words rather than letters of the alphabet.

(2) The views of educationists differ as to whether the sight-word technique advocated by Dr Doman is the best way to introduce children to reading. While some children may benefit from such teaching at an early age, researchers have yet to show that this is desirable for all pre-school children.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, is the Information Technology Council to be abolished.
(2) What were the functions of that institution.
(3) Was it performing its functions inadequately in any way and, if so, in what way was it inadequate.
(4) What action is proposed to take over the functions originally performed by the Information Technology Council.
(5) As a result of the action, what Government services can be expected to be affected, and in what way will they be affected.

(6) As a result of the action will any information which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that information, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.

(7) As a result of the Review will any informed advice or co-ordinating capacity which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that informed advice or co-ordinating capacity, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.
(8) What is the estimated saving in abolishing the Information Technology Council.
(9) What is the estimated short and long term cost of not having the services of the Information Technology Council available to the Government and the community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government has withdrawn from participation in the Information Technology Council, which comprised representatives of various professional and Government bodies. It is likely that the Council will become inactive as a result of the Government's withdrawal.
(2) The Information Technology Council has the objective of assisting Australian business, industry and Government to improve productivity through the better use of information technology.

(3) The Information Technology Council was a source of advice on the design, the implementation and the results of Government programs associated with information technology. However, the Government felt that participation in a formal organisation was no longer a necessary part of the process of obtaining advice.

(8) There will be a saving in departmental expenditure of approximately $3,000 a year.
(9) There is no identifiable cost, either to the Government or to the community, arising from the Government's withdrawal from participation in the Information Technology Council.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1569), Senator Gietzelt asked me, as the Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question without notice concerning the future of Towra Point, Sydney.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has provided the following answer for the honourable senator's information:

The property, of some 282 hectares on the southern side of Botany Bay, was acquired by the Commonwealth in 1975 for the establishment of a nature reserve under the provisions of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. Towra Point contains biologically valuable coastal wetland ecosystems and is of special international significance for the protection of migratory birds.

The honourable senator would be aware that a number of surplus Commonwealth properties, particularly in the Sydney area, have recently been transferred to New South Wales. These properties have, in the main, formed the basis of the Sydney Harbour National Park. On 19 February this year, the Minister for Administrative Services in a joint press release with the New South Wales Ministers for Lands and for Planning and Environment, identified Towra Point for inclusion in the next group of land transfers. Action is in hand to complete the formal transfer of the land to New South Wales.

The State Government has agreed that the appropriate future use of the property is as a nature reserve, managed by the New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service with the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service assisting in the preparation of the plan of management and being represented on the management advisory committee. The terms agreed between the Commonwealth and the State for the transfer of this land prevent Towra Point from being used for other purposes, such as an airport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1814) Senator Sibraa asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer to the election of the Socialist candidate, Mr Mitterrand, as the President of France. As his attitude towards French independence movements in the South Pacific is likely to vary from that of his predecessor and as his views will therefore be closer to the Australian Government's attitude on the area, will the Australian Government take the first opportunity to inform the new French President of our views on these matters?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Mr Mitterrand was elected President of France on 10 May. He assumed the office of the Presidency on 21 May. Mr Mitterrand has foreshadowed legislative elections before the end of June to seek a working majority in the National Assembly.

The Government acknowledges the importance attached to the question and the desirability of registering our interests and concerns with the new French Government. This it will do as soon as it is appropriate.

The Senate will be aware that in a message to Mr Mitterrand the Prime Minister noted the importance we attach to our relations with France and said that he looked forward to the further development of bilateral relations, drawing strength from our shared concern for the peace and stability of the international community, as well as from the importance that both countries attach to the South Pacific.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1389) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, a question without notice concerning systems analysts and computer programmers.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Full time courses in computing and systems analysis are offered by 17 universities and 14 colleges of advanced education and some technical and further education colleges, at certificate, associate diploma, diploma, undergraduate bachelor degree and graduate diploma levels. All such courses are approved for the purposes of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS). Students who already have completed an undergraduate degree are normally ineligible for TEAS whilst undertaking a second undergraduate degree except to the extent that the minimum duration of the second course exceeds that of the first. (The only exception to this is where the two courses form part of an approved combined course under the Scheme, e.g. the Bachelor of Business Studies /Bachelor of Applied Science (EDP) at Caulfield Institute of Technology.) Graduates are, however, eligible for assistance whilst undertaking a graduate diploma such as a Graduate Diploma in Computer Science or a Graduate Diploma in Information Science. Given the wide availability of such courses and the scope for assistance under TEAS, it is not considered necessary to provide additional special measures to assist in the training of systems analysts and computer programmers.

It is also relevant to note that the Government has already announced, in principle, that it will support the transfer of resources in universities and colleges of advanced education to increase enrolments in technology and business studies courses. In 1982 and 1983 it will earmark $5m per annum to assist in this process. It will be a matter for the Tertiary Education Commission and individual institutions to consider particular levels of enrolment in various types of courses but the Government expects that manpower considerations will be a major factor in determining the areas in which enrolments will expand.
